Bottle. I respect the high raitings for this beer, cause its very complex and unique, even though I couldn´t really enjoy it myself. Its too much of everything reallly... too spicy, too sweet, too alcoholic, too complex, too strange...

Botella de 330ml. Copa de Vino. Resaboreada en jun´12 a veces me gusta volver a las cervezas de mis inicios-. Color oro y apariencia ligeramente velada. Corona amplia, firme y persistente, de burbuja pequeña y textura cremosa. Aromas de levadura, malta caramelo, azúcar y caramelos, trazos de naranjas y albaricoques maduros y toques especiados. Gentil y no empalagosa entrada agridulce. Paladar suave, cremoso y afrutado con notas de toffee. Cálida y punzante sensación alcohólica en el intermedio. Cuerpo medio e intenso y carbonatación moderada. Final de suave especiado. El retrogusto muestra el carácter malteado y dulce y la fruta madura. Cerveza muy bien equilibrada. Asimilación muy agradable incluso en un día caluroso. ¡¡Guau!!
330ml bottle. Oversized glass. Reenjoyed on jun´12 sometimes I like to come to my early stage beers- Gold color, slightly foggy appearance. Thick, firm, lasting, small bubbled crown. Creamy texture. Yeasty, caramel malt, sugar & candy aromas, hints of ripe orange & apricot , spiced hues too. Gentle no cloying sweet-bitter upfront. Smooth creamy, fruity mouthfeel. Toffee notes. Spicy & kind warming feeling in the middle. Medium & flavorful body, moderate carbonation. Smooth spiced finish. Sweet ripe fruit & sweet malty character are shown on the aftertaste. Very well balanced beer. Very pleasant drinkability even in a hot day. Wow!!!

Pours muddy yellow with medium white head.
Aromas of citrus, oranges, sweet malts and belgian yeasy. Nice!
Taste is very, how should i put it, clean. Sweet taste of peaches, some citrusy fruits, a bit fudge.
Palate is very nice. It starts sweet which it keeps doing all through the mouth. Ending is slightly bitter which aldo i nice.  Its a very very good tripel.

Yellow to light orange, hazy, with medium white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is fresh, citrus, fruit, grass, very little yeast tones, but some coriander and herbs. Taste is initially slightly bitter and pungent, before turning sweet. There is a robust bitter backbone all through, however. Surprisingly strong presence of alcohol, especially in the finish. Warming. Medium body and carbonation.

Ar: Citric, fruity, floral, spices, corn, alcohol, hay, herbs.
Ap: golden colour, medium white head.
F: Acidity, brettlike, citric, spices, floral, fruity, alcohol.
M: High carbonation.
T: Enjoyable.

Trevlig fruktighet. Fin smak av tutti frutti och skumbanan. Stor trevlig fruktig smak. En mycket god belgare. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pours hazy golden with a thick foamy head that settles but stays. The aroma is slightly discrete but delicious, fruit candy and yeasty scents, and malt. The taste is spicy, fruity, sweet, but ends slightly watery(?). Theres hop bitterness in the aftertaste. The palate is quite full and the carbonation lower than what is usual in belgian beers, however that allows the consumer to better savor the beer. Its a good triple, a wonderful appetizer I think. Hmmm, whats for dinner?

I try not to be too harsh on tripels because i usually dont care for them.  This one wasnt too bad with a nice light noble hop type floral/fruit taste and that standard cracker, dough, hay malt that I dont care much for.  Pretty decent though.

Pours a fairly orange color with plenty of bubbly head. The aroma is light, subtle and complex. Im detecting malt, banana and spice. The taste is similar with a bit of malt, bread, yeast, banana, spice and a little citrus. This is a lighter flavor than I expected but still quite subtle, smooth and delicate. Nothing is overbearing, very balanced. It is light on the tongue and a nice warm finish.
pours cloudy orange with a finger of white head. Smells of wheat, cloves, banana and yeast. Tastes about the same with hints of oats and sourness. Slightly bitter warming finish.
Vanilla and citrus aroma. Sweet alcohol dominates the first draught, some spices in the following ones.

Pour a clear light golden color with a robust white head. The brew clouded as the yeast in the bottom of the bottle is poured in. Typical Belgian lacing observed. The nose hints at light fruit (apples - pears) and cereal. The taste is very similar with just a mice bit of spice in the finish. The body is medium but effervescence gives the impression of a lighter feel. There is a slight bitter after taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330 ml bottle poured into a Westmalle chalice.  Use by date of 8/12/14.  Pours a cloudy pale yellow.  With a large fluffy head that dissipates at a medium rate leaving behind lots of lacing.  Smells of bread dough, yeast, banana, pear, and light clove.  Taste is bready, yeast, banana, pear, other light fruits and a barely detectable alcohol warmth.  Has a medium bitter dry finish.  Not overly sweet, very balanced.  Full mouthfeel with a lively level of carbonation.  Very good beer, never disapoints.
Hey ist a flowery bready standard poster child for triples. Alright but I like the cleaner ones
Sweet pear-like aroma. Pale golden body.  Taste is sweet and fruity balanced by a sourness that picks up in the aftertaste.  Not much else going on, but a decent beer.  Not my favorite.

330ml bottle.  Pours light gold with a large, frothy head.  Aroma is candy sugars, light straw and clove.  Subtle.  Taste is very yeasty, banana and clove.  Clove in the dry finish.  Very lively in the mouth.
UPDATED: JUN 2, 2012 Bottle 11.2 oz. into tulip. Pours amber orange with a frothy head. Aroma is light malty fruity, citrus with some caramel. Flavor is light sweet. Nice thick moulth feel.

Lovely beer! Pours pale orange with a quickly dissipating head. Minimal lacing. Nose is raw dough with a hint of candy. Mouth is good balance of sweet fruit and light bread and malts. Finish is mild bitter. Lively carbonation, medium body in the mouth. Awesome!

Poured into a Tappist glass, the beer looks perfect with a nice head with very good retention, aroma is yeasty and earthy, the taste is not as sweet as I thought it would be, medium carbonation with some snap, warth from the alcohol is very noticeable and slight bitterness.

Bottle from Ninas. Pours a light golden colour with a thick, rocky white head. Aroma of candy sugar, grassy hops, caramel, biscuity malt and alcohol. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and a chewy mouth-feel. Mildly bitter with lingering lemon and grassy hops again. Quite dry with well balanced alcohol.

I had such high expectations for this beer that i ordered 6 of them at Christmas. They didnt last long! There is a distinct dough smell  and the taste is pepper, yeast and sweet fruits. Its a great combination. I remember there was a little more alcohol presence for an 8% ABV but its all good. Cant wait to get more.

28 Oct 2009: I wrote this. 33cl bottle, best before 08 Mar 10. Had this bottle for some time, my wife and I are staying at the brewery in two weeks time, so Ive decided to open the one remaining St Bernardus I own before we travel. Very suprised to see Ive never reviewed the tripel before.

Poured carefully into a Westmalle Chaice; no sediment in the pour, so a clear old gold body sits in my glass, on top a solid foam blanket of bubbles. Bubbles rise through the beer, it looks inviting. The head has the power, strenght and condition to stay complete throughout the tasting, very rare, even on the best tripels. The sediment was poured into a small wine tasting glass, it was taken after the review.

Dough aromas, with yeast, but this isnt any sort of bread in my hand. The sediment had a more vinegarous and potent smell.

A deep warm glow desends down your body as you sip the beer, this is good stuff. It feels a lot heavier than the 8%ABV it admits too, some real body in this master of tripels.

I am very lucky (various reasons) and have had many Belgian tripels, both on tap and bottled, this is without doubt one of the best.

I mentioned in the review I would be staying at the brewery, well the first beer I had from the fridge in the Brouwershuys was a Triple and it was poured for me by no less than Hans Depypere, the owner of the brewery. The fridge is free to use if you are staying at the lovely appointed and furnished B&B.
First thing that comes to mind is the incredible sweet taste of this beer. Sweet with fruity notes this was a very enjoyable and one I would have/ looking forward to having again
Lightbrown, cloudy with flakes. White thick fine foam. Mild aroma of apricot. Medium body high in carbon. Taste is caramel mixed with apricot. Bitterness comes later and gets magnified and lasts long
Bottle. Orange amber with a thin head. Aroma is quite peppery. Flaour is tangy caramel with a dry bitter pepper base. Finish is very dry light chocolate.

Sunday Night I was drinking this because I wanted something fresh and sweet. A Dear friend of mine sent me an SMS, she wanted to meet me to have the opportunity to talk about my travel in NYC. 
I drunk it all in less than 10 seconds because I had to accompany her and I was like: "woow" 
1)Fresh
2) Particularry sweet
3) Saisons beer taste 
4) ALCOHOLIC 
5) in some parts it is fizzy and bitter! 

You want something sweet and "strong"? Drink this! 

Thanks Egy for the night! I will never forget this beer!

Hazy golden color, lots of yeast. Clear white lasting foam, high carbonated. Strong smell and bit of sweet taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle to glass to mouth. Modest yeast/fruit aroma. Cloudy gold in colour. Lots of sour and bitter, rich taste. Crisp, medium carbonation. 
This beer traveled a long way to find me and Id be happy to catch it closer to home; the extended voyage may have done this tripel a disservice.

A - Fruity and floral with coriander
A - Hazy gold with white frothy head
T - Sour with light sweet finishing with mid bitter
P - Mid to full and soft
O - Great
Bottle with Nate. Yeast, tropical fruit, caramel, pepper, alcohol. A decent body, medium carbonation.
Poured from bottle in glass yellowish to orange color. Aroma of floral and citrus fruit. Very good tripel.

Rappel pour nos amis américains. Cette bière nest pas une trappiste !!
La brasserie St Bernard fait partie des "Belgian Family Brewers", même
si effectivement à un moment donné, elle a obtenu le droit de brasser 
selon la recette des pères Trappistes. Ceci est une exception assez rare
pour bien entendu être mentionné, et puis attirer lattention sur cette bière précieuse....
Cette triple titre à 8 % abv et mon exemplaire était à date au 11/5/2012.
Au versage, elle est extraordinairement vivante avec des milliers de bulles très fines partout, et une belle mousse blanche encore assez stable... Sa couleur de "blé dor", doré clair, est splendide.
Les arômes sont sur lamertume du houblon, le blé sec, et une pointe de
gingembre.
La texture de la première gorgée est soyeuse à épaisse.
La première bouche est superbe de fraîcheur, avec lorge mûr et une 
pointe dabricot et de fruits confits. On sent que la complexité va être au
rendez-vous...
Deuxième nez toujours aussi frais.
Deuxième bouche où lamertume du houblon souligne un caractère et 
une très belle complexité.
Le troisième nez trouve un petit zeste dorange très fine.
La 3ème bouche ne faiblit pas et transmet un maximun dimpressions...
avec une petite touche de citron pressé et dagrumes.
La levure est dense, vineuse et digne dune spéciale.
La longueur est très belle, et les impressions en progression.
Lalcool est bien dosé, et prouve encore une fois que 8 est la bonne mesure pour une triple.
La finaleest équilibrée et fait encore découvrir dautres éléments qui viennent sajouter à une palette déjà bien riche...
Nous découvrons ici le grand peintre flamand qui fait sortir de son pinceau et de ses couleurs une harmonie qui ne faiblit jamais, et nous
montre la voie du paradis.
Le savoir-faire de St Bernard est ici dans toute sa majesté.
Respirons au dessus de notre verre, humons, sentons, puis dégustons
ce nectar qui ne peut que rejoindre le divin...
Une blonde sans reproche.

Poured into a Duvel tulip from an 11.2 ounce bottle best before 9-16-2014.

A: Hazy amber/brown body with a thick creamy white head. Sediment floating in the body.

T: Lots of flavor here. Slight floral notes up front with ripe fruits into a cloves spice and a slightly medicinal finish of fruits and alcohol.

M: Full creamy body with excellent fizzy carbonation. Sightly bready.

O: Im enjoying this very much, easy to drink and enjoy.

Poured into the glass it has a hazy yellowish orange with a large head. The aroma has floral notes and some fresh baked bread. Taste is slightly bitter with some flowers. Little bit of citrus and a bite on the finish.
Golden colour. Aroma of coriander and citrus fruit. Taste is spicy, fruity, citrus. A very good tripel.

One of the best tripel i had.
Great aroma...really crisp and fruity.
Body is perfectly balanced...
Taste: yeast,malt,citrus....

Bottle. Pours golden with a big white head that lasts long. Little aroma, could make up some typical Belgian yeast and some fruityness. Bit like tangerine and orange. Flavour is incredibly mellow and easy drinkable. Low carbonation, full bitter sweet flavour. This is good tripel, will definitely pick this up again soon!

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2013 Dark blond with quick fading head. The aroma is yeasty. The flavour has quite a moderated sweetness unlike some other Tripels. Less towards banana and more towards frangipane. The yeastyness is present in the finish.
Excellent tripel. Opaque gold with a thick, retaining white head. Asian pear and brioche nose. Clean, carbonated mouthfeel. Medium bodied with tree fruit and some savory notes. Sweet finish.
golden pour with a white head. nose is dried fruits, yeast, light musk, and spices. easy on the palate, smooth dried fruits, backed by spices and yeast.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2012 Aroma floreale, speziato con qualche sentore di pepe nero. Al palato si presenta molto equilibrata con una dolcezza, contrastata da un buon amaro. In bocca si avverte un pizzicore dato dal lievito e una presenza di pera con un infinitesimale presenta di radice di liquirizia. Finale persistente e gustoso che invitano, più che a berla, a sorseggiarla. Risulta davvero evocativa in bocca. Ottima. Ecco perchè il monaco sorride.
Pours a cloudy gold with a thin white head.  Spicy fruit, clove, and pepper aromas.  Similar flavors with a hint of banana.  Medium to light body with low carbonation.  Finishes dry.

Aroma complejo, el cual no permite distingur de forma sencilla sus componentes. Aromas frutales con un final a canela.
A la vista es una cerveza con excelente y densa espuma, liquido color dorado cobrizo, opaco, turbiedad que se nota en la copa.
El primer contacto con la cerveza se torna muy plano sin dejar sentir su segunda fermentación en botella
Al trago se siente un poco la dulzura y gardo alcoholico.
En general, una buena cerveza, de la cual, sin embrgo, esperaba mucho mas.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2012 From bottle into short stemmed glass at Capital Ale House Richmond VA. Interesting beer, thick white head no lacing, sweet starchy aroma. Bitter sweet taste, more sweet than bitter. Palate was highly carbonated and a bit harsh going down. Not great but good. Expected much more.

Hazy golden yellow with a massive off-white head that retains impressively and incredibly active carbonation. The aroma has some tropical fruit notes upfront, along with spices, biscuit, candy sugar. The flavor is initially yeasty with some tropical and citrus fruit notes.

Bottle, approximately two years or more old.  Whoops?  Pours a deeply muddled browned amber with a medium sized off white head.  Malty and sweet on the nose, soft and gentle oxidization.  Medium bodied, soft chocolate, malt and warmth.  A touch of oxidization on the finish, and some warmth.

aroma: alcohol, caramel, floral, bread
apparenza: cloudy, amber, frothy
gusto: ,medium sweetness, lively bitter
palato: 
full body, oily feel, average carbonation, long finish
che tripla!!a mio parere una delle migliori mai assaggiate,laroma è sicuramente una delle cose migliori della birra,intenso e dai sentori di alcool e caramello. Il gusto è molto dolce con piccole punte di amaro e sprigiona tutto il potenziale nel finale che risulta lungo e molto piacevole.

Sint Bernardus is hands down one of the finest brewers of abbey ale that a beer drinker can find today. This tripel excellent in flavor,aroma, and color. If you have the opportunity buy this it will be worth the money.
The rich complexity of the thick ale is matched by a wonderful white head.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2013 This beer is nothing short of brilliant. From the first pour until the last drop in the glass. High carbonation mixed with light caramel sweetness against a very crisp finish creates a wonderful palette. I will have this one again and again and again....

From notes.  First reviewed 10/19/2010.  Poured from a 330 ml bottle into a goblet.

St. Bernardus Tripel pours a hazy dark orange copper color with a thick creamy white head. A good level of retention, and each sip leaves generous lace clinging to the glass. A bit darker than I would expect out of the style.

Tons of fruity and spice notes in the nose. I expected the spicy yeast aroma, but the pineapple, apricot, and other tropical fruit really surprised me. Also seems to be some apple and cherry in there. 

This is about as perfect of a flavor in a tripel as I can remember having. It starts out well, with a combination of toffee and honey providing most of the sweetness. Juicy apricot and pineapple come in before the spicy yeast takes over. Wow - allspice, cloves, maybe some cinnamon and pepper as well. A light herbal and citrus hop presence perfectly match the original flavors on the tongue. There is a touch of alcohol in the flavor that is tolerable.

Both crisp and creamy, it has carbonation to lift any residue off the tongue and keep each sip feeling fresh, but it has a soft creaminess that is quite pleasant. It starts juicy, but it starts moving toward dry by the end. A touch grainy from the unfiltered nature of the beer.

One of, if not my absolute, favorite tripels. This will frequently be found in my fridge.

I found this one too sweet, and seems like theres a lot of cereal and grain as someone pointed. Smell is better than taste. Its pretty original and not bad at all, but not exactly according to my own taste.
Transfering data from personal beer file. I drank this beer a long time ago. Ill update this rating if I have the chance to drink it again.

Hazy copperish bronze under a thin white foamy head, with lots of lace. Aroma has a lot of pale cereal grain with a funky bubblegum yeastiness, and a light grassy hop tone.  smells very "abbey" brewed and classical.  Taste has a ton of yeasty dryness, complete with dusty tones of earthy bubblegum and biscuit dough. The malty tone is bready and slightly spicy, with a pale grain overtone. Wheaty too. Wasnt terribly keen on it, but it is well made.

Pours golden clear with medium persistant foam head.
Smells yeasty characters, this beer has the same profile as but less complex, less deep, less rich, less intense than ABT 12. Drinkable well balanced fruity Tripel.
Bottle from a 4 pack sampler. Pours hazy golden, smells of sweetness, and tastes sweet, spicy, citrus. Creamy full mouthfeel. Really good.

Appearance was clear golden with lasting 3 finger head with loads of lacing. Aroma was sweet malts with citrusy floral hops and estery yeasts that  was pleasant to smell. Taste  was sweet and citrusy with a herbal hops.Mouthfeel was  crisp  creamy carbonation with a balanced average length dryish finish.Ahhh tripel...

Pours hazy honey yellow with floaties and a lot of foam. The smell is yeasty, peppery and spice heavy with some sweet grain. The taste is robust and lasting. There is a dense grain rate and an array of spices that are hard to single out, some clove, coriander, lemon and orange citrus, and more with a bold Belgian yeast kick. It is not very sweet, a bit on the dry side and a tiny bit acidic. Overall a verygood tripel with a lot of depth.
Pours hazy gold into my st. B challace.  Aroma of fermented fruit and vanilla.  Taste is bold and cOmpliments the consistency well. A great triple.

St. Bernardus 8 on the label. 33cl bottle. Brown colour with a frothy and dense tan head with an average duration. Aroma is sweet, caramelish, slightly lemon, spicy. Flavour has fruity notes, moderate burnt sugar, yeasty, spicy, plumbcake. The final is moderate sweet and slightly bittery with an average duration. Well balanced. Carbonation si medium to high. Body is high. Texture is oily.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of white fruits, dust, Belgium candy, floral hops and cereal malts.  Medium gold hue with a large white foamy head that mostly diminished and left ok lace.  Flavor is very sweet and lightly bitter.  Palate is full bodied with average carbonation.  Overall a nice tripel that drinks well and hits every mark.  Nice.

330 ml bottle bought @ Bierzwerg.de. Pours hazy golden with a huge frothy white head that leaves lots and lots of trace on the glass while slowly dissipating. Smell is subtle and sweet with cookie dough, ash, yeasty esters and sweet very ripe fruits. Taste is sweet, slightly bitter, spicy and very malty with banana, plums, cilantro, black pepper, cookie dough, banana bread, lemon peal and yeasty esters. Finish is rather dry, bitter and spicy. A bit weird and unexpected but very nice, exciting and enjoyable.

Bottled. Cloudy golden color with a nice white head. Aroma is  fruity, hints of apricot peaches, orange, yeast and malt. Taste is sweet fruits and spicy, some yeast notes, finish in dry and sweet. good one..
Aroma is spicy, fruity, yeasty and slightly estery. Loads of banana on the palate, some clove notes, fruitiness and a hint of caramel. Crazy monks and their awesome beer!
Gyllene lätt beslöjad öl med vitt livligt skum. Jäst, kryddor och citrus i doften. En söt, citrusfruktig smak balanseras av en lätt bitterhet.

Pale golden pour, cloudy, good head that lingers along the edge of the glass.  Bready aroma with apricot and some underlying aroma I cant identify (but is good).  Smooth on the tongue, with an initial sweet breadiness edging toward caramel.  The flavor stays on the tongue well.  I like it.
Aroma is yeast, orange, wheat and some lemon. Taste is rather bitter, fresh, yeasty and crisp.

Malt, bread, and caramel in the aroma.  Taste is a little sweeter than other st. bernadus beers, but heavy carbonation gives it a nice crisp bite at the end.  Really good, as expected from st. bernardus.
cereal, citrus, cheese, cooked vegetables, orange, cloudy, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, heavily sour, salty, full body, thick feel, flat, long finish,

Pours cloudy with mice gold color, decent lasting head.  Citrus (orange) scent with home of clove.  Nice carbonation slight bitter taste kinda like Orange peel (very nice).  Pleasant clean slightly bitter citrus finish that lasts a bit.  Nice beer.

Bottle 0.7 L.
Hazy orange body with a large, frothy, white head, mostly lasting with a nice lacing; high density of tiny particles.
Heavy spicy (cloves) aroma with yeasty (orange) and malty notes.
Flavour is sweet (fruity) and acidic with some bitterness in the long lasting finish.
Medium body with a creamy texture; lively carbonation; alcoholic warming in the finish.
Nice beer.

Bottle.

Hazy dark golden with a large white head. Rather sweet aroma and taste, yeast, fruit, clove and some spices.  A lot of carbonation. Soft mouth feel, a pleasant and drinkable Tripel.

33 cl. bottle @ home. Pours hazy gold with a big firm with head. smell of citrus en Belgian yeast. Taste is likewise woth some sweetness. Round aftertaste with a little sourness. A tripel by the book.

Had a sample glass from my dad.

Aroma: A bit yeast, a bit fruit, nothing much.
Appearance: Pale and gold, with a very big white head. Cool.
Taste: Quite bitter, bit sweet. 
Palate: Steered by very lively carbonaton, maybe a bit to much even. Finish is ok quite bitter.

Overall: Quite boring, Its a bit warm from the alcohol but nothing is very outstanding. Good tripel but not very special.
Pours golden with large head. Malty aroma, with ome caramel. Taste of malts and grains, caramel and hazlenuts.
golden pour with a white head.  nose is dried fruits, yeast, light musk, and spices.  easy on the palate, smooth dried fruits, backed by spices and yeast.

33cl bottle. Clear orange with a bit hazy liquid. Big white head. Nose : Fruity esters : cherry, pear, raspberry. Raisins. Caramel. Dough. Spicy. Sip : Creamy body with medium carbonation. Mouthful but still drinkable. Sweet start surrounded by fruit esters. After couple of sips there is this delicately dry taste coming into surface. Nice surprise to be honest. Still the aftertaste is sweet and a little bit sour. Little peppery. Good brew as usual. Although Its from far my favorite tripple.
101107: Hazy golden color with a big creamy white head. Fruity aroma. Spicy anf fruty taste wit some sweetness.

Pours a cloudy orange colour with a tall frothy white head. Aroma is yeasty, sweet malt and hints of fruit, particularly orange and spices. Taste is also yeast, malt, lightly fruity, caramel and spices leading to a light bitter finish and slight alcohol feel. Lovely beer.

330 ml bottle, will soon be available at Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 8%. Slightly hazy pale yellow colour, huge white head. Strong and "typical tripel" aroma: notes of Belgian ale yeast, fruit, flowers, mild spices and white kandij sugar. The medium sweet flavour is spicy and moderately fruity, with decent hops in the finish. Has everything you expect from a tripel.
Bottle - small dense head, hazy dark straw/light orange color, citrusy aroma, fruity flavor with a strong shot of Belgian yeast

Bottle. Pours light copper with a thick, long-lasting head. Smells of floral, grass. Taste is light sweetness, with a yeasty trail.  No alcohol present in the taste but the warmth is there. Really solid offering.

Bottle from Beers of Europe
Orange-amber, hazy, white bubbly head that dissipates to thin layer, good lacing.
Aroma - Sweet fruits, strawberries, orange, hint of banana, yeast, bread dough, spicy, hint of cloves, faint touch of bubblegum, bit tangy. Very complex.
Taste - Very yeasty, bread, dough, spicy hops, sweet golden malts, bit of banana and cloves, well blended, alcohol ridiculously well hidden.
Palate - High carb, medium to full body, smooth and creamy,slightly powdery texture. Finish is quite dry, bready yeast, some peppery bitterness
Superb beer, very complex aroma, yeast is fantastic, amazingly drinkable at 8%.

Fresh bottling. Served in a tulip. Pours hazy dark honey with a large white meringue head. Good retention and lace. Nose is quiet cold and so is the palate, besides that theres plenty of carbonation. Im letting this warm... Thats better. The nose brightens up with mostly dough and cheese yeastiness. No spice, but maybe some fruit. If I had some good brie, Id be eating it with this one. Tillamook cheddar will have to do. Light sweet, light bitter flavor. Medium body, good carbonation, sticky texture, and a lightly hopped finish. Was hoping for better.

From notes: Pours hazy straw color, with a small, white head.  Lots of carbonation bubbles lining the glass.  Pleasant aroma of candied citrus, with a very light mustiness from the yeast and perhaps a note of black pepper.  Deep, with a slight thickness that lingers on the tongue.  Light, sweet, honey-like taste with citrus mixed in.  The mustiness from the yeast lingers in the finish.  As it warms, the sweetness fades, and it takes on an earthier taste with a mild black pepper note.

Aroma is belgian, lemon, hay. Appearance is hazy golden brown with huge white frothy meringue head. Taste is belgian malt forward, spicy tangy hops, candied sugar, clove, lemon, pepper. Palate is medium full. Belgian malt, candied sugar spice and clove linger. Overall an excellent example of a style I dont really care for.
750 ml. pours a golden orange color with a beautiful white head.  Aromas of banana, hay, and light hops.  great triple

Bottle 33 cl, Cracked Kettle. Pours clear honey amber with a huge white creamy head leaving plenty of lace. Aroma is malty, sweet, fruity, bready, hoppy and floral. Flavor is malty, bitter, pungent, sweet, caramel, fruity and has a nice touch of almonds. Good carbonation, very crisp and refreshing. Finishes sweet fruity and bitter.

Bottle (which spent a long time in the fridge, will re-rate a fresher bottle another time). A very hazy orange beer with a thick frothy white head.  Sweet fruity aroma, oranges, hops, and some spice.  Flavor is mild, sweet, with a slight bitterness on the finish.  A lot of carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2014 Very nice Tripel this one. Pours a nice hazy amber color with strong foam. Has a fruity aroma with most notably hints of dough. Delicate bitternes and a great palate. Wonderful beer!

0,33 l bottle, courtesy of Balazs, thanks!
Hazy golden one wioth a creamy medium white head. Aroma of coriander, spicies and some lemon peel, herbal hops. Medium bodied beer with a fine smooth mouthfeel, light lactic acid, malt and raisins, spicy character because of coriander and herbal hops. Nice tripel!

Bottle from Da Aldo. Poured clear, with a golden yellow color and a white head. Yeast, honey, apple, cantalope, hops in the aroma. Medium dense with high carbonation. Candy sweet, fruity taste with a dry, tarty aftertaste.  Good one!

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy yellowish-copper with large creamy off-white head.  Lots of lemon and spice on the nose, some floral, some sweetness.  Flavor is predominately sweet.  Caramel, apple, raisin, pepper.  Not too much carbonation; very simple and very good.

No idea how I havent had this before now....pours out a slightly cloudy golden color with a nice white head. Aroma is of sweet fruits, some alcohol , lingering apple and some pear. Taste is sweet fruits, spicy/fruity Belgian yeast notes, apple, light tartness and a little of the alcohol warmth creeping in there on the finish.
Hazy blond coloured beer with small white head and no carbonation visible. Rather spiced aroma with some hoppy hints. Full sparkling palate. Finish is hoppy bitter dry with some spicy hints.

Hazy dark yellow, big white head fades to nothing. Nose is banana, Belgian yeast, slightly sour fruit notes too. Palate is smooth and dry, banana, ester, slightly buttery too with a long, acetic hoppy finish. Nice.
Bottle shared with northropfrye. Subtle aroma. Taste of bananas. Beautiful golden hue.

Bottle in trappist glass. Aroma of bananas and yeast. Hazy yellow colour with white head. Taste is initially a little bitter, some banana notes like a Belgian wit and also dried fruit. I really liked this beer.

Appearance: Poured a deep yellow/orange color. Good white head. Excellent lacing. Long head (About 10 minutes).

Aroma: Citrus (possibly orange). Hoppy. Faint smell of alcohol.

Palate: Good body. Smooth. Good carbonation. Dry. 

Flavor: Bitter. Acidic ending with a long aftertaste.

Fles 33 cl. 
Kleur: Goudgeel. Licht troebel.
Brede stabiele witte schuimkraag die lang blijft bestaan. 
Geur: Fruitig en zoet. 
Smaak: Zoet met een beetje bitter en ook fruitig. 
Volle frisse smaak. ABV wordt mooi gecamoufleerd.
Afdronk blijft geruime tijd bestaan.

Cloudy deep golden orange pour thin white head .... aroma of sweet fruity yeast (apricots, pears), light floral/herbal.... taste is of fruity yeast (pears,apricots), grainy, spicy floral hops and malty with a little abv in it that flows into a malty, spicy light warming finish .... nice decent tripel

This awesome brew poured up a cloudy dark orange colored body sporting a hearty two-finger frothy white colored head with good retention and lacing. Aromas of apricots, sugars, and some spice that I just have not been able to pinpoint as of yet. The flavors in this brew are just amazing and very well-balanced, full of caramel, toffee, fruits, lemon zest, and a slight hint of alcohol. Full-bodied, very creamy and smooth, with a dry, yeast-like finish.
Bottle fae Beets. Pours a wonderful gold. Smells of yeast and spice. Tastes wonderful. Belgian yeast, fruit. Great mouthfeel brought about about by the well measured carbonation. Lovely stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 Reviewed from notes (2007).
A: Orange-gold body with a thick lasting white head
S: Various fruits, yeast and pale malt sweetness
T: A well balanced blend of fruits and malt with a hit of hops and spice. a very pleasant flavor profile that hides the 8% ABV very well
M: Light and velvety ... carbonation flows throughout
O: A joy to drink!

Nice tripel, Strong Phenol aroma of pepper clove and esters of banana and orange with white sugar candy hints.
Golden yellow color with white persistent head.
Strong phenol flavor of clove, and pepper, with estery banana and orange. Intense carbonation which makes good boddy, but could use more malt flavor. Good example of the style.

I really enjoyed this beer. Im not rating it down due to its looks. I got banana, honey, toast. So, whatever. Flavor was slightly sweet but not overly so and then balancing and finishing dry. Tongue tingly.
Good cloudy beer, let it drink with a soft flavor, Is even better on draft. If you can find it on draft. In Café Botteltje the have it for the moment.
Cloudy copper colour with a small white head. Great yeasty, fruity, spicy aroma, with caramel, brown sugar, berries. Awsome sweet creamy flavour, licorice, banana and yeast. A delicious tripel.

(750ml bottle) cloudy gold/yellow with a film of fine white bubbles. Nose of golden raisins, caramel, spicy Belgian yeast, bubblegum and quite clean. Taste of gold raisins, spicy, medium sweetness, Belgian yeast, well balanced with a delicious linger. Very dry finish. A classic tripel, and one of the best.

A: Lively golden color with fair amount of turbidity, very simular to a heffe. Lovely white head that lasts a few seconds as well.

Ar: I fucked up and used a glass that reeked of dish soap. Fuck.

T: Mouthfeel is pretty much perfect. Effervescent enough to keep it interesting throughout, but not overwhelming. Best word I can use to describe the overal taste is clean. If you take a break after a couple sips, you can feel some of the alcohol come back up in your breath. The finish is creamy. Ill have to re-review this again, the glass is definitely keeping me from getting dat full flavor.

D: dangerously drinkable. Cold or a little warmed up.

Pour straw golden yellow with sediment big white head good lace. Aroma clove, coriander, spicy yeast, bread, malt, pepper. Taste pepper, spicy, yeast, clove, honey, candy sugar, bread, malt, ripe fruit, floral. MF medium body crisp carb. Overall a tasty tripel well brewed with good taste profile.

Super hazy yellow color.  Kind of like a banana but a duller brownish color.  Huge white foamy head with this pour.  Smells like bananas!  And wheat!  And yeast!  Weee.  Taste is super smooth.  Taste is of bananas and oranges!  Some yeast as well!  Very delicious.  One of my favorite tripels!
Bottle. Poured a hazy golden with a creamy white head that settles to a ring. Aroma of fruit, light spice, and some funkiness. The flavor found fruit, and hints of spice. Medium body and sweet.
Comes on smooth, excellent follow.  Had it right after the Chimay triple though and I can see why the Chimay is a slight notch up.   A very smooth taste in this one. bottle from Oak Barrel in Canmore

Aroma: yeasty but not particularly strong. Appearance: pale golden colour with fine white head. Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour. Palate: medium body, lively, long finish. Overall: Enjoyable beer easy drinking. one of my favourite styles and this is a good example of the style

(33 cl au Bistro des Bières Belges)  Le liquide a une robe profondément orangée.  Le nez est appétissant  avec un sucré de malt approprié, des épices et des fruits jaunes.  Les saveurs aussi intéressantes avec des malts doux, une levure affirmée et des flaveurs fruitées qui vont du citron jusquà la banane acidulée.  Belle et bonne présence dun alcool touché par les fleurs.  Très agréable.  En bouche, le liquide est moyennement dense avec une effervescence modérée et une texture à la limite huileuse.  La finale est me plaît beaucoup : une explosion des saveurs avec un alcool chaleureux.
Pours a hazy amber colour with a large lacy head.  Sour, yeasty aroma.  Slightly sour and spicy flavour.

Pours hazy pale amber with massive foamy white head. Nose is sweet cereal malt, lemon citrous, creaminess and deeper musky fruity odours. Possibly a bit of orange and mango. Mouthful is quite light in body and yet oily and a flavour that starts mild but quickly deepens. Yeasty malt, bitter hops, sour citrous. Bit of toffee/caramel which tends to come through and dominate after a few sips. If I was going to criticise it, needs a bit more citrous hop and fruit kick.

Bottle at Beneluxx Tasting Room in Philly.  Was surprised that I did not rate this one previously, but enjoyed it very much.  Did not take good notes at the time I drank it (about a week ago) so will be on the lookout to try this one again.

Pours very clear golden amber with a foamy white head.  
Fresh sweet hay aroma with some sour notes. 
Sweet and slightly sour.
Mouthpuckering, fizzy, alcoholic finish.
Bottle, pours a bright golden colour, smell yeasty taste was bitter, overall it smelt like a triple and tasted like a triple, wasnt anything too too special

Aroma: Similar to Chimay white and Westmalle Tripel. Flower garden, orangey/citrusy, light toffee, slight booze, smells fresh.
Appearance: Slightly cloudy burnt gold color with a decent two finger white head. 
Taste: Toffee, fruit basket, spices, a little lemony sourness, hops presence noted. Agreeable bitter finish. Slightly less complex in comparison to the Trappist offerings, but its definitely good.
Palate: Slightly oily, carbonation is perfect, well balanced. 8%? Wheres the alcohol?
Overall: Cant believe Im saying this given I was appalled by their 12, but this is comparable to Westmalles or Chimays offerings. Its really good and they nailed it. Its $0.70 cheaper than Westmalle, so I gotta drink that again to see if its worth the extra 70 cents!
great example of what a tripel should be. caramel, soft fruits, some raisin and spices. slight bitterness in the finish completed it nicely
Pours cloudy amber with a white head. Aroma is caramel, tropical fruit, light spice and light alcohol. Flavour is sweet caramel, fruit, light pepper and alcohol.

33 cl bottle. Unclear golden colour with a nice creamy white head. Aroma of yeast, bread, caramel, little sour, fruity and spices. Nice flavour of yeast, fruit, toffee and someway complex. Ends up very dry and nice.

Hazy orange-gold and a fluffy white head that clings to the side of the glass. Aromas of lemon juice, soft biscuits and that unmistakeable tripel yeast aroma. Slightly sour on the nose, but easy to deal wth.
Fluffy and creamy mouthfeel which gives way to big Meyer lemons on a tree out the back. The malt is very very soft and there is a sour tinge on the sides of the tongue but a small sweet note develops as well. Well balanced. This is a beer for contemplation.

From a 750 ml corked and caged bottle. This poured a golden color and raised a big white creamy head with good lacing. Beautiful pour. The nose is ripe fruit with coriander, citrus, and floral hops.  Medium body and a silky smooth mouthfeel.   The favor is kind of mixture of apples and pears, with some very subtle spices.  The finish is dry and ever so slightly bitter. The overall experience is one of subtlety, with nothing overstated, but simply delightful and very refreshing and easy to drink.

bottle, pours hazy dark golden with large white head.... citrus, peach,flower notes, fresh flavor citrus, sweet, belgian yeast, flowers..... nice .... light bitterness : alcohol.......classic belgian ....
Frothy head from the bottle.  Sweet smell.  Very balanced in taste.  Great hoppy bitterness at the end.  This Tripel is very well done.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2014 Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a hazy light orange (plenty of yeast floating) with tight off-white 1" head.  Highly carbonated, lots of lacing, and medium body.  Taste is acidic citrus, some candied sugar and honey, some clove, and a hint of bitterness in the finish.  Complex and good.

Its said that the St. bernardus beers resemble the Westvleteren beers. I think they do as well. A blind tasting would provide a true outcome, but should I guess I think I like this better. Very nice balanced tripel this one.

Bottle. Dark gold with a very slight haze. Slightly sugary malts on the nose with light spice, pear and peach. Soft body. The alcohol makes a statement early, but the brew turns sweet, almost cloying, before spice and peachy fruit finish

Bottle. Pours clear gold with a thin white head. Strong Belgian yeast aroma with some peach, citrus, and floral notes. Light malty sweetness, yeast and fruit flavors, very light bitterness on the finish. A faint alcoholic warmth. This beer is pretty much exactly what I look for in a Tripel.
Pretty nice tripel. Mouthfeel was very nice. Nice body and great co2. Taste and smell were a bit dull.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2015 Bottle 330ml. Color hazy orange with big head. Aroma honey, floral, bread. Taste honey, bread, floral, spicy, dry.

33cl bottle shared with Kermis at the Paas.
Clear golden pour.  Fine white head.  Quite a decent triple
Bottle at De Paas.  Hazy golden pour with white head.  Aroma has wheat and banana with yeast.  Flavor has same aspects with some fudge and citrus.

Huge offwhite head threatens to overflow the glass. Slightly hazy orangey body with wild carbonation. Milky spicy honey aroma with cinnamon and herbal notes. Dry-sweet milky honey and herbs taste with buttery spicy notes. Mid-bodied. Mild mouthfeel. Dry herbal spicy honey aftertaste with grassy soft metal notes. Lovely! Extremely drinkable, yet subtle and full of flavour and character. (0.33l bottle, Bier Tempel, Brussels.)

Bottle; The color in this snifter is murky light gold with a fine bubble white head that frankly doesnt retain that well in this glass, at least. Light spotty lacing here, though. Sweet florals, honeydew, bready malts, and grassy hops on the nose. Its quite nice, really. The flavor profile does strike a nice balance, to be sure, but it does feel a bit sweet overall, really. There is a very light spice note present; the sweet breads are quite nice, actually. The grassy, floral hops back it up but I would actually prefer a bit more of that, actually. Anyway ,  a nice tripel here.

Mild süßer Geruch mit alkoholischem Hintergrund. Im Antrunk Erscheint das Bier minimal alkoholisch, dieser Ton verschwindet aber recht bald hinter einem frischen würzig-säuerlichem Ton, dazu leicht herb, eigentlich mild bleibend. Das Bier bliebt so spritzig, auch wenn der Alkohol zum Abgang hin etwas stärker wird, denn deiser wird weiterhin durch einen süß-würzigen Getreideton verdeckt. Im nachgeschmack kommt eine deutlich malzige Note auf. Hat schon was, das Tripel! 	 
Test vom 7.10.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 8,9,10,12,11,11 - 10,40

The beer pours a cloudy dark yellow color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the oranges and lemons with some Belgian yeast notes. I also get a little bit of bready malt. The flavor is a mix of Belgian candy sugar with some orange and bready malt notes. There is also a little bit of alcohol present. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Si presenta molto bene, con un bel colore pieno e un ottima schiuma, anche al naso non è niente male. In bocca è proprio classica tripel...

Gotta give it to the Europeans;  theyre on to something with mixing sainthood with beer.  I spent enough time in Southern Baptist churches growing up to envy any organized group of people who incorporate beer into their religious beliefs.  St. Bernies Tripel is good Belgian beer, nothing spectacular or snazzy, but solid nonetheless.  Tastes of wheat and hay,  yet remains dry and yeasty enough to find off sugar overload. The grassy spiciness of the traditional Tripel is on display, but restrained, leaving the beer balanced and drinkable, despite its potency.  (11/08)

Serving: 750 ml bottle from State Line Liquors. It pours a hazy gold with a medium frothy white head. The nose is yeasty with notes honey, light florals. The flavor is lightly sweet with a bit of back bitterness. Nice honeysuckle notes, a bit of bubble gum, and hay. Light to medium body with lots of carbonation leading to a medium finish. A quality brew for sure.

Bottle.  Pours a dark golden color with a huge frothy head.  The aroma was a very nice complexity of ripened fruit, spice and yeasty notes.  Tastes of mild sweet and sour fruit and some clove with the banana yeasty notes.  Very nice beer.  Just glad this Belguim is pretty widely available.
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is malty, fruity yeasty and light spicy. Flavor is quite sweet. Dry and spicy finish with warming alcohol. 210511

Sampled at Hopapalooza II. Pours a clear dark yellow with a thick, white head that lingers. Aroma is citrus, malt, yeast, and faint notes of alcohol. Flavour is also somewhat citrusy, with predominate notes of orange and faint hints of lemon. Medium-bodied with a smooth, somewhat lingering finish. Lovely.

Bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a little white head. Nice lacing as well. Aroma is a slight tart with lots of citrus notes from the yeast. Taste is very sweet with a very nicely tucked away tartness that gives awesome depth to the beer. Finishes slightly clean, with a little lingering coating of the tongue.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a soft amber with a big, fluffy white head. Lots of fruit, sugar and belgian yeast present on the nose. Sweetness throughout. Light citrus and fruity esters in the taste, with your typical belgian yeast, bananas and a touch of grass. Good beer

07.07.2011. 0,33l Bottle. From Biere Cultes Paris. Golden brown colour with white head. Hazy unclear. Lively carbonated with fruity aroma. Sweet malty flavours with moderate bitterness. Sweet fruity aftertaste.
Servida en The Drunk Monk (Mataró). Siempre he sido un gran amante de las tripel y esta es excelente.

750ml bottle.
Hazy golden brew with a frothy white head.  Looks just like a Tripel should.  Lots of fruity and Belgian yeast aromas - flavor is spicy with some banana.  Very drinkable and smooth - all around a great Tripel.

Bottled, aged about 3 years. Huge, frothy head. Clear amber colour, murky when all the sediment. Grassy hops and very complex yeast aromas. Loads of dry berries and fruits, a bit like dry sherry. Some fresh strawberries and perry too. Dry and clean pils malts, slight sweetness in the middle clearly comes from sugars and fruity yeast. Dry finish with mature, almost woody fruitiness and herbal hop flavor. Velvety texture, some alcoholic warmth. Insanely drinkable for such a strong and complex beer. This is what Belgians do best!

Great pour!  Monster light colored head with small bubbles... Glowing orange in color. Fruity, slight hops, yeasty nose... Great taste as well... Light orange peel, fruity, light lemon, grass, banana, yeast notes... Refreshing, well balanced. Texture is light and fluffy way to easy to drink. Overall: Great tripel, great beer!

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2011 In bottle; poured golden brown with a nice apple aroma. Taste was mild bodied with apple and honey notes ... very easy drinking and much better than I expected. Highly recommend,

1pt. 9.4 oz. bottle served in flute- poured a slightly turbid light yellow with heavy shades of copper color, very lively medium carbonation, 2 finger white frothy head hogged up the top half of the flute, leaving behind trails of lace.  Aroma of wheat, grass, earth, yeast, with notes of anise and some very light freshly cut young wood.  Hits the mouth with a light medium body, malt is very light- almost a saison feel, some pepper and banana in the middle, finish has a dulled lumpy grape and yeasty twang to it.  Okey dokey, next!

Poured from 750ml into tulip at Euclid Hall

 A: Light bright orange with massive off white billowy head- very cloud like. Great lacing!

S: orange, citrus, yeasty, soft malt, banana bread, grainy, and just a touch boozy but nothing too crazy.

T: Sweet malts, honey, white grape, banana, tropical fruits, little bitterness on end but malts balance.

M: Light carbonation, soft for a Triple, sudsy, and crisp. Alcohol is completely masked.

D: Very complex Tripel and one of the worlds best. The drink ability on this beer is scary.
small head, red amber pour. mild aroma, fruit bread. rich well balanced with a note of brown sugar. not very hoppy. long caramel finish. very  good beer very refreshing for an amber.

bottle, bought in Watou, not very good aroma, citrus fruits ect. but little bit after date. golden, hazy, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, good balancedfull body, slick feel, average carbonation, long finish, I ve expected more from this beer
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours cloudy orange with a good frothy head and some lacing. Aroma is yeast (some notes of the Sint-Bernardus abt 12 are noticeable), lots of fruity notes and spices. Medium bodied, smooth mouthfeel. I would have liked a bit more bitterness, but all in all a very decent tripel by Sint-Bernardus.

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep golden with a thick, lacy, lingering, off-white head.  Aroma of Belgian spicy yeast, caramel malts, light floral hops, and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor very complex for a tripel, and the spice really dominates this one.  Texture is smooth, but could be better.  A really good tripel.

Poured a golden color.  Frothy head.  Fresh fruity aroma on the nose with mild candy and figs.  Taste was a medium sweetness with presense of alchohol and belgium yeast.  Palate is med bodied, slick texture, average carbonation and long finish.  Just a bit of bitterness at end.  This is a very good drinkin belgium trippel, and complex and spiced. Smooth all-around.  Yum.

Bottle. A light spicy aroma, a little bit fruity, some coriander. The white foamy head is rather small with a long duration. The body is dark orange to brown. A nice fruity taste with a light after taste of yeast. The body is light to medium strong, creamy and dry with a soft carbonation.
Poured cloudy pale yellow. Fruity spiced aroma. Flavor with lots of spice and trippel fruitiness. Nice trippel.

This beer pours a great looking pale gold with a finger high head that lasts several minutes. This is also incredible lacing. 

The aroma is very subtle but mostly floral with a touch of hops.

The tatse is wonderful, very smooth from start to finish. Great notes of hops and spice. Very drinkable from start to finish.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Gebod: I found the hops & spices to be too overpowering down to the point that they drowned almost all of the tastes, resulted in a really long lingering bitter aftertaste, there was also some citrus & pineapple, not much sweetness, maybe might work out better in a bottle or aged

750ml from IPB.
Appearance : Slight gusher. Clear blong with a medium white head. Foamy and creamy.

Aroma : Quite spicy and quite yeasty. Very fresh. 

Taste : Spicy and yeasty. Light hops. Dry finish with hops yeast and spices. Lively carbonation. Nice balance between yeast and spices. Finish is a bit mineral too.

Overall : Nice stuff. A bit too spicy for my taste but Im rather sensible to that. Nice crispness. Light citrusy hint on finish. Rather drinkable and fresh.
Hazey gold-orange with light white head.  Light matly floral aroma.  FLavor is maltier, less sweet and spiced than expected, but still very nice and a different take on the tripel.

Pours a murky, dirty gold with a fairly modest white head. Nose is candied sugar, yeast, and coriander, as to be expected from a tripel. Flavor is warm and bready and quite full-bodied, shifting from sugar to banana bread from front to back. Coriander/spice and hops are perfectly balanced against the malt body. Carbonation is less lively than in most tripels. A very rich and simple example of the abbey tripel style, and nothing short of superb.

11.2 oz bottle best before 11.05.12.

Pours into my tulip a golden color, initially crystal clear until the yeast enters. The head is extremely active and recedes extremely quickly leaving behind spotted lacing.

Like all St. Bernardus beers this one has a lot of scent. It is incredibly fruity with the yeast up front and it is also very sweet smelling.

The taste is heavy too, it super fruity and slightly spicy, the yeast shines, it is sweet but not overly so.

St. Bernardus always impresses, I dont have that much to say about it besides it is fantastic.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-15-2010 23:55:32
Im not feeling this one. Poured from a bottle with a big head. Very dry taste with some malt flavor and little hop action. Some floral notes on the palate but doesnt do it for me.

Aroma of apple, citrus fruits and some yeast. This beer has a nice hoppy bitterness and relatively little sweetness compared to other tripels. Carbonation is rather high and somewhat unpleasant. Very decent tripel.

gold pour with a massive white foamy head.
aroma is light grassy, slightly grainy, fruity.
flavour is nice fruity, biscuity maltiness. semi sweet with a light grassy bitter finish. very nice.
Goldern amber colour, thick head.  Light aroma of hops and fruit. Great balance of malt and hops, light bitterness thats satisfying. Very good

Poors the color of applesauce with a nice two finger head.  Good retention.  Nose is fruity and flowery.  Taste was citrus and fairly tart.  I was hopping it would be more malty.  Good on the palate however.

330ml Bottle from Bierzwerg.  Pours a nice opaque golden orange color with one finger of dense off-white head.  Aroma is citrus, rose water/floral, and spice.  Taste is also citrusy, sweet, with a hint of cinnamon.  There is also a very mild bitterness towards the end that merges into a lightly bitter finishing.  Mouthfeel is soft and smooth.  Very nice Tripel.
Nice triple. Could use a little more malt. Not quite Karmilite but good. All the St Bernardus are good.

330 ml bottle, BB date reads 09-25-2012, into tulip. Clear, effervescent golden body is overlain by airy white head that doesnt last and completely dissipates. Id expect the head to be firmer and creating more lace as subsides. Aroma exhibits light, somewhat bready, toasty malt character with a nice interplay of fruity esters, phenols, sweetness and alcohol. The significant fruity esters are represented by orange, pineapple, mango and peach, followed by moderate spicy and clove-like phenols, evident candy sugar sweetness and restrained soft spicy alcohol. As far as the aroma section is considered, the balance between esters and phenols is leaned towards the former while in the flavor dept the later prevail. Soft malty body embraces dominant peppery phenols and spicy alcohol flavor, subdued citrusy esters of orange, and moderately high bitterness that seems to result especially from the yeast-derived phenols as well as from hoppy bitterness. The relatively high bitterness combines with moderate carbonation to lend a dry finish with spicy aftertaste. The body is medium-light and somewhat creamy from the slightly warming alcohol.

Appearance:  cloudy medium gold, two-finger light brown head.  Aroma:  champagne, honey, cinnamon, white pepper, light citrus.  Taste:  as the aroma indicates--sweet and a little spicy.  Finish:  sweetness gives way to a nice champagne-like dryness.  Notes:  One of the sweeter tripels Ive had.  Palate was very well-carbonated.  Very enjoyable, and a superlative example of the style.
Has an effervescence to it mixed with fruit and and balanced hoppiness.  A really good tripel.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2015 Drank this and the regular Watou Tripel side by side. They look the same. This is peachy and lemony while the other is spicy and a bit salty.. Cant say one is better than the other.
Amber bodied, banana yeast full bodied triple.  Seems to me all St. Bernardus beers are excellent examples of styles they produce.

Bottle. Much darker than a typical Tripel and a pretty small head (by style.) yeasty nose, only a hint of wheat, and plenty of barnyard. Flavors also more "Belgian" than the typical wheat flavors in many Tripels. Very nice brew.
Good body, wonderful aroma, nice complexity. Good go to beer. Another gateway beer.

Just a great Tripel plain and simple. I got the initial burst of grapes on the first whiff. A little sour but not really? Blurry body with extra carbonation and an unforeseen finish. Not much of a head. I enjoyed holding the beer in between my tongue and roof of my mouth. It had a champagne like effect.
Draft @ mission dolores in brooklyn. Tasytes of banana and orange. Smells of grapes and powdered sugars. This is just a really good eample of this type of beer (tripel). Very good

330ml bottle from Bierzwerg

Simply a great tripel. Rich, fruity, complex taste with a full body. Aroma has hints of banana.

12oz bottle given to me as a Christmas present. I cant believe Ive never had this before.  The pour is a matte melon gold/orange with a nice thick creamy head of white.  Aroma is mild. The first thing that hits my nose is creamy citrus and some alcohol vapors.  There is also some lingering spice notes.  The citrus acidity is the first thing that hits my tongue, then the creamy body and a touch of sourness before the trailing spices are the only thing left.  A very smooth and well balanced tripel; far better than my experience more recently with abrasive American tripels.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a goblet.

3.5 A: Murky dark orange/brown color. One finger of creamy white head. Below average retention and moderate lacing. Yeast floaties throughout.

4.0 S: Banana and mango esters. Pepper and clove yeastiness.

4.0 T: Lots of fruity esters. Banana sticks out but there is also another level of fruitiness like a fruit cocktail where individual flavors are hard to pick out. Lots of pepper, clove to a lesser extent and lots of yeastiness.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good bubbly carbonation. Creamy.

4.5 D: Very drinkable, but for the price Id take other stuff.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-14-2009 20:47:18

Bottle. Golden, hazy, average and mostly lasting head. Moderate malty and caramel sweet aroma, surprisingly lot of grassy hoppyness, light alcohol. Body is moderate, malty and caramel sweet flavor, faint hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and caramel sweetish, light alcohol. Nice hoppy aroma, otherwise one- dimensional caramel sweet tripel.
Aroma: grape, sweet, malt, hops, honey melon, a bit diacetyl. Nice head. Extraordinary taste. Creamy and full bodied palate. A delicious beer!

Bottle vintage 2005. Pours hazy golden with a smallish white head that lasts. Carbonation has really smoothed out with age. Aroma is malty sweet, honey, bead and yeast. Flavor is malty sweet, bread/biscuit, honey, slight sour green apple. Finish is like liquid honey wheat bread and the alcohol is almost none existent. This aged tripel has an incredibly huge, round depth of flavor, a completely different experience from a fresh bottle. Its just incredible.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2011 Pours a beautiful cloudy yellow. Yeasty, standard tripel aroma. Beer is extremely carbonated, probably the most carbonated beer Ive tried. Tastes yeasty, belgian spice and fruit note. Quite a good tripel, pretty much a classic example.

(bottle)  Pours a hazy golden color with very creamy and persistent head.  Well commercially described.  Good depth in flavor.  Sour apple, mild malt with subtle alcohol undertone.  A very solid tripel, but shy of superior status.

Cloudy, golden-orange with a puffy off-white head that sits there all day. Aroma of ripe fruits, crisp hops, Belgian yeast, sugar. It completely smells clean and refreshing. Bold taste, fully malty with fruit and caramel, some hops in the back. A little earthy and buttery. Body is full and thick, with a lively carbonation and nice dry finish. Excellent tripel, definitely one of the best.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a nice white head.  This has a good amount of apple in the nose, some fresh bread, booze is definitely noticeable, banana, and spice.  Wonderful flavors.  Apple and banana are there as are the bread and a slight bit of booze.  Belgian spices and sweet malts make this a terrific tripel.  The finish is dry and long.

Pours a hazy light brown. Soapy head, two fingers high, dissipates rather quickly, but leaves some fine Belgian Lace. Aroma is very intriguing, apples and belgian yeast with a definite licorice  anise undertone. Also a slight whiff of alcohol from the 8% ABV. Taste is malty sweet, with more of the anise coming through, and a little bit of fresh baked biscuit. Just enough bitterness on the finish to carry the alcohol. Very complex, a super brew.

Poured into a St. Bernardus trappist glass. Appearance: Pours a deep golden to light amber with a one finger creamy white head that settles into a thin film and leaves some lacing. Aroma: tropical fruits fill the nose, unfamiliar to me in a beer until now. Some light malts, bready yeast, and flowery hops accompany the fruits in the background. Taste: the tropical fruits burst in the taste. The sweet and sour reminiscent of pineapples, mangoes, and coconuts combined hits at first followed by some cereal and yeast notes and finishing pleasantly dry. The abv is basically undetectable. Overall: this is a fantastic tripel. Different than others ive had in the best way. Not cloyingly sweet like many are. Perfectly balanced between sweet, sour, and dry. Delicious.

330cl bottle pours a hazy golden to orange beer. Aroma is somewhat sweet with hits of sugars and malts with a slight alcohol finish. A frothy white head that laces the glass gives this beer a great appearance. Taste is slight citrus fruit with some alcohol notes give this beer great depth. An amazing beer.

Bottle as a birthday present from Scarlett, split with Linh. Pours a bright hazy amber orange body with frothy, soapy white head. Aroma is strong belgian spice and candy and some slight alcohol burn. Mouthfeel and taste is same. Solid tripel.
Pour a golden yellow with a white head. Aromas of floral hops and hay.  Lively carbonation. Crisp and clean.
Deep rich tripel smell simple flavor, but still very good and not at all overly sweet but still not too dry good balance of attenuation overall great beer
UPDATED: FEB 26, 2012 Amazing balance, perfect amount of malt. This beer starts and ends beautifully.

From a sampler fourpack.  Bright green label with a drawing of gay, apple-cheeked St. B and his glass of ale.  A drab, swampy-colored pour, but with a surprisingly big, foamy head.  Aroma is mostly yeast (unfortunately).  The flavor too is pretty yeasty for the style, but it is still a tasty brew.  There is some wheat, some biscuit-like sweetness, and sprightly hops in the finish.  It gets sweeter and maltier as it warms in the glass.  I was surprised to see the ABV was 8% - I thought it was less.  A good, but not great, tripel.
Straw yellow pour from bottle with a medium head.  Aroma is lemon zest.  Taste is lemony, with notes of hard candy, salt and citrus.  Lightly bitter finish.

Wonderful dark murky gold color. Fabulous head retention. Kind of a phenol fruit thing going on in the nose. A creamy lush orchard smell with candied sugar. Taste is similar. Caramely fruit and medium bodied. Awesome triple. Right up there with the Westmalle and Chimay in my opinion, though certainly sweeter than both.

Golden and slightly cloudy body. The tap gave a small head. Yeast, sugar, spices and apple. Rich, sweet flavour. Balancing sourness is here. Long after taste. If anything, it is too well balanced. Great triple. (On tap in Poperinge.)

Bottle.  Pours a clear light orange with a small white head.  Aroma of light fruits (apple, cranberry) and bready malts.  Flavor is sweet upfront with sweet malts, bready malts, and fruits.  Overall, a tasty triple although it is less spicy and more heavy-bodied than most triples (really it is a BSA).  Very enjoyable though.
7/4/8/4/15 [3.8/5]

Pours very cloudy, light orange colour with a huge white frothy head. Aroma is multy-dimensional with plenty of yeast: earthy and soft flowery notes come first as obvious associations. Fruity hints and a little of a grainy backbone but not in a sweet lager way. It might be just me but I found a trace of lemon which might show a tiny bit of hops. 
Flavor is much softer than expected... unfortunately. It is pretty much sweet with an lightly alcoholic vibe and some lemony touches. Nothing to die for. It is a lot more restrained than other tripels like, say, Westmalle, Chimay or La Trappe with which are compared often.
 Medium body with a sticky texture showing a little heaviness in the mouth but also a reasonable complexity. Low carbonation and long finish with a good concealing of alcohol. 
A good beer but I expected much better.
Bottle. Plenty of yeast character, provides a high level of carbonation. Little too much residual sugar for me.

Bottle poured into tulip glass. Cloudy brownish gold with a big dense creamy head. Aroma of apples, spices and yeast. apples come through in the sweetness of the taste, a little spice in the flavor. For the palate, St. Bernardus feels a little heavier and less carbonated than some tripels I have had. On that note this is one of the better tripels I have had.
Bottle pours a yellow brew with a white head. Citrus fruit scent with spices. Taste is sweet fruit, lemon and banana. Twangy

Pours a bit dark with the style with a billowing white head and a bit of lacing. Nice Belgian spice with some fruity aromas. Taste is similar with the addition of some clove. Medium body with good spicing. Drinkability isnt quite as good as many of the stalwarts of the style. Despite a nice taste, it doesnt leave me clamoring for more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-10-2010
Nice pale yellow colour. Aromas of yeast, hops and fruits. Powerful and well-balanced tripel. A great instant of beer.

A light cloudy lemony yellow, with a great thick but light head. The aroma is fruity and yeasty. Flavor a rich but extremely drinkable, with a nice sour start and a mild hoppy finish. Overall excellent, very enjoyable to drink.
Thick, white head. Dark gold in appearance. Yeasty overtones dominate the aroma. Light taste, masks the alcohol well. Very smooth.
A cloudy  amber color with a white frothy head. Good Lacing. Apples, passion fruit, and yeast on the nose. Very Yeasty with lemon notes. Finishes with some light Hops.

bottle.  Pours peach orange gradient with big white head.  Fruity aroma includes peach, apricot, white grape, banana, and there is also a yeasty aspect, smelling like white bread, even some soft wheat tones, and light spices, clove.  Flavor of pear and clove, rich white cake, which lead to a crisp bite from modest spices, and then progresses to a long fruity spiced finish.  Very smooth and creamy but with a good carbonated spiced bite to it.  I love st. bernardus, and this one does not disappoint.

Bottle looks very good, the beer in the glass very zippy, huge head. Starts strong, but notes not too intense. Quite spicy, fruity like apple, some yeasty notes. Finish well balanced, warming, modest sourish. Really good one!

Pours brilliant yellow with a thin creamy white head that fades to streaks on the surface.  Aroma is of baking bread and tart apples with a significant sweetness in there too.  Flavor has a bit less of the sweetness than was apparent in the aroma, but the apples are still there.  I was surprised to see that the finish of this beer is described as sour- perhaps I got it mixed in the the tart apple flavors though.  Very very good, one of the better tripels without a doubt.

Poured into a snifter, came out a nice light brown/yellow. Could taste notes of banana and spice. The fruitiness remained prominent with a subtle and pleasant tinge of sourness at the finish. The flavor is a bit subdued, and I admittedly am more of a dubbel person, but I have never had a beer in this style that beats this one.

Poured into a tulip glass. Appearance is a hazy gold color with a white head. Aroma is of banana, clove, and a small amount of citrus. Taste follows suit with bananas being the dominant taste. Somewhat heavy as far as the palate goes. Fantastic beer from a fantastic brewery.

Drank from an 11.2oz bottle.Appearance: Beautiful apricot color with, what the!? Theres tons and tons of floating yeast sediment in here! It looks like a nasty fishtank that hasnt been cleaned in months! Actually, the color is really cool and the head is big and frothy, but those yeast particles are a turn-off (and they were from the top of the bottle).Aroma: Smells pretty much the same as the other St. Bernies beers. Some light fruit, noticeable alcohol presence. Fairly mild overall.Taste: Much more robust than the Watou Tripel, but still weaker than some of the Trappist tripels. A melange of light fruit like apricot, peach, maybe even honeydew. Theres a fairly rich caramel and butterscotch sweetness too. Little bitterness. Flavor doesnt peter out at the end like the other beers from this brouwerij.Mouthfeel: Noticeably thick, but soft and gentle. Doesnt tear up my palate. A slightly creamy texture from the head tingles the tongue.Drinkability: Mild taste and soft mouthfeel make for a very smooth beer. I did find myself burping every once in a while, but the least of all the St. Bernardus beers.Overall: St. Bernarduss second-best beer, but definitely not the best Tripel in Belgium.

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J6pupTYz5ls

Hazy, orange/caramel coloured beer with medium amount of head. Soft, fruity aroma. Dried fruits. Apricot. Yeast that to me has a cheese-like aroma. Very fruity and pleasant to drink. The mouthfeel is like drinking a fruity juice. I will gobble up this pretty fast.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Bottle @ home. Cloudy, yellow orange appearance with a fluffy white head. Slightly spicy, yeasty, bready, sweet, light barnyard, belgian golden ale nose with some fruity notes. Tangy, moderately spicy, somewhat floral, slightly peppery, belgian yeasty, bready, pale malty flavor. Slightly spicy aftertaste.

Bottle 33cl. A cloudy yellow-amber beer with medium head. Smell is yeast like with small wheat smell. Aroma is malty and wheat like, good fruit presence, agrume, apricot, cassis. Good creamy triple beer, with metallic notes, finish has spicy hops hints. Nice triple with fruity and grain presence.

Bottle. Pours a medium white fluffy head, poor retention zero lacing. Cloudy golden body. Heavy on the wheat, yeasty. Then coming through is orange peel, lemon zest, followed by gorgeous pine aromatics and Im really getting into this now. Some hop character coming through, alcohol, freshly-mown grass on a summers day, cane sugar, peppery. Moderate bitterness, decent sweetness helping to balance the beer. Warming. Good carbonation. Dry finish. Seems to compliment whatever food it us served with.
30th December 2005  Early amateur rating warning! An okay tripel but cant hold a light to a Tripel Karmeliet.

33cl bottle from bierkompass.de. Poured hazy orange color with a fluffy white head. Yeast and spicy slightly sweet aroma. Nice! Flavor similar, spices, banana and yeast comes to mind. Slightly dry towards finish with some alcohol warmth. Very drinkable, very tasty indeed.

A-pours the standard golden amber color with a thin light white head.

S-notes of belgian yeast come in up front as some lightly tart lemon and notes of sweet apricot come in next.  spicy phenols and notes of alcohol are present with a light herbal hop presence.

T-the taste is rather good, subtle yeast blends with tart lemon, some sweet golden fruit in there as well.  hints of alcohol and phenol add a fair bit of spice to it as a night herbal hop presence with light bitterness rounds it off.

M-medium body has an agressive carbonation making it rather prickly throughout.  a slightly dry finish is clean and somewhat crisp.

D-this is full of flavor that is well integrated and balanced.  tasty tripel that has everything you want to see.  a more dry finish and stronger malt presence to balance may help, but still very solid!

Pours with a gigantic and solid head, body is off-yellow gold with a modest amount of carbonation. Its hard to think it could get better than that! Aroma is a soft mix of hops and malts, some alcohol on the back end but its almost incidental. Taste is a smooth syrupy mix of hops and alcohol, thick on the tongue, very heavy. Very strong flavour, not bad, but whats missing is a level of complexity Id prefer from a brew like this.

330ml bottle from carguy. pours hazed golden with some chunks of yeast. retains a snow white head. great flowery hop nose with pils malt and booze underneath. the flavour is pils malt upfront with the same floral hop effect working in the background. nicely carbed with a blanced finish. really solid tripel.
Yet another good Abbey Tripel of the evening. Pours a hazy gold with little head and light lacing. Aroma is a bit flowery, taste follows. A little bright from a Tripel in my book.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2011 Yellow beer with medium and blond head. Aroma is delicious, and it is different than I excepted from blond beer, lot of fruits, even dark fruits, cooked bananas, honey, fruitesters and yeast. Flavour is fruitfull, bananas, yeast, honey sweetness, but spicy and quite dry in the end. Quite a lot of carbonation, but body is strong enough and thus, this beer is nice to drink. Good, balanced, very fruitfull, straightforward and quite sweet triple; very enjoyable.

Bottle, purchased at the brewery. Pours a hazy light yellow-orange body with a large, creamy white head. Nose is honey floral tones with coriander, yeast and hints of clove. Taste is an extremely tight blend of sweet, honey-like floral yeasty notes; a solid, yet airy mix of everything a real tripel should have. As usual, St. Bernand Brouwerij delivers top-of-the-line traditional beers, and with material this good you dont really need much originality.
Hazy amber colour with minimal to no head. Hopped aroma, wheaty touches. Bitterness of the hops comes through - very nice.
Pours a deep golden yellow/orange. Nose is pepper, banana, orange peel. Taste is very fruity, passion fruit, orange, banana, lemon zest, clean and dry malt profile. really good.

Tap. Large dense white foamy head over a clear golden body. Excellent lacing. Aroma-taste of banana, cloves,coriander seed, pepper with a subdued sweetness. Medium to light bodied, light carbonation. Nice.

330 ml bottle @ home.
Pours a slightly hazy golden colour with a foamy medium-sized head. The aroma is slightly bitter with floral hops. Notes of citrus, sweet fruits and Belgian yeast of course. Rich flavour of sweet fruits, honey and mild hops. Very nice balance. Medium bodied with oily texture and medium carbonation. Dry and warming finish. Almost as good as their Abt 12.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 Very good tripel. Lots of bubbles. Rather drinkable, bit of tartness. Serving: Bottle

Served in a Unibroue snifter

A: Golden with a white frothy head leaving traces in the wall as it retreats. Almost no visible carbonation.

S: Citrusy, hoppy, sweet, bread.

T: Same citrus and bitterness I got from the smell that leaves a coat in the mouth, a tad watery for my taste.

Overall a very good beer from people that have been doing this for a long time.

Bottle. Fantastic brew, great triple.  Orange-Gold brilliance.. good head that last long with great lacing to the bottom of the glass. Orange, spice, citrus and yeast in the nose.. Moderate sugar.. very rich and complex with the right balance of hops and fruit. Very enjoyable

Bottle 75 cl. 3 years old.
Everything aboute this beer is good. I would recomend this as a typical example of a good tripple. A bottle with 8% and soo smooth and tasty.

Murky deep yellow/light brown.  Huge foamy  head.  Initial smell doesnt promise much - hidden beneath the foam?  But it comes alive in your mouth.  Underneath everything is some potent alcohol that gives everything a wonderful liveliness.  Funky yeastiness plays tricks with this one.  Opens with a dry (and alcoholic) maltiness.  Moves to a sour/floral thing that really is the best part of this one.  Forever finish - bitter/astringent.
Sampled in the big bottle. Pours nice golden brown with huge white head. Drinks really smooth. Not much of hops but full on quality crisp light malts. Great brew!
Colour is nice golden, a little unclear, with a fine white top. Aroma is malt, lcohol and fruit. Taste is a little bitter, malt alcohol and fruit. Good palate and CO2.

Amazing beer overall. Hints of coriander, all spice, cinnamon. Great rich yeasty taste. Full bodied. One of the best Abbey Tripels I have ever had. 
http://patricksbeer.blogspot.com/2010/08/st-bern

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2010 Awesome tripel.. taste and aroma are both brilliant, theres lots of fruit and malt and more vague things in it... its very lively, sparkling in the mouth yet it has that after midnight thing going for it aswell... definitly one of the best tripels i ever drank

Pours out orange coloured with a big head. Holding is ok. Good spiced smell, lightly yeast and some citrus smell. Mostly sweetness. Sour-sweet taste with lots of spices inside. A bit overdone I think.
Excellent beer.  The aroma, which is matched by the taste, is fruity and a bit sweet.  This is an outstanding tripel.  Amazing drinkability, especially for the ABV.

11.2 oz. bottle. Pours a pale translucent yellow with a medium frothy white head. The aroma is wheat, caramel, toffee, orange, and cloves. The flavors is very sweet, with a slight bitter aftertaste. The body is heavy, almost abrasive. Light carbonation and a sticky, pulpy mouthfeel. Delicious and very interesting.

Hazy amber/gold color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, fruit, clove, some citrus, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, fruit (notably peaches & bananas), clove, citrus, and spice; Finish is dry; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, really good - excellent tripel!

Very nice triple. Quite smooth for its type. Im not giving it a higher taste rating because it was a bit too smooth for my liking. It left me wanting for more, which in belgian triples is a bad thing!
