Golden hazy body with white head. Aroma is moderately strong and pleasant - fruity, peppery phenols, yeast, floral hops. Has nice addition of wheat in flavour. Some alcohol warmth. Balanced.
33 cl bottle. Hazy deep golden with big white head. Flavour is malt, dry, fruit, sweet and alcohol.
Yeasty smell, golden and slightly brown pour with a dissipating head. A nice spicy tripel, long aftertaste, cooling sensation in mouth (nice!) and a dry finish. Excellent.

Appearance- This one poured a nice amber color with a nice, big off-white head. Lacing was incredible.

Smell- Interestingly complex with hints of spice, yeast, bread and fruits.

Taste- A nice sweetness with hints of honey, banana, cloves and other spices I cant name. Has a nice dry finish. The alcohol is present.

Mouthfeel- Has a medium, smooth body with a lot carbonation.

Overall- A great triple but not my favorite of the bunch.

Decanted from last years 11.2 oz bottle into a snifter, this pale golden liquid raises a mighty head and exudes notes of white grapes, almost prosecco. The flavor is drier than many tripels, and is all the more outstanding for it. This may not be the apex of Bernardus outstanding larder, but it is a fine beer nonetheless, and the perfect aperitif before fireworks and dinner on the 4th of July. Many Belgians have moved to this country over the years, and heres to one of that tiny nations finest exports.

head: 1/2 inch 
colour: deep blond , hazy 
smell: wheats , yeast , hops , bitter 
taste: spices , bitter flows over into malts and hops , sweetness , grass , dry end  quite nice !

Rating #370, bottle from Kvickly  

Appearance couldnt be better for a tripel. It is opaque hay-yellow with a very high everlasting head, and even yeast floating around in the glass. Aroma is hay, flowers and so on - a walk in the belgian landscape. Taste is tons of hay and flowers, of course accompanied by an obvious yeast profile as in any good tripel. Sweet malty and bit alcoholic finish with medium bitterness. Creamy and rather thick beer; refreshing, which is underlined by the carbonation. This tripel really works well, but I wouldnt dare to call it unique.

This beer, with high fermentation, has a pale amber color and a flowery, fruity taste with a harmonious balance between sweet and sour (8% alcohol content). This beer has a thick and vivid froth and strikes by its balanced taste with a delicate bitterness.

Sampled at Vineyards in Ottawa (November 2005). Pours a hazy peach juice looking colour with a big head that is creamy. Good retention and fizzy heavy lacing that stays. Some small particules in the bottom of the glass. Nutty alcohol nose with mild light fruit. Smoother mouthfeel than Maredsous tripel (10). Nutty taste all the way through and very smooth as well. Not as much apples as in the Maredsous 10. Some plum and raisins. Pretty good and well-brewed.

St. Bernardus
Tripel
Pours yellow with a medium white head. Nice aroma of banana, spices, Belgian yeast and cream. Mouthfeel is bubbly and crisp, yet has a creamy coating left behind. Flavor is good funk, cloves, and slightly bitter citrus Alcohol is virtually non-existent. Good tripel, especially out of a Bernardus glass.

Poured a hazy amber/orange with a large white stable head.  Aroma of malt, yeast, banana, citrus, and spices.  Taste is slightly fruity with some good malt flavors.  Spices throughout and slightly earthy.  Alcohol is barely noticeable.  Great finish.

330ml bottle. Well carbonated with a little twister of bubbles spiralling to the surface. Fluffy cloud like white foam head that is quite deep. Amber in colour with a spice fruit aroma that dominates. Strong sweet ripe fruit flavours and the high alcohol content leaves a kick on the palate.

Oh dear Lucifer what a beer. Tastes sweeter than apple juice and smoother than a milkshake. This is just amazing. There is a very earthy aroma to this, kind of put me off but once it settled in my glass I enjoyed it quite a bit. Very sweet yet, I dunno, I guess it smells like a fruit orchard in fall. This is amazing and worth every cent. I payed nearly $20 for four 11.2 ouncers and enjoyed them to their fullest extent. I love this beer.

330 ml bottle. From Poperinge, Belgium. Courtesy of Brandman.
Hazy golden colour with small white head.
Belgian yeast, fruits, malt, mild bitterness and some alcohol in aroma.
Fruits, malt, Belgian yeast and mild alcohol in flavour.
Alcohol warming. Balanced.

Deep brown body with creamy white head. Aroma of dark fruits. Very sweet with notes of dark fruits, vanilla and banana. Full bodied. Sweet, lasting finish that had a strong kick. Not as good as their Wit but very nice nonetheless.

Pours a very hazy lemon copper gold with frothy white head. Aroma is very sugary, a mix of brown sugar, raisin, bubblegum and alcohol. Flavor is earthy bread and coriander with spicy sugars. Body is creamy yet light with quite a bit of carbonation.

I am enjoying the hell out of this beer.  Pale cloudy amber, with a thin head.  Aroma is grapefruit, general citrus acidity, and grass.  Taste is light with citrus fruit dominating.  Palate is very dry.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 33cl bottle
Pours a hazy dark gold to orange color with a nice white head.^br]
The aroma is fresh and fruity, flowery with noble hops and some sweet malts. The taste is very full with fresh fruits, sweet malts and a strong flowery hopiness that ends in a fairly dry sweetbitter fruity finish.
A magnificent tripel that is heavenly on a hot sunny day!

750 ml bottle from Kellers IGA.  Pours a hazy, deep orange-gold color with a ton of visible yeast sediment all over and an out-of-control off-white head that settles into a resilient cap on the beer.  Aroma of banana, Belgian yeast, bready malts, pears, apples, pepper and other spices, and floral notes.  Flavor of banana, Belgian yeast, apples, pears, honey, candi sugar, pepper, a variety of malts, and a little bit of alcohol.  Medium-full bodied, wiht a bready mouthfeel and very active carbonation.  Sweet and malty.  Yeast everywhere in this.  Really nice tripel.

Served from bottle into a Chimay goblet.  Pours a nice hazy golden yellow with one-finger white head that subsides to a minimal amount.  Lacing was minimal throughout.  The aroma was comprised of fruit and slight alcohol notes.  The flavor was full of fruit, sweet malt, and slight alcohol.  It had a medium feel on the palate with high carbonation.  Overall this was an excellent brew that felt very nice on the palate and was extremely drinkable, refreshing, and smooth.  A definite must try for anyone.
Hazy golden pour with frothy head. Somewhat fruity sweetness if off set by a somewhat sour/acidic aftertaste. Has that characteristic Belgian yeast flavor.One of the better triples in my opinion.
Very nice  trippel full of spices and candy sugar. Also countains a frutiness side  (mostly apples). So it is sweet and none offensive with a slight bitterness. Easy to drink and well balanced.

bottle from Old Town Liquors in Louisville (4 pack with proper glassware). cloudy, golden/orange, frothy off-white appearance.   Cereal and floral aroma.  light sweetness.  medium body,  soft carbonation, creamy and long finish.  A fine beer!  Wish I had a 750ml bottle!

Bottle. Poured a very hazy yellowish amber color with a nice one and a half finger white head that lasted though the entire beer. Did leave some lacing on the side of the glass as it went. Aroma was fruit, fig, plum, and some malts. Flavor was lots of fruits. Figs and plum were there. I love this beer. The more Bernardus I drink the more I love them. This one is up to par along with there others.

330 mL bottle at Volo in Toronto, served in a snifter. Pours slightly cloudy amber with a quickly fading white head. Aromas of yeast, sour apple, banana, raisin and spice. Flavour is fruity sweet throughout with a nice vinous complexity. Alcohol makes its appearance in the long, peppery finish. On the palate, light-medium in body with a watery texture and soft carbonation. This is a nice tripel, but lacks somewhat in complexity: I would expect a bit more at 8% ABV. Definitely worth another try at some point. 2010-05-07

pale amber colour wih white head. aroma is floreal with spicy notes and some presenc of fruits such as citrus and banana. moderate alcoholic aftertaste and contained sweetness. overall i consider it a well balanced and pleasant beer. though not mi favorite in the genre

33 cl bottle to tulip glass. Pour is hazy and golden with a finger or so of sudsy foam. Nose is doughy and spicy with a hint of alcohol. Taste is sweet up front followed by spice and bitterness. Mouth is big and full, average carbonation. Finishes dry and warm with alcohol. Overall very well balanced. Not my favorite tripel, but a good standard.
From a bottle into a chilled Trappist glass. Pours
750 ml bottle a golden yellow colored beer with a white head aroma malts spices fruits citrus hop and yeast taste fruits citrus spices some sweetness and hop
(11.2 oz bottle).  Pours a beautiful yellow with nice white head.  Aroma of lemon or orange and rock candy.  Slightly bitter and prickly on the tongue.  Salty, sour and sweet balance.

33cl bottle from a multi-pack. Explosive opening, pouring a brilliant gold with a thick white head that rapidly faded; yeasty aroma with some bread and wheat; restrained malt flavours with a touch of citrus; the finish is warming but with no obvious alcohol. A pleasant example if the style.

Bottle.

A - Hazy copper orange with a large creamy white head. Ok retention (a bit below average) with a nice layer of lacing left.

S - Good base of malt along with some along with some golden fruit and citrus. Lemon and orange along with some peach, apricot, and apple to name some of the fruity aromas. Good amount of yeast and spices as well. Hints of some banana and bubblegum Hefe aromas as well.

T - Similar to the nose. Malt base provides a nice sweetness with some Hefe flavors and a slight hint of breadiness. Good amount of Belgian spices and yeast and a pretty strong fruity taste (similar to the nose). A little bit of citrus tart and very little bitterness comes out as well. Well balanced with sweetness coming out slightly ahead.

M - Medium body with average carbonation. Smooth and slightly creamy. 

D - Very drinkable beer. A lot of fruit and overall sweet but not even close to cloying. Well balanced with some spiced, warming, tart, and bitter flavors present in the background at varying levels. Warming beer but the alcohol is well hidden. Enjoyable to drink.

Notes: Nice Tripel that is big and fruity but also well balanced. A very solid offering from a very good brewery. Definitely worth trying.

12 oz. bottle poured into my Chimay chalice

A- Body is a light golden hue. Pours with a beautiful creamy 1 finger eggshell head which has perfect retention. Lots of lacing is left behind in the glass. Body is slightly translucent and yeast can be seen floating throughout as bubbles steadily rise to the top.

S- Mild fruit such as apples and pears upfront with a subtle presence of alcohol. Spicy Belgian yeast buried deep in the background.

T- Taste is soft and subtle the whole way around. A soft fruitiness upfront with a slight yeasty background. Spicy yeast comes through for the finish. All that lingers is a touch of alcohol warmth.

P-Low carbonation and body that is very smooth and creamy. well done.

O- This is a nice, light, refreshing tripel. There are others that I enjoy a lot more but this is still a good one. It was great to get to try such a well-hyped example of this style. I will probably have it again-but not too soon because it is so expensive.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-08-2008 05:06:59

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2010 Bottle pour to tulip glass gives cloudy yellow brown color with thick white head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma sweet and fruity.  Flavor citrusy, sweet and sour, yeast.  Smooth somewhat thick mouth feel with a nice gentle finish.  Nice tripel but not to the level of their abt.  Alcohol well disguised.  Not much complexity here.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2010 (bottle) pours a hazy golden-yellow colour with a frothy dense white head. aroma of wheat, powdered sugar, candied fruits, light herbal hops and alcohol. flavour is the same, though less nuanced, with a dry grainy finish. strong-bodied with smooth carbonation. nice enough.
Excellent tripel that pours a nice golden color, with a medium white head that sticks around for a while.  Has hints of fruit and citrus, with a good amount carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2011 Hazy gold, coat of white head. Aromas of sour oranges, cheese rind, cough drops, black pepper. Light honeyed fruit sweetness followed by a little marmalade sourness and spicy hop bitterness. Also something like apricot stones. Very carbonated mouthfeel. Alcohol is well-integrated. Dry finish with a little chewiness. [3.5] Bottle 7C. Hazy gold, lasting fat coat of white head. Sweet and sour aroma with oranges, menthol, coriander, white pepper. Cheesy yeast note is there, but less than last time. More dry than bitter at the end. Very fizzy mouthfeel. Expected to like this more this time, but much the same.

one of the best in what is quickly becoming my favorite style. unbelievable flavor and body for a tripel that isnt too high in abv. gorgeous pale coloring and tight carbonation that can only remind me of champagne. white head that stays beyond the end of the liquid. so good that i literally just kept sipping it, i couldnt take it away from my mouth for more than a few seconds before i wanted another.
750ml bottle. Dry, bright and yeasty. Light bubblegum, and hoppy finish. Rad, quintessential tripel. Could drink this all the time.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours to a deep golden body with a tall and dense white head.  The aroma is yeasty, lightly perfumey, citrus, and pale malts.  The flavor is yeasty carbonated sweet malt with a nice perfume hop.  Some earthy dust and light mineral water.  Almost apple pie like.  The palate is clean but substantial.  Medium-light bodied.  Very nicely textured.
Bottle. Color: Hazy gold, with rich white head. Aroma: honey with citrus touch. Medium sweet taste with apple. Full bodied,  lively carbonated with bitter finish.  Pretty good beer, I like it.

Pours a bright golden yellow color. Active carbonation throughout the session. Aromas of hops, fruit, and a little yeast. Has a light fruity citrus taste, with some yeasty notes, and a good hop flavor.

A great Tripel with a very well-balanced flavor. This beer pours amber orange with an off-white soapy head that leaves a great deal of lacing. Im drinking out of a St. Bernardus Goblet and that just makes it all the prettier (the glass is great, by the way, almost an over-sized wine glass). The head is wonderfully Belgian. This beer has its share of delicate funky yeast. The flavor is a careful balance of bitterness and earthiness. There are some good sweet malt notes lurking in the background, and I wish that they were a touch stronger or richer or something, but I guess thats not the way of most Belgians. Its a very good beer and evinces a great deal of craftsmanship. I always feel a little wanting when I love a brewerys Quad and then try their less interesting Tripel.
Cloudy golden head with big white creamy head that laces as it thins. Sweet yeast aroma. Sweet, bubbly, yeasty, clean, warming taste and feel.

Poured a hazy yellow/gold (almost pale) with a small off-white head. Aroma: a curious sweetness, alcohol, yeast, grapefruit. Taste: sweet, spices, alcohol, fruity (grapefruit). Aftertaste is fruity with a medium bitterness. Medium carbonation. Medium body. Overall: good but not great.

Poured a beautiful golden, hazy amber colour with subtle aroma of citrus and hops. Smallish head with some lovely lacing. Light carbonation and a nice medium body. Bit of an abrupt finish but didnt detract from overall enjoyment. Very quaffable!

Bottle. Pours a hazy light orange beer with a good white head. Very active beer when I opend the bottle. To bad some of the beer got spilled. Really impressive aroma with fruity hints and some spices. Taste is also very impressive with a full mouthfeel. Hints of the fruits again and some bitter notes. Complex brew wich was very enjoyable. St. Bernardus never disappoints me. One of the best Tripels I had so far.

Poured from the bottle a hazy cloudy yellow with sediment.  Very nice white head.  Aroma consists of pear, yeasts, alcohol and a hint of bubblegum.  Taste is sweet with a nice finish, grows more complex as the beer warms.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange, nice looking, creamy off-white head. Aroma is malt, citrus and yeast notes. Flavor is a blend of sweet malt, some fruits and spices. Soft palate and slightly bitter finish.
poured very alive yellow and cloudy with lots of floaters and of white head with aromas being of hay, grass, dough, raisin, taste was light fizzy, long finish, of cereal and fruits just not my thing

Bottle. Light orange and honey golden in appearance with a half inch of thin white head. Lots of carbonation trails throughout the pint glass. Aroma is similar to champagne along with some apple fragrances. Taste is sweet and doughy with strong caramel malt and burnt sugar flavors. Theres also some orange peel and cloves in there as well. It has a dry and warm alcohol finish with strong carbonation. Overall flavor is rich and bold.

Bottle. Hazy yellow with a fluffy white head. The aroma is medium spicy with a good fruity hoppy backbone. Caramel. Lovely fruity and light spicy flavour with lots of caramel. Light warming alcohol. Nice treat.
A really well made tripel. Manages to avoid that alcoholic strange burn I get from a lot of beers of this ilk. Smooth and fruity this is another great beer from these guys.
si presenta con un bellissimo cappello bianco compatto.lAroma è di pompelmo con  note di luppolo e banana.risulta una tripel molto pastosa e cremosa!
Golden with an everlasting head. Aroma-big yeast followed by pale malt then a little hop bitterness. Taste-perfect balance of sweet malt, yeast, touch of hops, and a bit of alcohol. Rich and fruity.
Drank from a sniffer out of a bottle at the last chance for cheese restaurant in Hunter, NY.  Has a light amount of carbonation with a slight hoppiness to the finish.

Pours creamy yellow-brown with 3 fingers of white head and lot of lacing. Soft floral aromas with banana and apricot. Creamy on palate but well integrated with carbonation. Melon, Banana and Orange blossom on palate. Absolutely delicious.

frothy large white head. good lacing. fully diminishing. cloudy, thick dark yellowish orange body. aroma: moderate hoppy and yeasty, alcohol, peach and citrus lemon. if: moderate sweet and light bitter. ff: light sweet moderate bitter. long duration. palate: medium body, dry texture, fizzy carbonation and moderate astringent and light chalky finish.dulçor frutado, diferente da média, levíssimos toques lembrando limão; paladar com toques atípicos, boa surpresa; azedinho sutil no final, devido as muitas particularidades, compensa o valor pago, extremamente carbonatada, chega a estufar, cerveja pra se beber bem lentamente. 280s

Aroma of grapefruit hints of hops.  Pours a nice amber golden haze.  Very lively beer.  Nice medium head.  A very doughy tripel.  Different from any other tripel I have had.  Has notes of banana and even bubblegum, which is a first for me with beers.  A creamy beer that has some bitter on the backend.  A delicious brew.  But not of the level of the Chimay, Chouffe, or Tripel Karmeliet.
bottle - orange beer with a white strong head. Aroma  banana, malty sweet. Nice triple flavour has with typical maltiness but also a refreshing  Recomedable.
oro buona schima piuttosto persitente naso9 erbacee leggermente speziato in bocca buon corpo alcol nasosto leggera speziatura buona luppolatura amaro deciso

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours bright and gold.  Strong notes of roasted corn in the nose.  Very floral.  Very yeasty.  Hints of decco candy and basement.  Flavor is bright, slightly sweet.  The candy and flora come more to the foreground.  Very smooth.

Pours a cloudy orange with a ton of esters, and a small but constant white head. The aroma is bready yeast, with some citrus, banana, and white grapes. The flavor is similar, and very delicious. On the sweet side overall, but nicely done. Floats on the palate, with soft carbonation. I have to say, this is better than I had expected.
Draft. Pours golden with a white head. Flavor is yeast, sugar, some floral citrus notes. One of the best Tripels Ive tried.
Bottle.  Aroma of yeast, bananas and spices.  Flavors follow, with the spices tingling the tongue on the finish.  For a style Im not too fond of, this is a great one.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 11.2 oz. bottle, pours a hazy golden with a monstrous white head. Aroma is citrus and yeast. Flavour is predominantly yeast, with a citrusy undertone. Classic take on a tripel and an excellent one at that.

Chilled but not cold in a pint glass.  Pours extremely hazy, deep orange in color, with a thick white head.  The aroma is mostly fresh dough with some yeast and a tiny bit or citrus (orange/lemon) in the background.  The taste is sweet with a hit or sourness that comes on late.  There are some floral notes but the flavor profile is quite narrow for a tripel and certainly not among the best.  Im not saying that I did not like it; however, it is a little too sweet, the alcohol is masked too deeply, and its a little thin on the palate.  I think that this is one of the more overrated tripels but it is easy drinking and is not offensive in anyway - its really not exceptional in any way either.  Im not really sure why so many people rave about this one.

What a great example of what a Tripel is supposed to taste like. Deep gold in color with a rich lasting head this beer has a gente alcohol warmth with no burn and one of the best bottled Tripels I have ever had.

bottle - hazy orange beer with a nice white head. Aoma has some banana, is yeasty and fresh. Complex flavour has some maltiness but also a refreshing yeasty sourness. Carbonation is quit high. Faint alcohol detectable.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2010 [bottle from bierkompass.de]
Slightly musty aroma with lots of vinous, white grapes and faint banana. Hazy dary straw with a thin, white cover that clings to the glass. Very smooth banana, white grape flavour with a pleasant, herbal bitterness and sweet cherry ethanol finish. Excellent balance and delicate for such a strong beer, but just a bit too much banana for me. Light to medium body, high carbonation, peppery warming sweet finish.

Hazelbrown pour with medium creamy head.
Hoppy and malty aroma, with hints of fruit (banana & citrus) and earthy notes.
Bitter hops taste, fading to sweet fruit.
Orange with a very thick head.  It smelled of flowers and citrus with a taste of lemon citrus and yeast.  Highly carbonated beer.

Pours with a healthy head, strong ester aromas are present.  The head setlles out nicely.  While there are a lot of ester aromas there arent any ester flavors.  A very nice ruby/golden color really a beautiful colored beer.  Slightly citrus/spicy attack which mellows to a malty, very very slight fruit-like flavor.  Overall a very nice beer.  Just another wonderful offering from a wonderful brewery.

Will pour a five+ finger white head that fades quickly to a thin layer, leaving some lace. Hazy pale amber color.  Honey and fruit nose. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Flavor is light honey, yeast and pear.  Nice triple.  Higher ABV is hidden. $17.00 for a gift pak of four 330ml bottles from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

Popped the cap and high pressure excitement that sprayed everything in my kitchen.  Aroma of doughy bread with a hint of alcohol.  Very thick, foamy palate with a nice little burst of IBUs and a touch of cranberry.  Very nice head and quite smooth for a heavyweight.  Very nice beer.
Hardly noticeable aroma, appearance is good, taste is almost too subtle. The palate is weak. Overall, disappointing for a triple.

Another great beer from this brewery;
hazy pale color; huge foamy head
great aroma
yeasty, smooth light tasting with full palate
doesnt stand out as much as some from this mixed 6 pk , but smooooth...

Pours into tulip with a frothy white head, golden apple color with floaty bits. Aroma is dough, banana bread, apple, floral and grassy hops. Taste is yeasty, sweet spiced pear balanced with sour subacid fruits. Finish is fruity and spicy, creamy with soft effervescence on the palate. A wonderful triple that is worth coming back to.
From an old rating note: 12oz bottle.  cloudy yellow pour.  citrus, bread and banana in the aroma.  candy sugar, dry, cloves in the taste.  good.  need to try again for a better rate.

Pours a brilliant hazy golden yellow with an enormous fluffy white head that refused to go anywhere for the duration.

The aroma is unmistakably St. Bernardus with the signature fruity esters - bubble gum and banana - from the yeast.  There is a light spiciness to the nose and some sugary apples and pears.

The taste is much the same but seems even sweeter and much fruiter with the pears and apples really coming to the front.  The yeast backbone is hefty and imparts the banana sweetness that I got in the aroma.  The finish has some peppery spices but less than some tripels Ive had.

The mouthfeel is extremely creamy and close to full-bodied for the style.  Lots of carbonation as well.

St. Bernardus makes some world class beers and this one is no exception.  Its an insanely drinkable, uber-fruity, sweet tripel that holds its own with some of the best out there.  I love this stuff.

Bottle enjoyed at the Hop & Vine...  Poured golden/orange with a thck, rocky, white head.  Aroma of apples, apricots, champagne like yeasts.  Well carbonated with a thick, foamy and full palate.  Well spiced, light fruits and mild hops with vegetable-like earth tones and sweet grains. Finished with a tart, yeast ester-like flavor. As it warmed it got a little creamier, boozier, and sweeter with a citrus-like, wood quality.

Poured into a snifter a murky yellow/orange with a thin white head.  Wow this thing is beautiful.  Somewhat soft nose of sweetness, floral, light fruit.  Taste comes in better with a touch of sourness along with citrus, a lot of sweetness, and some fruity notes.  Sadly the palate is very bland and musty and doesnt retain the sweetness and taste.  Still good though

Bottle. Pours a dark gold, whit floffo head. Aroma of tart citrus, yeasty, malty, light caramel. Flavor has a nice malty back bone with a light sweetness. Some caramel, a little farm house, earthy, notes of licorice, nice light fruit notes with a smooth balanced bitterness. Mouth feel is light-medium body with high fizzy carbonation, smooth. Overall, great beer!b Easy to drink.
Pours out a dark golden blonde with a small white head that lingers for a bit. Fruity, spicy aroma. Taste is light fruit and spice, with a hint of alcohol.

Hazy oranges and golds hang heavy in my chalice under a thick orange creamsicle head which fades in rocky patches. Clumps of lace cling to the sides of my glass even as I tilt her orange-gold depths towards my nose to breath deep of her promise. Did someone open a jar of orange marmalade and apricot jam? I could swear someone did because my St. Bernardus Tripel could certainly pass as one. Rich, sweet, and a bit heavy, her nose grabs the orange marmalade and apricot jelly and leads me right into a heavy cloud of Belgian yeast, spice, dough, and sweet alcohol warmth. A bit of pineapple joins the mix which rests comfortably atop a solid foundation of graham crackers and sourdough. At the back of each whiff is a funky hit of sour lemons even as nutmeg, cinnamon sticks, and spiced apples tickle and tease. Mm tasty, and I havent even tasted her yet, a travesty of epic proportions I must correct immediately. Eyes closed in reverence, I part my lips and invite her rich golden-orange depths into my being. Bright and dry, my first generous quaff is much drier than I was expecting, especially considering how wet her nose was. A bit of an adjustment, but one I am enjoying. Belgian yeast, spice, and warmth are immediate even as my mouth starts to dry. As my body picks up soothing warmth, dry brown spices mingle and meddle atop my tongue: nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger, and for added measure, dry wood. Spiced apples, apricot jam, and orange marmalade fill the middle of her body with a faint hint of brandy warmth and spice. Fresh whole pineapples along with red apples, pears, and kiwi join the growing tropical mix even as she continues to dry my senses. A hit of sweet alcohol warmth in the back of my throat lingers for a long dry spiced finish. Her nose could not have been more different than her body, but as I near the end of my bottle and my glass, I find that they are actually more similar than different.


Different in all the best ways possible. Once more St. Bernardus proves their brewing mettle. Its easy to understand why, at one point, the discerning Trappist monks at Westvleteran chose them to brew their sacred beers. Westvleteran is nigh impossible to get here in the states, but I can get St. Bernardus any and every day of the week. Speaking of which, I think I shall have to bring some more St. Bernardus home with me for future heavenly sessions.

Poured from 11.2 oz. into a St. B. chalice.  golden in color with huge white head.  Mild nose with hints of grass and grapefruit.  Very bubbly, with champagne like qualities. Fruity taste, indeed balanced between the sweet and sour.

It poured a hazy golden liquid with a creamy white foam that left lots of lacing.

Smell of yeast, dried fruit, wood and honey. The honey scent was quite strong.

The mouthfeel was semi-smooth with just a bit of roughness. It had a medium body and low bitterness. Tasted similar to the smell and the most dominant flavour was definitely honey. Lots of sweetness. Very nice beer, one of the best triples I have ever tried.
Pours golden, off white head. Aroma has a prominent belgian yeast character, sweet candi sugar backed by cloves. A great sweet flavour, balanced by dry alcohol, strong cloves, warm, spicy. Awesome.

Bottle from Total Wine. A cloudy yellow beer with a large pillowy white head. Moderate aroma of bread, bananas and oranges. Flavor closely resembles the aroma...a bit sour in the beginning and again at the end. Flavors are not intense enough to cut through the sourness or complex enough to work well together. It is, however, nice and frothy as advertised
Tripels are not my favorite style, but I do like this one. Not much Aroma. There is some visible sediment floating in the beer. The taste is a smooth banana and yeast combination. Very mellow.

Very pale orange color with lots of floating debris. It looks fine if you dont hold it up to the light. The aroma is mellow, the malt is the star, with some hops to back it up. Some floral and apple notes play a nice counterpart to the malt. Flavor is also nicely mellow. Not too bitter, and just a hint of sweetness. Light and spritzy carbonation. A very good beer overall.

Pours a cloudy pale golden with a large frothy off white head. Aroma is medium sweet, fruity, spicy and very light alcohol. This tripel has a decent amount of sweetness (much less than Tripel Karmeliet) which is nicely balanced with a slightly lesser amount of bitterness. Lively carbonation, creamy texture. Medium to full bodied, short and dry finish. This is another fine beer from St. Bernardus.
Exploding bottle.  Cloudy gold/orange pour, frothy white head.  Fruit, earthy malt, light sweetness and banana, floral.  Pretty tasty tripel, well done.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours a murky yellow colour with a good size head and normal carbonation.
Aroma is very vague, but pleasant none the less, would have been better if it was a bit stronger.
Taste is very fruity, citrusfruits and sweet fruits there, nicely balanced with some spices on top.
Good beer.

75cl bottle. From a friend. Best before 2012-12-28. It poured a light orange colour with a big white creamy head that settled down fast in the glass. Very carbonized. Aroma is fruity with notes of yeast and some wheat. Flavour is dry and a bit grassy and fruity. Medium long aftertaste.

clear and golden with huge white head.  fruity nose.  moderate carbonation for style.  flavor with mild bitterness before some fruity esters and some strong alcohol, notes of oxidation makes me think this is an over aged bottle.  the prospects of a great triple are there, but this particular bottle is likely less than ideal.

Pours a hazy gold with medium white head that dissipates quickly.  Smells of yeast, light malt, nuts and fruit that is dominated by bananas.  Smell is very similar to a delicious, alcoholic banana nut bread.  Taste is of spices mainly at first which fades into a malt and fruits.  Finishes with alcohol, spices, and fruits.  Light texture with full carbonation.  Taste and aroma disagreed with each other, but in the end still a good beer.

2003 Vintage, from bottle Dec. 12th, 2009.Pours cloudy golden as it is bottle conditioned with a small bit of carbonation.  Smells of yeast, fruit, and honey.  Tastes of heavy honey and sweetness.  Light bodied and one of the best of the night.  Very refreshing and sweetness lingers.  Maybe it was the 2003 vintage that made it that much better, but I loved this one.

Great aroma, smells just like the Abt.  Very fruity with the distinctive Belgium yeast smell.  Murky, light brown in color with a one finger white head that lingers.  Great mouthfeel.  Light bodied but a full, carbonated palate.  Flavor is all fruit with a nice alcohol burn.  Has a grass like aftertaste that develops late.  Slightly bitter aftertaste.  Overall, this is another great Belgium beer!!  Highly recommend.

This beer pours a rather mirky pale yellow colour with a small white head. The aroma is of fruits and spice but it is not overly pronounced. There is fruit in the flavour but unfortunately all I could get was a lot of different spices which is good if thats what you like. Light bodied with a long finish, it is easy to drink and a good beer.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Smells citrusy, hoppy and like bread.  Not the best beer Ive ever smelled.  Thought it was going to be more bitter than it was based on smell. Taste of malt, citrus, and bread.  Can sense the alcohol. Head and lacing is top notch, but beer is for drinking, not for looking at. Great palate. A little disappointed in this one.  Definitely not one of Bernarduss best.

Aroma is fruity spices and must.  Pours a cloudy (with floaties.) Has a very citrusey flavor - almost like grapefruit. Hoppy in this sense. Flavor is refreshing, slightly sour/slightly bitter but finishes clean.
Bottle. Pours hazy golden yellow with  a lot of sediment in suspension. Sweet aroma of  banana, vanilla, raisin, citrus, and a little alcohol. Tastes very sweet with medium sourness and bitterness.
hazy amber pour, frothy, lasting white head with good lacing. Malty, citrusy aroma. medium sweetness, lightly bitter.

Golden amber, thin white head, light lacing.
Aroma is of gingerbread, high caramel sweetness, some fruit, spices.
Flavour has some caramel sweetness, floral hops, spice, yeast and alcohol.
Lightly bitter mouthfeel, medium/light body, high carbonation.
Finishes long, sweet, warming. 
Getting old a year past its date, sort of a shock. Would have thought that this would hold up better after having fresh ones bought at the same time. 
330ml bottle purchased from the LCBO in Peterborough, Ontario.
Opened on March 1, 2009.
Best before June 5, 2008.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy amber brown body with a yellow exploding head.  Huge fruity esters.  Plum, toffee, and a light caramel apple tone.  Dates with spicy yeast accents and lush etoh warming.  This ale is rather divine.

Years ago this is the beer that started my love affair with the tripel style. Pours a sunny hazy blonde color with a thick luxurious head that doesnt look like its going away any time soon. As I drink the beer a very thick lace is left on the glass. Aromas of fresh baked baguette, good yeasty spiciness, some hay, and some lemon rind. The flavor reminds me at first of a very good pilsner with the nice mildly spicy hoppiness and the bready bright lightly salty malt character. The flavor turns more complex in a hurry though with some light banana notes some mild sweetness, some spiciness, with some minerally character (the good kind) . There are some citrusy lemony flavors both in a raw lemon and lemon candy kind of way that is not to say that the beer is particularly sour, far from it. The alcohol is really nice well nuanced and mild. What a delicious beer. Exemplary within the style.

Slightly hazy dark yellow with a thick frothy white head. Wonderful sweet aroma of citrus, banana and vanilla. Taste has light sweetness, medium bitterness and has a slightly sour finish. Quite some carbonation and a creamy texture. Good beer.

Cork and cage bottle. This one was a gusher! Hazy golden pour with a large foamy white head. Aroma is yeast, fruity, spiced, citrus. Flavor is very fruity, spicy, yeast, citrus, white pepper. Bubbly mouthfeel.
Dark yellow pour with lots of chunks.  Giant white head is speckled like cinnamon.  Smells faintly of banana and citrus.  Very spicy.  Fruit flavor.  Finish is thick and warm.

This is decent, but a rather disappointing tripel that I find rather characterless, bland, and dry.

It is bright gold, very clear before the sediment makes it hazy.  A huge white head  shrinks steadily but quickly  to a lasting, thin wispy top.  It produces a little uneven, foamy lace. 

The aroma is a lot of grain with light raisin, mineral, bread crust, mineral, a hint of pear and hay, somewhat resembling a pale bock.

The taste is up front pear and hay with mineral, slightly raisiny but mostly dry.  It soon becomes drier in alcohol with a hint of lemon pulp, but all thin and dry.  The finish and aftertaste are dry and thin, tasting of fruit candy without the sweetness. It is one-dimensional and rather bland.
Bottle from 2002. Pours a hazy orange color with a small white head. Has a fruity spicy yeasty aroma. Sweetish fruity malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty finish.

Bottle courtesy of Fratto. First off, huge head response. Bright orange color with chunks of yeast galore. Lovely aroma of sweet fruit, yeast and a little bit of spice. Tastes of dry fruit, very poignant. Finish loses some of its luster but remains an overall very tasty tripel.

Bottle from Mr Lawrence Wine Merchant, Brockley. Bottle gushed out (sediment and all) and the bit I managed to get into the glass poured a hazy orange colour with a strong white head. Aromas of peaches,spiced apples, some citrus. Flavours of apple sauce, caramel, sweet spices. Sweet and hoppy finish. Good tripel.

Pours a nice hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is esthers, banana, spices, fruits, alcohol, sugars, yeasts. Flavor is banana, sugars, yeasts, fruits, citrus, a bit of bitterness. Lots of carbonation. Decent Tripel, not too sweet.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a goblet. There is a best before date of 19-07-10 on the back label and it was sampled on 7-1-09.

Appearance: Its head is bright white in color and about one finger in thickness. The light foamy head fades quickly down to just a small ring of foam that makes slick lacing on the glass as I swirl and sip. Under this head is an orangey tan colored liquid which is cloudy and full of tan yeast floaters.

Smell: The aroma has notes of fresh peeled apple skins, funky yeast and a touch of apple cider vinegar. 

Taste/Mouth: There is a slightly astringent, citrus and hard apple cider flavor with some spicy phenolic character as well. The finish becomes bone dry with flavor notes of dry powdery yeast and some mild leafy hops that add just a touch of bitterness. The carbonation is light and just tickles the tongue. Its body has a medium to full feel and its texture is a little bit thick, almost chewy.

Notes: I found this Tripel to be just a little ruff around the edges, heavy and well, just a little bit above average. Im not sure if I just got a bad bottle or maybe it could use some more time to condition in the bottle or maybe less.

330 mL bottle at St. Veronus.  Hazy amber gold with a nice head and a moderate amount of sediment.  Aroma is yeasty/fruity/spicy - similar to, but slightly less appealing than, La Fin du Monde.  Still good though.  Flavour is similar to the aroma, with a dryish, slightly bitter finish.  Decent body and carbonation.  A nice beer.

330 ml bottle - clear, dark gold with thin white head and minor lacing; grainy, sweet with thin body; almost syrupy with mild flavors; some sweetness; raw, grainy and some yeasty spice; pretty tame overall
Really flowery and perfumey. A lot of hoppy taste and smell. Good beer overall. Very balanced with maltiness and sweetness. Refreshing and thick.
Extremely refreshing, crisp, and flavorful. very yeast and doughy palate. the body was cloudy but still relatively transparent.

#500!!!!! Color is a pretty cloudy yellow with long lasting foamy head. Smell is sweet like a white wine, and flavor is a fluffy, wheaty malty mouth of delightful mess. Palate is a little stingy, but overall very refreshing. noticeably thick, too. No really acohol flavor. Quite nice. Bottle from Total Wine and Spirits, North Miami Beach.

Pours a hazy orange with a thin, short lasting head. Nice sweet aroma of yeast, fruit, brown sugar and spices. Mouth feel is harsh and dry. Full body. Taste is very similar to aroma: yeast, sugar and fruit (banana and apricots) with some spice notes.  Long earthy finish. Very nice, complex brew, not very easy to drink though.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2015 (750ml corked ) Forget that  overrated and unbalanced Westmalle Tripel , this fine yeasty liquid wears the  drunken   "King of Triples" crown.  perfume ,spice,oranges , flowers , yeasty esters   , with  steams of dry complexity . Sweet malt backbone.      A divinty here .

In a Trappist glass, this Tripel pours a straw yellow with little head.  Nice aroma of fruit, flowers and alcohol.  Taste is exactly what one would expect from a superb Tripel - citrus, spices, yeast and some floral notes that temper the alchol that also makes its presence known.  Very nice.

Great aroma on this, i was really surprised even on my second bottle of this.  Spice, citrus, cigar smoke and black licorice make up the awesome nose on this.  Taste isnt as big or cool, but its still delicious.  Peach, lemon and ash.
sour aroma with white head... taste of sour and citrus is well balance with the alcohol flavor.. very smooth.. amazing

beer pours golden with thick white head, good carbonation and floaties galore. smells of yeast, citrus fruits and alcohol. taste is a well balanced and complex blend of yeast, apples and oranges, and a cinnamony spice. very smooth and goes down easy, delicious from first sip to last sip. great stuff.

Bottle from Sams.  Pours nearly clear gold with bubbly white head... head recedes but sticks around.  Nose shows some hops, lemon and orange citrus, some bitter citrus peel, peaches, some banana, and lovely yeast. Spicy. Taste shows some tart pear or apple, lots of slightly under-ripe peach, herbal notes, honey, and white pepper.  Full taste and clean, dry finish.  Well carbonated but not prickly. Dig it.

Gold blonde colour, big head, yeast grains in the glass when ouring out the beer. Aroma has something of ornage peels and lemon or lime. A bit herbal. Tastes full, smooth, sweety, like sinas (sisi), a slighlt bitter finish. Nice beer though the sisi-taste is not my thing.

Bottled. It is very carbonated and pours a  light caramelish orange with a thin to medium white head. aroma is sweet and spicy with flavor of fruit and yeast with alcohol presence. Great drier finish.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 750ml bottle via Hagen. Pours a hazy amber with a large white head. Nose is all about some VERY spicy Belgian yeast. Taste is complex and hard to describe as their ate LOTs of flavors but they meld together so nicely. I think i get some ginger, pepper bananna, clove, cinnamon, orange, honey and more pepper. It is hot, but not alcoholic hotness, this is spicy hotness, almost like jalapeno peppers in there, but not really lol. Like i said i have a hard time on picking out the flavors in  this beer because the flavors meld together so perfectly. In any case, this is a very very good beer. Body is medium, carbonation is high.

Kind of a weird brew. Lots of bready/biscuit flavors, with a an odd sweetness similar to brown sugar, some slight citric fruitiness, brett like basement funk, and an herbal hop note towards the finish. A bit unbalanced, and a bit too sweet for my taste. Not bad, just not for me.

Nice straw gold appearance with rocky, meringue like head that dissipates quickly into a thin but resiliant white layer.

Nose is of pre-baked Pilsbury biscuits, clean lemon, and miscellaneous herbs.

On the palate this beer is well-carbonated with a rising, zesty citrus flavour followed by a sweet and tangy bite that leads to the finish. Citrus baked goods come to mind, such as pies.... lemon, maybe key lime, very citrusy.

Finish is long and rather tart, perhaps a touch bitter as well.
Poured into glass.  Hazy orange/yellow pour with fluffy off-white head with some decent.  A little spicy with some citrus  notes and a bit of maltiness.

330ml bottle from Utobeer, bb.27.01.12.Cloudy, golden body with a greyish, soapy head, slowly diminishing. Inviting aroma of sweet spices, lemony hops and a note of yeast. Comprehensive taste with spices and subdued banana combined with minty sweetness and nutty malts followed by yeast and warming alcohol. Full  bodied, but still very soft and easy to drink. A tasty tripel, indeed (Earls Court, hotel room 07.08.2009).

Bottle. Hazy golden pour with a thick, foamy white head. Light pear, yeast, and alcohol aromas. Balanced malts, moderate sweetness, and mild bitterness with light toffee and fruit. Very nice, creamy mouthfeel.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2009 Pour from the 25oz. bottle into a pint glass: More like a Heffe than a Tripel here- but Im not complaining. Balanced tastes of banana, sweet malts, coriander, and fruity yeasts. For an 8% abv Tripel the alc-y stays hidden. A good buy. Drinkability: Yes. Rebuy: Sure. #120 on 13092009, DG.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 TAP: hazy yellow pour, nearly no head. Grape and wheat on the nose, some malt on taste, smooth, boozy, no hop, not too sweet and tasted maybe flat? I kind of think I got a bad batch of this, because it didnt strike me as overly great.
UPDATED: JUL 26, 2010 Hazy yellowThin head. Malty very alcoholic. Light fresh well rounded not bad at all. Lots of candy sugar andsubtle fruit tones, with a nice wheat flavour. Very nice

Bottle. Pours hazy golden orange with a big fluffy white head and lots of chunky sediment. Nose is quite spicy with yeast really standing out and a hint of mandarine in the background. Flavour is fairly grainy with cookie dough, orange peel and mixed spice coming through. Fairly light mouthfeel which becomes quite dry at the end. Another very nice beer from St. Bernardus.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2009 Appearance:  Yellow straw with brown tint, Long-lived, White head, vigorous carbonation.
Aroma: Initially earthy (which fades some), pleasantly vegetal, floral, and spice (nutmeg?), sweet caramel malt and candy sugar gains in strength.
Flavors: Caramel, candy sugar, long floral and toasty caramel finish.
Comment: More complex than the Watou.

Light gold, yeast floating in bottle. Lots of head when poured.  Very smooth beer.  Not the sweetest or most bitter tripel I have had but rather somewhere in the middle.  Very nice.  Will definitely have one of these again.

Must have been the right beer at the right time.  Complex fruity and flowery aromas from the start, with a strong bready yeast aroma.  Flavors even more complex with minty bitterness on the finish.  Great Tripel.
Very very foamy, spurted out of the bottle. Nice looking triple with some hints of nuts. Not too much alcohol and not too bitter. Nice Triple.
Pours a nice pale amber with a nice bubbly head and plenty of funky belgian yeast in the aroma.  Flavor is fruity with a nice sourness...the high abv is well hidden.  Very nice tripel.

Bottle. Pours hazy gold with a mightily fizzy white head. Nice lacing. Nose is spicy bananas, citrus/lemon, creamy malt, pepper. Palate is more banana peel, white pepper, lemon juice, candy floss, yeast. Long, mildly boozy finish. A classic example of the style from a trusted brewer.

Tripels not my fave but this one is good.  Huge head (possibly cause this was cellared 6 months), foamy, left foamy blotchy lacing.  Hazy, cloudy, partially with bubble action. Yeasty, bananas, spices, soft palate initially, then a bit sharper, a good deal of body there.  Bananas, malt, a bit of alcohol.  Outstanding.
Single bottle into an abbey glass.  Delicious and fruity flavor, but the flavor isnt quite strong enough to really knock me dead.

Wheat, hay, and lemon aroma. Hazy yellow, thick white head, nice lacing. Quality malt and grass flavor. Drinks like a helles. Something is wrong, this is unlike any Tripel Ive ever had. "Pales" in comparison to 12.

On tap at the White Horse, London. A hazy yellow beer with a big fluffy white head. Fruity Belgian aroma. Tastes fruity, spicy, sweet, lemon. Had this many times in bottled form but this draught version was smooth and magnificent. A wonderful Belgian Tripel.

Pours a cloudy dark yellow with a fluffy, long lasting , white head. The aroma is mainly yeasty, with some lighter citrus notes, mainly lemon. The flavour is decent, yeast, some malt caramel, light notes of fruit, a touch of citrus, alcohol in the finish. Good, but nothing great. A well rounded, enjoyable brew.

Pours a cloudy pale yellow/orange, big fluffy head, incredible lacing. Nose of yeast, some citrus, not much else. Taste of yeast, malt, some fruit, a nice hint of alcohol in the finish, a tad warming. Medium bodied, creamy texture, and lively carbonation with a rather dry finish. Wonderfully balanced, not the most exciting tripel Ive had, but absolutely enjoyable.

I shared a bottle of this with BeerBaron617 this evening.  It sort of got all foamy and explosive when we opened the bottle, but there wasnt too much lost in the situation.  It poured a dark yellow with lots of floaters.  It had a nice fluffy white head.  Aroma is sort of typical for a Belgian, but not too heavy on the clove or banana.  It has a very nice flavor, sweet, but as the description says it has a bit of sour in it that compliments the flavor quite nicely.  I really do enjoy this. it leaves a nice warm feeling in my belly :)

Shared an 11.2 oz bottle with MereLikesBeer. Honestly, nothing more than an average tripel. Classic Belgian notes, with nothing out of place. Tasty stuff, but I expected a little more from this brewer on the first impression. Note- It did fizzy up a bit on the uncapping, which may have added to the overall experience. Either way, not too bad. Cheers!

Pours a deep murky medium dark amber with a frothy white head. Aroma is sweet of spices, some banana, bread, citrus, and yeast. Flavor is some what thick with this bread like feel and taste with some banana, clove/ spices, yeast, citrus, caramel and fruit. The balance of flavors is well done with a sweet and bitter finish to end. Very good tripel, even though i payed 10 dollars for a 1pt 9.4 fl oz bottle and it exploded when I opened it....

St. Bernardus Tripel 8/2/09 (on tap at Blue Palms, 5oz pour.  Color is solid gold, with an ample white head.  Aroma has some lemony zip, with sugar and an estery touch.  Quite nice.  Palate is medium, not particularly light, with prickly carbonation.  Flavor is far less intriguing than the nose:  there is a strong sugary sweet element blended with banana and malt flavors.  Grain and yeast are also quite noticeable.  Good offering, but I prefer Bernardus other stuff.

Straw / slightly amber. Chunks in the drink. An error?  Fine-medium bubble head, retained.

 Not much aroma. Fruity, but not so complex as the Westmalle Triple (from the same tasting).

 Dry walnut like taste. Interesting, but not good.. Much better concealing the alcohol than the Westmalle Triple from the same tasting. Then again the Westmalle was 9.5% ABV.

Nothing special. Chunks in beer to me is gross, hence the low rating.

 Purchased in SuperBrugsen.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2010 33cl bottle into Trappist glass. A hazy  orangey-yellow beer with a large dense foamy white head and nice lacing. Aromas of golden malts, yeasts and soft citrussy hops. The taste is fruity bittersweet malts with a gentle spiciness (a hint of coriander in there) and an alcoholic presence. Medium-full bodied with a rich mouthfeel. I find it quite bitter for the style unlike other comments I have read. Another top quality Belgian Tripel.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2009 A: Poured with a large, white frothy head that diminished to about 1/2-finger size. Body is a nice, dark-golden color that was cloudy, with heavy particles floating around. Good lacing on the sides of the glass.

S: Nice aroma, quite similar to the Watou Tripel, with lots of yeast, citrus, and some hints of alcohol.

T: Very nice flavor of breadiness, citrus, orange, and a light alcohol warmth in the finish. Average duration.

M: Medium-to-full bodied with a creamy texture, and average carbonation... not quite as fizzy as some of the other St. Bernardus beers.

D: A very, very good tripel... not the standout of its class, but definitely near the top, and very drinkable for its ABV.

Pours a murky gold with lots of floating yeast chunks (despite careful pouring).
Aroma shows the typical belgian yeast along with cinnamon, pears, sour dough bread, and candi sugar. Some subtle sweet alcohol noticeable.
Aromas are almost perfectly mirrored in flavour (with the exception of cinnamon). The sweetness is a bit overbearing however.
Im not a fan of the huge carbonation either even if it is part of the style.
This is what a tripel should taste like in my opinion. Nice and smooth with not too much alcohol or citrus. Nicely balanced, good color with great head
Bottle. Great triple, another good beer from St. Bernardus. Flavor is great, a the different complexities fit together well, abv isnt apparent. Aroma is nice will need to have this again.

33cl Bottle. Hazy amber color with a nice head, richly carbonated, , some sediments floating around. Nicesweet malty aroma with spicy notes, some fruit and caramel. Taste is sweet with caramel,fruit, lots of spices and some balancing hops. Quite nice !

2008 bottle opened mid 2009.  Golden color with thin white that laces well.  Lots of still sediment suspended in the glass.  Nose is sweet and yeasty.  Candi sugar, ripe fruit but not as strong as I would have expected.  Taste starts off sweet then the sweetness yields to some alcohol warmth followed bya a slight biscuit/breadiness.  Finish is clean.

Pours yellow and clean, with abundant carbonation.
Estery aroma. 
Nice estery taste, with some alcohol e a little bit of sweetness and bitterness.
A nice tripel.

Pours a hazy yellow with a nice white head. Tons of sediment, lots of carbonation, very little lacing. Odors of lemon, alcohol, honey, and yeast. The taste is sour lemon, yeast, and other sweet fruit and spices. Really good.

33 cl bottle.  Poured golden amber and cloudy with a moderate, long-lasting head.  Light sediment.  Odors of honey, fruit, yeast and booze. Taste is sweet fruit, caramel, and spices.  Substantial mouthfeel and lightly boozy finish. Like liquid bread pudding. Yum.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 Appearance: Orange brown. Hazy, tiny amount of sediments. Lots of white head.
Aroma: Citrus, yeast. Spices.
Taste: Nice fruit. Malt and quite hoppy. Dry. Some alcohol.
Info: 330ml bottle, 7/7-2009, 26/100, 29/300M

Bottle, 33cl. Yellow hazy beer with a nice white and creamy head lasting the whole beer long. The taste is fruity, spicy with some malt and yeastiness also. The taste is also fruity, with a hoppy, bitter taste coming in your mouth ad also some yeast. The aftertaste is light sweet. Refreshing beer, certaintly one of the best in this style!

Pours large white fluffy long lasting white head with excellent lacing. Cidery apples, fresh herbs, and spicy yeastiness in nose. The aroma really makes you wanna drink it all in one sip. Flavor is first sweet and malty with caramell, quickly followed by a spicy and refreshing bitterness, which lightens up the finish and makes the mouth ready for the next sip.

A great brew.
Blonde, pas trop pétillante ni très moussante. Meilleure lorsquelle est un peu plus froide que la température ambiante. Elle offre alors de fortes saveurs de farine asser spéciales.
Cloudy gold pour, very nice aroma youd expect from a Trappist. Large head that lasts a while, Nose is wheat and orAnge, good flavor though the aftertaste is a bit boring
poured cloudy golden with a big fluffy white head that lasted half a beer.  smelled of wheat, oranges, and spice.  tasted about the same with a pretty boring aftertaste.
33cl bottle from Hopduvel in Ghent, Hazy gold yellow beer, strong taste as it should be for a triple, rich flavour with good after-taste,

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2010 ***new comments***
Well, just opened a bottle while listening to the national anthems being sung from Chicago.. That Jim Cornsomething rules. His version of the US anthem is the greatest version of ANY anthem Ive ever heard period. This has a BBD of 24 04 08 - this sucker is OLD! Heavily fruity now and excellent on that front - almost no spices to be found, fruits seem to be a mulled version of very ripe tropical fruits and, dare I say, a faint chocolate???, a bit fruit cakeish as well. Taste? Ill say rather excellent!  No banana that I claimed in the original review which must date back to early 2006, Notable malts, mild yeast and quite fruity. 4 years in the dark and this thing is very very good. Bump from 7474 15

Very hazy and I cant decide between brown, orange or yellow....lets just say weak metamucil...probally from all the sediment i swirled into the glass. Poured out a huge off white head that didnt last really long but has a good surface cover retention throughout. Lots of concrete-like messy lacing and a cloudy film from every swirl. The aroma is very nice and soft, which is probally what wins me over on this tripel. After the pour the smell consisted of a nice soft spice, some mild yeast and a lingering scent that could only remind me of weak rootbeer. That all fades and turns into a fruity aroma - mostly pear, slight spice, some noticable malts and some background dampness. Brew goes down really soft and smooth, meduim bodied and leaves a great aftertaste consisting of sourness, dryness and lingering yeast. The bitterness hits hard like it should and then fades out nicely. I must note at this point that my beer has been in the glass for well over 45 minutes - thanks Aqua Teen Hunger Force for distracting me : . Taste is really good. Seems complex while remaining soft at the same time. Plenty of yeast and mild clovish flavour. Dry mouth!!!! Fruits come around as banana and something else. Somewhat musty, but that seems to me to be tied in with the yeast. Bitterness is really hitting harder now that Im at the bottom of my glass...interesting brew - I keep changing my mind on what kind of score to give this....Im not sure if I am gassy, bloated or if I ate too many McCain Spicy Wedge Superfries.

Thick dark golden color with a lacey head and floaters. Aroma of honey, spices, peaches. Sweet honey flavor with caramel and spice. Very fruity, with a rather thick body. Decent hop in the finish, with molasses-like sweet malts and alcohol heat. Rich, hearty and flavorful. Slightly too sweet for me, but complexity makes up for it.

On tap at the Flying Saucer in KC. Pours a cloudy, yellow orange body with a finger-width, white, quickly dissipating head that leaves lots of soft lacing. Aroma of floral tropical fruits. Mild yeast and banana bread with just a hint of spices. More raisin and caramel comes in as this warms. Flavor is more bready and caramel influenced than the aroma hints at. Very soft. Still has some tropical fruits, but more of a raisin. Finishes with mild caramels, yeast, raisin, toffee cake, and an even mix of banana and tropical citrus. Some soft spices dry this out. Not a lot of aftertaste, just a light fruity cloying malt. Medium bodied and very smooth. Overall, a decent tripel. Mild, complex, and flavorful, but too soft...which makes for a nice body and balance, but pretty average.

dark gold with massive white head. great fruity aroma that becomes a bit more yeasty as it warms. excellent mouthfeel, hardly any sensing of the alcohol. Enjoyable flavor of tart fruit and spice-- like banana great almost, as was mentioned below.

Beer pours a slight cloudy beige, a tinge of orange comes shinning through when the light hits it just right, a quarter inch noisy white head capped off the brew that left behind some nice sticky lacing, there small floaters everywhere in the body. Aroma is apple juice with strong alcohol presence, wheat can be detected but alcohol dominates this sharp smelling beer. Sharp yeast and very noticeable alcohol comprise most of the taste , the alcohol seems way stronger than the 8% thats actually in it. The warmer the brew got the smoother it got and more darker bitter tasting malt flavors came out. The brew is one you cant slam back more of a sipping brew, taste way more harsh then most triples Ive had, it made my stomach feel very warm and I guess was disappointing compared to most of this style.

11.2 ounce bottle from Mission Valley Bevmo (San Diego, CA).  Pours a cloudy light amber color with a big thick white head that has a lot of staying power.  Aroma of yeast, light spice, and some light citrus (lemon/orange).  Tastes of yeast and lightly sweet malts accented by spice and some fruitiness.  Finish is dry and has just a bit of tartness that is quite pleasant.  Not outstanding, but still a very good "standard" tripel.
Poured hazy orangish golden, smooth, and clean, tropical fruits, little yeasty, little spicey, little caramel.

Rating #300. Pours a hazy shade of ice-tea with a big, willowy white head. Aroma of spicy Belgian yeast, rasins, and bread. Taste is . . . hard to pinpoint. Its sweet and spicy, certainly not bad, but kind of bland really. Has a smooth, slightly bitter finish. Mouthfeel is soft with moderate carbonation. Alcohol is very well-hidden. Good beer, its very drinkable, but the taste is too uneventful for me to say that its really enjoyable.

Light golden color. Cloudy with a tinge of grapefruit and a significant head that lasts throughout. The nose is similar to banana bread with some yeastiness and spice apparent. Very smooth entry and transition to a finish that is lemony, with noticeable ripe banana. Some spiciness present along with very little evidence of the high alcohol level. Easy to drink.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2009 Pop the cap and the pour is a dark, complex golden hue that brings a nearly perfect fluffy white head. Carbonation is precise which allows the flavors of a signature yeast, fruits, and various spices. This is just such a good, good beer. A refreshing blend of fruits and yeast that adds up to my favorite Tripel. Mmmm - LC

Pours a slightly cloudy orange-tan, like weak iced tea.  Great stable head, initially about a finger, that retains very nicely and coats the palate.

Aroma of yeast, nutmeg, and citrus.  Initial spicy punch of flavor, followed by a shot of pepper, and finishing with flowery citrus.

bottle, unclear orange/yellow colour, absolutely very nice white head! Smells yeasty, alcohol, fruity. taste: quite fruity, subtile sweet, alcohol. I also taste very nice melons in the aftertaste. Just another great product from st Bernard! I dont know what the best tripel is in the world, but Im sure this would be a good candidate

Enjoyed via 11.2 oz bottle in tulip glass.  Pours a medium yellow to light golden color.  Nice long-lasting white head.  Nose of subtle dark fruits and some spices.  Palate is slightly malty and slightly fruity; a great balance that is difficult to pin down and difficult to find in all but the finest tripels, especially state-side.  Yeast-derived notes remind me a lot of the yeast from Westmalle or Rochefort.  A splendid medium-dry finish ends the drinking experience.  Easily up there with the best tripels Ive had.

Cloudy golden color with a large off-white head.  Nice aroma of sweet oranges and some spice.  Flavor follows the aroma with some wheat and yeast.  Alcohol comes through on the finish.  Overall, a pretty good tripel.

11.2oz bottle (Best before 22 04 11) and served in a tulip.  This tripel poured a hazy golden orange with a thick head of slowly fading off-white foam.  Decent lacing.  The aroma included orange peel, light candi sugar, lemon, honey, and some spicy yeast esters.   The flavor had orange and lemons, light graham cracker, and also some warming alcohol.  Somewhat bland.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and had moderate carbonation.  Pretty average as far as tripels go.  Just okay.
good looking color. shades of gold,orange, and brown. has a pretty good taste, but doesnt have much of an aroma.
pours a cloudy golden amber.  flowery aroma with spice, clove.  medium creamy mouthfeel.

Poured from big bottle.  Aroma of orange, cake and raisin.  Cloudy golden, seafoam head.  Uh oh - 
major sediment floating around in there.  Flavors of orange, angel food cake, banana, spice, 
pepper.  Alcohol in back.  Highly drinkable.  Still, the sediment makes this look like a science 
experiment.  Finished OK, with alcohol more apparent, but I poured the last inch of the bottle into the garden to avoid the sediment.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text:
Thanks to Gypsy19 for this one!
~Pours a hazy golden with lots of carbonation and sediment floating about. Big white head.
~Sweet, wheaty, yeasty, apricot and spice in scent.
~Spicy clove like and yeast flavor.
~Medium creamy feel.
~Good refreshing, enjoyable belgian brew.
Huge head! I like the smell, very beerish. Very simple beer with a combination of pail malt, bitter and dry clean finish. Not bad at all.

Bottle: Cloudy, stable creamy off-white head, deep golden to orangey coloured, leaving a nice lace; deep sweet and fruity nose (oranges, orange-peel) with shades of toasted malt and candy-sugar in the background; very robust sweet-bitter flavour, full bodied: "mouth-filling", creamy MF; oranges again in the finish, followed by a zesty bitterness retronasal. Great, very pleasant..............

Very Pale and light.  Nose has a bunch of sugar, light alcohol, and wintergreen, beautiful tripel flavor profile with a cotton candy fade, somewhat sweet. This is the best tripel I have had to date...excellent...pairs really well with spicy foods

Beautiful golden pour. Fluffy white head yields to a substantial lace cap. Sweet bananna on the nose follows through in the mouth but is artfully balanced by a slight bitterness on the finish. Nice carbonation. Alcohol lends a pleasant warmth, but isnt obnoxious.

bottled 330ml bought in Watou 100 meters from the brewery

app ; medium lasting white head, hazy amber body, visible lively carbonation

aro ; very mature malts collection, of course yeast and orange

tast ; very tangy, at the beggining difficult to determine the taste, strong yeast, is it wheat beer? no , the label does not support this thought, says clearly "Barley malt", some citron notes an the finish, also some alcohol is easy no notice, after all it is 8%, also pepper in palate as one of me predecessors noted, the rest of my opinion in given by the ratings

Bottled. Pours cloudy golden color with a strong white head. Smells of orange and grapefruit with a touch of grass and hops. Flavors are as above with yeast, raisins and clove. It finishes evenly with little alcohol. Decent triple--ill see if it can bottle age over the year.

Pours a cloudy orange/tan with a white creamy head. Yeast chunks floating. Aroma is of biscuits, coriander (always seems to be there), some oranges, and a little spice from the yeast. Not too complex, even after it was allowed to warm. Medium/Full bodied. Very sweet at the front, some tart fruitiness in the finish - I even noticed a bit of vanilla. Nice. Overall, very smooth and easy to drink. The alcohol was well hidden. Solid.

Pours out of the 330ml bottle a hazy golden orange with a white head that has very good retention. Aroma has loads of orange zest, coriander, yeast, spice, and floral notes. Tastes very bright, no alcohol showing at all, and not overly sweet for a triple. Orange, apricot, lemon, bubblegum like yeast, cloves, and coriander. Mouth feel is very nice, and so is this beer. I love this brewery!

75cl corked bottle at home.
caution. if you dont pour quickly youll spill some beer as it rushes out the uncorked bottle.
unckear orange with a large thick that goes messy white head. very nice mild fresh and fruity orangy citrussy aroma, spices. even some wheatbeer notes although i doubt wheat has been used.
flavor is stronger than aroma, a bit sweeter, but down the same lane. orange, citrus, nice balance, some bitterness to match in the end. quite fruity in a very fresh and flowery way.
after writing all this, the beer has started to push up foam again, even though i poured a large 33cll glass from it. quite lively.

Pours hazy tinted yellow color with a booming, frothy white head that leaves good lacing as it dissipates. Very yeasty and spiced malt based aroma. Peachy and apricot flavor with a heavy dose of cloves. Yeast and alcohol are noticeable at the finish. Dry, yet full bodied, very good beer.

11.2 oz bottle from New Beer Distributors, NYC.  Pour a hazy golden yellow orange with good amounts of granulated sediment floaters.  Nice looking white head.  Mouth is peppery, apricot, bready, and cloves.  This beer kicks ass (3.95)

Location: 750 from Gillys March 09


Aroma: Strong fruit and some citrus, flowery hints as well

Appearance: Hazy, golden orange, think foamy white head, lots of movement, really nice looking beer

Flavor: Fruity sharpness, more sweet then sour, malts and yeast

Palate: Full body, strong mouthfeel, lots of carbonated

Overall Impression: 
This was a really solid, well made tripel, with a bold, but somehow well-balanced sweetness.

Date: 20/2/09
Beer info: Bottled in brown 330ml bottle 8.0% abv bb 13 07 11

Sampling Notes:
Served lightly chilled in chalice.
Pours a picturesque hazy orange gold body with a thick, creamy persistant white cap of foam.
Ripe fruits on the nose, apricot and peach come to mind, possibly some pineapple and banana. Bit of rich, sugary maltiness in the mix seems to deliver the message that this is a big beer, citrus, peppery and clovey phenols are lifting with temp rise.
Nice big mouthfeel, creamy with a lively carbonation. Quite a prominant drying mid-palate gives away its hefty abv.
Excellent body of flavour; perfume and peppery spice, stonefruits, bitter orange bringing forth a jolt of citric sharpness. Some malty sweetness in the works, finishing very dry, warming with a lingering clove spice.
Damn well made Tripel. Bit on the dry side, especially on the finish, but the flavour is what makes this beer.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a 2 1/2 finger white pillowy head.  Lots of sediment floating around.  Aroma is yeasty, spices, some citrus in there as well.  Smooth drinking, and full bodied.  Perfect amount of spice in the taste.  Well balanced beer.
Bottle.70cl. sweet aroma, with yeasty piney citrus in there somewhere. another monstrous head on a belgian beer, peach, apricot to mango. Very nice.
A lot floating around in this tripel. Pours a golden yellow and yields a large billowing head. Mild and very balanced.
330ml bottle. Light, cloudy amber with a smooth white head. Softly spicy, yeasty,  lightly bitter, and overall very balanced - no flavors stick out. Bright palate. Overall, drinkable and refreshing.
Bottle at tasting at Keg and Barrell.  Pours an orangish cloudy with a desent head.  smelled of floral and spices.  Very nice creamy mouthfeel.  Enjoyed alot

Nice cider like color pour, with a white bubbly head and a nice cloudiness as expected. Taste and smell is flowers and citrus fruits with malts and yeast appearent. Nice mouthfeel, well balanced taste makes it very enjoyable.
Always a reliant tripel. Robust with grapefruit-like palate and clove-like tones. Light and cloudy but not watery at all. Not too sweet, nice head. Just a little less carbonated than I like.

Aroma has some sour orange and some lightly spicy yeast. Appearance is mostly translucent with some fleckiness and such. Nice fluffy head with some good carbonation. Flavor has some definite yeast spice, with maybe a little vinegar and apple flavors, almost like a sour ale in this respect, but not so sour. Something else, maybe some apricot? Palate is lively and even a little creamy. Certainly a good beer, but maybe tries to do a little too much. The Quadrupel is much better.

Pours cloudy golden-orange with lots of big suspended bits of yeast, thin white head with moderate retention and some lacing. Aroma is estery and spicy but also has distinct notes of hand soap. Flavour is on the bland side, similar to the nose but mercifully without the soap. A relatively long, inoffensive but not terribly interesting finish develops honey and what might be mild citrus. Not bad. Not great. Certainly nothing to write home about.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2012 Feb. 24, 2009 Rating: Pours a slightly dull orange with a thin layer of foam with decent retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is quite unique - very sweet honey and that damp grain aroma that I tasted in the Pater 6... Honey-malt taste, more damp grains, a creamy sweetness, and no hops to speak of. Lingering watery orange-juice finish. Odd. Good carbonation and crisp body. This beer reminds me of honey-stuffed crumpets or english muffins. Grain and honey notes dominate, and an odd creaminess tries to redeem. Unusual.

Jan. 4, 2012 Re-rating: Pours a pale straw yellow. Inviting light funk & honey sweet aroma, light citrus. Honey and damp grains again (oaty) but this time Im digging it. Crisp body, light creaminess, good carbonation. This is unusually pale and light for a tripel, but I do enjoy it.
Bottle.  Strong coloured bronze beer with a strong head.  The aroma is spiced and molasses, and the flavour is dry and spiced.  Overall a nice beer.

Beerish chewy malt smell with some esters in the background.
A murky pale color with an apple juice hue. Minimal white head and action with some sediment suspension.
Sweet caramel taste with some sourness and grapefruit flavors.
Medium/moderate bodied, resinous, slight astringency, and a crisp frizzy carbonation.
Very drinkable its gone now I have to look to see what else might be left.

dirty orange pour, thick frothy white head
aroma of honey, lemon, and tons of yeast
taste is sweet and sour, lemon, apricot,  balanced by some dark dried fruits
finish is mostly yeast
nice texture, not over carbonated, thick and a bit slick on the tongue
very nice beer, though slightly cloying as it warms...a bit dried + more hops might be better

Very hazy orange color with a huge white head which left tons of lacing up the glass.Smells like orange and bananas with yeast and cloves. Very sweet and spicy caramel smell with a little hint of lemon.Taste was full of wheat and fruit.Apple and pear with a great yeast flavor. A little hopp flavor at the end.I loved this beer. VEry well balanced in taste and flavor. Light carbonation and a pleasant aftertaste.

Man I am just not a huge fan of St. Bernardus relative to the whoever has been driving their ratings way up. This tripel is good but not great.  Bottle poured a hazy golden color with a big white head.  Yeasty and malty aroma with sour apple and candi sugar.  Flavor is more of the same, sweet malt and sour fruits, maybe some spices.  This had some similar sour/funky flavor to their Abt 12 that I cant quite put my finger on. Taste is yeasty with some funk and green apple-like flavors.  Smooth palate, medium body.  Its good but not as drinkable as others in the style.

A- Pours an opaque, dirty dark gold hue, 3-fingers of solid creamy head that is completely sustaining, big lacing throughout
S- Nose is a great blend of Belgian yeast and sweet malts, some floral and citrus hops in the background, slight spice and alcohol
T- Initial taste is dominated by sweet malts, fruits, and sugar, yeasts abound, tones of grass, hops, banana, apple, and alcohol, finish is sweet fruits, quite a taste adventure!
M- Light/medium-bodied, creamy texture, very lively carbonation
D- This is a truly great Tripel that embodies all the characteristics of the style, very well balanced and complex, quite drinkable but the 8%abv can sneak up

Pours hazy orange with off white head.
Aroma sweet sugary, with nose of dark fruits and resinous.
Taste is very similar, candi sugar giving the beer a syrupy mouthfeel, some dark fruits , possible apricot and yeast with light notes of citrus.
Bottle. Hazy golden body, with a huge off-white head. Aroma is very fruity, citrus and sweet like hefeweizen. Aroma is also fruity, cirtus. A very good tripel.

750ml bottle.  less complex than i was hoping for, but still a solid triple. golden pour, thick head.  I would prefer more kick in the palate, perhaps with more carbonation.  good beer overall, though.

Cloudy gold pour with some nice floaties. Nice white head. Aroma of honey, citrus, flowers, and mild spice. The flavor is similar, but not quite as sweet. Fruity, somewhat dry. Bread, yeast, cloves. Dry, clean palate. Very nice tripel.

Cloudy orange color with a large white head.  It looks quite nice.  Smells like a really sweet hefeweizen with cloves and hay.  Flavor is pretty malty sweet with some banana/citrus coming through.  Finishes really dry.  Pretty tasty brew.

First rating.
One of the few tripels Ive ever had. Nose was very sweet and citrusy, first half of the bottle poured a hazy yellow, while the second half had sediment floating inside. That Belgian taste was very identifiable; malty fruits and a bit of spice, with some carbonation. Very tasty.
Very nice Tripel.  Not overly sweet.  Aromas of cloves, banana, and orange,  Taste is of medium sweet malt with some citrus notes.  A yeast/doughy character is noted as well.

Pours a very milky honey gold with slightly green accents and a 2 finger creamy beige head that simply never goes away and leaves some of the nicest lacing around. Aroma is earthy citrus, fresh dough yeast, straw, spicy yeast, a little banana and some citrus tanginess. Flavor is grainy malt at first follwed closely by lots of toast and some caramel, then a little lemon. In the middle the toast and caramel remain dominant and more citrus notes move in, with some dark fruit and spicy yeast, which becomes more bread like rather quickly. Finish is grainy, toasty, citrus and spicy yeast. This stuff is what I would imagine a marzen brewed with Belgian yeast would be like-fantastic.

12oz bottle.  Cloudy orange-yellow with a lot of particulate.  A nice frothy two finger head.  Smells citrus, with some sweet fruit underneath, lots of yeast.  Did I mention the yeast?
