Yeah, its there in the taste as well.  its bready citrus.  Nutty.  Much sweeter than I expected.  A nice Tripel!
Heazy golden, medium head, full fruity one with peach, banana, some citrus, not very complex, smood one with gentle sweets.
750 mL bottle at Flat Rock Saloon.  Poured cloudy orange with some patches of lace.  Sweet, fruity, and finishes with a spice.  Pretty much what I expected, solid.

Pours a murky orange-tea hue, with tons of yeasty floaties.  A billowy head ensues, with thick, chunky lace left sticking to the glass.  Yeast, dough and citrus to the nose.  The flavors are extremely well-integrated, with sweet malts, light bitters, various fruits and lots of yeasty dough.  Some banana fills out the doughy finish... an extension of the flavor palate.  The mouthfeel is soft, yet decently carbonated.  A very nice offering here.

Hoppy, sweet and slightly fruity, a delicious Trappist Ale. All is in balance, it is rich, yet dry and lingering in the finish. The hops are prominent up front, yet it is not too bitter in the finish. This beer is a conundrum of sorts, has little complexity in any one aspect, but is an enjoyable ale.

14 karat body produces a fluffy white head.  Aroma is much more earthy than the Westmalle Triple...grassy, yeasty, and with a hint of green apple.  Flavor follows the nose and also adds a slight malty sweetness.  Enjoyable.

750 ml bottle. A very cloudy deep yellow beer with a big, compact and persistent white head. The aroma is quite sweet and on the malt side, though not very powerful nor particularly complex. Decent with some floral and grassy notes from the hops and some coriander. The flavour is better than the aroma, not overly sweet with some spices and a nice hop charachter. Again not the most complex tripel, but rather well balanced. Lightly sour. Medium to full body, lively carbonation, dry and quite long finish with medium bitterness. I expected more, but this is quite good.

Bottle. Light straw note for the malt, light to moderate hop aroma of lemon, moderate barnyard for the yeast with a hint of apple. Head is large, fizzy, slightly off-white with fair lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is murky amber. Flavor starts moderately acidic and a bit sour, then finishes moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, watery and has a fizzy carbonation. All the classic characteristics of an Abbey Tripel.
My first genuine Belgian beer and I didn’t think it was too much better than the American knockoffs I’ve tried.  Not worth $11 for a bottle. (Man, I’m cheap!)
Pours hazy golden with a fairly large white head.  Aroma is malty, spicy and slightly yeasty.  Taste is malty as well, with some really interesting spicy, minty notes.  Good stuff.

Style and Glass: Abbey Tripel; Trappist
ABV, Volume & Calories: 8 % in11.2 fl oz. estimated at 200 C
Purchased at: Canals Lawrenceville for $17.00 as a part of a 4 part gift pack complete with glass.

Aroma: faint, flowery, fruity, and wheaty.

Visuals: simple, beautiful packaging, golden, hazy, thin white staying head, crisp lace.

Taste: less balanced, heavy sweet malts, less hops, focus on sweet, fruity, apples, nutty, salty, peach.

Palate: rich fruity wash, terrycloth, spongey, longer muted finish.

Overall: A very nice dry tripel. Id love to have it again. Quite enjoyable  would pair fantastically with fruit, chocolate, chicken.
originally posted at: <a href="http://beercritic.wordpress.com/"&

Pours pale golden color, thick head.  Aroma of fruit and alcohol.  Some yeast.  Flavor is sweet malt, fruit, alcohol with bitterness at the end.  Tripels aren’t my favorite but this is a good example.

This tripel is a really good one. Lots of flavor mixed in here. It’s more fruity than the other St. Bernardus beers but the alcohol was more noticeable too. Perhaps that’s because I had a nice buzz after a few other Belgian beers. They really sneak up on you! Nevertheless, I will be drinking this one again soon.

Pours honey color with plenty of sediment and a nice white head with plenty of lacing.  Can smell yeast, ripe fruit such as banana or pear.  A lot of different flavors here, starts fruity sweet with malt, ends a touch bitter with spice and rounds out a bit sour.  Tingly mouthfeel, leaves a sticky film behind.  Excellent, well rounded tripel, refreshing and enjoyable.
Pours a dark golden color with a nice fluffy white head. Aroma of yeast, fruit, and spices. Very refreshing taste of mostly fruit, malt, and yeast. Mmm what a good beer.

Honey like color with great white head, aroma of pleasant vanilla yeast and  toffee like sweetness and some less pleasant herbal notes, flavors of strong malt and cream like liquid with alcohole quite noticable finishes with some bitter pleasant taste. A nice triple but I had some better ones before.

Pours murky orange with a fizzy white head. Aroma is of yeast, malt, spice, citrus, and fruit. Taste is of fruit, malt, yeast, and lemon zest. Very light mouthfeel. Nothing spectacular, but tasty and refreshing taste.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2009 Pours chunky amber with a large, one finger off-white head, good lasting lacing.  Aroma of caramel, pear, apple, banana, biscuit, and some floral notes.  Medium body, velvety, crisp.  Delicious fruity flavors, apple, pear, and banana.  Slightly sour.  Well balanced, with lemon and a very slight bitter aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a very cloudy dark amber with a white fluffy head typical of Belgian ales. Lots of bubble and yeast floaties. Faint aroma of yeast, citrus and alcohol. A very pleasant aroma. Very fizzy on the palate with a dry slightly bitter finish. The flavor is leans toward the citris, malt and alcohol. A good Belgian Tripple.

Poured a hazy gold color with long lasting white head. A very still body with many small particles. Smell of apples and sour berries, grassy and floral hops. Beautiful tase of apples and wonderful bitter hops, hint of black olive. Very foamy and full on tebplate, medium finish. Wonderfull! I think I like it more than the 12.

Pours a cloudy, pale straw, with a massive head, and tons of floating yeast.  Some lacing.  Aroma is cider-like, slightly bready and floral.  Flavor is sweet malt, apple, some pepper, with a touch of bitterness.  Palate is too fizzy for my tastes.  Overall its an okay beer, but not on thet top of my Tripel list.

Pours gold into the glass with a nice white head with orange highlights.  Aroma is spicy yeast notes with some fruitiness.  Flavor is nice bready malt with some orange citrus.  Not overly impressed by this tripel compared to the rest of their offerings

Pours a murky orange characteristic of a tripel. Aroma heavy with lemon and orange zest, aggressive spices, and abundant yeast. Flavor is very nice, with an exceptionally smooth combination of yeast and malt complimented by the spice and citrus. Palate is very good, quite drinkable. Very good brew.
Bottle. Unclear golden colour with  white head. Aoma and flavour citurs, yeast and hops.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 750 mL bottle into Orval chalice. Pours a very hazy blond with a nice white cap that quickly fades. Very good lacing. Aroma of floral hops, yeast, bubblegum, white pepper. Taste is bitter and hoppy up front with lots of carbonation. Nicely balanced. Slight warming alcohol in the finish. Crisp, dry aftertaste with some peppery notes.

Nice hazy blonde pour with a big white frothy head.

Aroma is hops, yeasty sweet and citrus.  Taste is bitter, hoppy and a little sour yeast, with a sour/hoppy bitter finish.

This isn’t bad but my least favourite Bernardus beer, I much prefer the Watou Tripel.

Poured into a tulip with aromas of wheat and malts. Lacing head gives the beer a pleasant appearance with its golden body. Initial taste of bananas ended with a refreshing bitterness. Pretty good tripel.
A classic abbey style tripel.  Good bitterness with a flowery aroma and taste.  Maybe some spice to it as well.
Pours gold, with a white head. Aroma is yeast and citrus. Flavor is yeast, spices, and fruit. Crisp, medium body.

Pours a hazy amber with nice lasting head. Aroma is intense citrus and spice. Tons of orange, lemon peel, and clove. Flavor is loaded with citrus and some sweetness. Balance is phenomenal. Palate is silky and full for the style. Excellent.

750ml Bottle: Aroma of flowers, fruit, spices, yeast, grass, coriander, apples, pear, and slight citrus.  Poured golden/amber in color with a huge, rocky, pillowy, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout as well as a few medium-sized ones.  Excellent lacing.  Lightly sweet, light to medium bitter flavor.  Tastes of yeast, fruit, spices, pears, apples, slight vanilla, malts, clove, and coriander.  Medium body.  Tingly, then chalky texture.  Lively carbonation.  Yeasty, fruit-sweet, chalky, dry finish.

Pours a deep hazy orange color with a big fluffy white head. Aroma is very nicely fruity and lightly spicy. Some citrus and banana notes with definite wheat. Flavor starts out with some straight up malt and sugar. Quickly gains a fruitiness that is mainly the banana yeast but with some mild citrus and even some tiny bubble gum notes. Finishes long and sweet but with some nice spices that keep it balanced. Medium body and average carbonation. Nice abbey tripel. Easy to drink and well balanced.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine and More in Tampa. Aroma is very citrusy...quite nice. Color is honey colored. Thick head that dissipates slowly and leaves lacing all the way down the mug. Flavor is fairly mild, with a hint of alcohol. Definately flowery hops...little bit of citrus. Fairly tame on the palate...Overall I like it...very drinkable with pretty good flavor...The damn head never went away...I had to rinse the fizz out of the bottom of the mug...A good beer though. Nice drink.
Nice light yellow color on the pour.  Lively flower/fruit nose.  Flavors of light banana, citrus, yeast.  Bitter sweet, good.
Pours an odd amber/ straw color with a live white head.  Sour aroma with fruit and spice.  Very live.  Lots of carbonation.  Slightly sour flavor with floral and fruity tones.  Quite enjoyable.
Very good. Nice big head gives off a great aroma. Cloudy amber color. Big flavor that hangs on well after you’re done.

Dark, cloudy apple juice color with a large empty bubble foam head that dissipates pretty quick. Aroma of yeast, stone, lime, etc. Heavy carbonation. Flavor is tart, yeasty, hickory, etc. Fizzy on the palate, but in a mild way. Finish is lively and lighter.
Excellent.  Very fruity on the nose and high carbonation gives a great mouthfeel and awesome flavor.  Not usually big on tripels, but this one kicked ass.

From bottle. Pours cloudy dark golden with a  thick white head. Standard tripel aromas of yeast, banana, spices and citrus. 
Flavors include spice, caramel and floral hops.  Very nice.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a thickish quickly deflating head, lovely lacing, color is pale yellow but cloudy...nose is belgian yeast spice, some cardamom, no hop....taste initially of carbonation then mild sweet malts with accompanying banana tones, finishing with mild hop bitterness, sweet and bitter well balanced....mouth feel appropriate to style.

A decent beer, but disappointing when put next to the 12. Has most of the characteristics of the BT, but in subtler terms. Creaminess, wheat, and other vague goodness with perfect carbonation level. Recommended, nevertheless, get the 12 if available, as in my experience it is only about 10% more in price.

Pours a pale hazy yellow with a two finger creamy white head. the nose is earthy, Belgian, musty, sweet, light alcohol, no spice. The flavor earthy, lightly sweet, slightly off tasting, musty, malty, candy, light alcohol. The palate is crisp with a light bite.

The carbonation is in perpetual and random motion in this dark golden cloudy ale, with its thick white head.  The complexity of flavors, sweet, meadows, bitter, even sour, keeps me interested and coming back. A real fine trippel.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2009 330ml bottle (Punavuoren Ahven, Helsinki, Belgian Weeks) - shared by mjs - thanks!
Almond and walnut aroma. Rich amber. Tiny persistent head. Quite vapoury. Lovely soft palate. Loads of fruity esters, but loads of nuts too. Very nice.  Ɩ-4-7-4-14=3.5)
Rerate: Bottle (cracked Kettle, Amsterdam)
Fruitier, some apple-pie pastry feel too. Right balance of malt and hops in the mough and the bitterness is great in the finish. Some almonds and walnut papers there too. Score the same, but it might be an underrate.

(Bottle at Punavuoren Ahven, Helsinki, on 2008-09-20) Golden / orange. Hazy. Large quite quickly disappearing white head. Fruity nose with some almonds and salty liquorice aromas. Full bodied palate with little carbonation. Malts, chocolate, salty liquorice, almond, nuts and bitterness in taste. Malty and slightly bitter aftertaste.

Sampled on draught: Pours a bright, cloudy golden colour with a large white head. Taste is pleasent, slightly yeasty and fruity- pineapple, lemon and grapefruit. Aroma is pleasent also. tropical fruits and clove on the nose.

750 shared with Brie for the kickoff of the Patriots vs. Jets.  There are some "cheese-heads" in the stadium for Favre’s first start at home for the Jets.  The pour is cloudy orange with a long lasting thin white head.  The head stays in my Chimay chalice till the last sip.  The aroma is of bananas, bread, and a hint of that funkity funk that I love.  The mouth feel is smooth and heavy.  The dominating flavors are banana, citrus, pepper, and bread.  The finish is buttery and sweet.  It’s been a while since that last time I have had a beer this complex.  This might be the best triple that I have had, the Gouden Carolus is a close second. (so far)

Bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Poured a clear gold color with a heavy white head.  Aroma of yeast, bananas and spices with some citrus notes as well.  Flavor was very spicy with a familiar Belgian caramel flavor.  Medium-full bodied with average carbonation.  Great beer.

Pours a luminescent blond in my tulip glass with a finely bubbled 2 1/2" thick head and lots of apparent yeast debris. As advertised,  blessed with a harmonious intermingling of  aromatic elements with prominence given to clove then to mild, slightly green banana, a touch of uric acid, and some floral spiciness. Flavor is somewhat a letdown. Characterized by a strong bitter-sour phenolic,overly green, unripe banana, and touch of band-aid. The flavors just dont mesh.

Poured hazy gold/orange with a very thick pillowy head that held up very well and left great lacing. Subtle aromas of yeast, bananas and citrus. Lemony hops bitterness up front, gives way to a slightly sweet toffee and caramel taste. Familiar carmelized sugar that you get with Belgians is evident but not overpowering. Finshes with toasted malts in the background. The smooth and creamy texture is outstanding and might be the highlight of this beer. Great carbonation, full bodied, and the alcohol is barely noticeable. Tremendous.

Bottle gushes slightly but pours a light cloudy golden hue with a small pillow of off white head.  Heavy spice aroma, slightly citrusy, hoppy.  Substantial body and mouthfeel.  Strong spice and alcohol notes up front with grassy middle and moderate carbonation.  Citrus and boozy finish in a fairly short dry hop finish.

Pours cloudy yellow-gold with thick white head that sticks to the glass. Yeasty, citrusy nose with banana and spice. Sweetish yeasty, fruity, bubblegummy flavor at first, ending spicy, dry, and a bit acidic. Rounded, sticky feel on the palate with a carbonation tingle. Tasty and refreshing.

Bottle, Beer Ritz Leeds. Poured darkish slightly hazy gold with a decent white head Aroma was hay, yeast, citrus. Flavour had  a sweetish beginning with spice, fruits and a hint of malt. Dryish finish. Solid.

Nice amber-yellow with a moderate head. Aroma of sugar, big yeast, and bananas. Blast of bubble gum, bananas and bread in the mouth.  A delightful fruity tripel with only minor spice and citrus notes.  Big, thick gummy mouth feel. Wet full bodied ale that’s rather refreshing and leaning to overripe fruit and vanilla.

A refreshing tripel.

Bottle (in NZ), a lively pour, a hazy amber with a large white pillow head. A spicy aroma, ginger and cloves, and sweet yeast. A spicy yeast flavour, quite a bitterness to the palate. I found it a bit uninspiring - but that is probably the result of the trip.

Poured a slightly cloudy golden orange with a thick white head. Sweet aroma of yeast, citrus and other fruity notes I couldn’t quite finger specifically (peaches maybe?). Flavour was quite spicy with yeast and fruit. Spicy finish. I was happy to try this one.

Best Before: 19 07 10.

Appearance: Pours a clear, bright, orangey-gold body topped proudly with an inch of white foam.

Smell: Sweetish, malty nose with hints of spicy hops, fruit-flavored bubblegum, booze, and more candy.

Taste: Sweet pale maltiness with a tiny bit of breadiness to it. Large dose of toffee candy. Drop of lemon extract, a drop of vanilla extract. Spicy, flowery hops with a medium-low bitterness. Splash of bubblegum liqueur with its accompanying alcohol heat. Tiniest bit of sourness rides into the otherwise sweetish finish. After a few sips, a growing taste of black pepper develops.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Sticky mouthfeel. Medium-high, slightly prickly carbonation.

Drinkability: Another very good tripel from the St. Bernard Brewery-err, I mean Brouwerij. Though, for me, when pit side-by-side with the Watou Tripel, I do defer to the Watou.
Bottle. Pours golden with nice white head. Aroma of fruit and yeast. Flavor is deep, sweet, spicy, fruity, yeasty. Gorgeous finish. Excellent tripel.

Golden orange color with white head.  Pleasing aroma with citrus overtones.  Flavor is balanced between sweet as expected with Belgium beers and a bit spicy/sour which was interesting.  Very good tripel overall.

Orange with a firm head. Yeasty aroma full of orange and spices. The initial moutfeel is completely numbed by an aggressive carbonation, that I’m not fond of. The flavours are spicy and sweet along the lines of peach.

Bottle.  Poured a clear, golden color with a nice white head.  I thought it had a slight citrus and spice aroma.  The beer had a medium body, oily texture, very lively carbonation, and an astringent finish.  Interesting flavor with a mixture of sweet, sour, and bitterness.  This is the first tripel I have every had, but I wasn’t impressed.  I do like the continual frothiness, but would not buy this again.
Golden color with a medium-large head.  Aroma has some nice sugary-citrusy essence with a bit of spice.  Flavor is a bit of spicy/sweet/sour sugary goodness that is tough to beat.  A classic tripel
light Orangey pour is hazy, with full white head.  Light malt aroma, fruit, a little peppery.Flavor reflects this, fruity and crisp, finishes with a little spice.

Cloudy Orange, nice dense white head, with lotsa floaties and a vigorous carbonation. Nice aroma - toasty, fruity, with hints of banana and bubble gum. Flavor is also bready at first, with some more fruity flavors mixed in. finishes crisp and a bit peppery.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2011 Pours a hazy orange with a thick white head.  Aroma is yeasty and sweet with fruity notes.Taste is sweet and citrusy, with a sweet yeast finish.  4.2

Re rate:  aroma is sweet malts with dark fruit, bread, banana, and belgian yeast notes.  Palate is thick.  Taste brings the fruitiness forward, finishing a little dry.

Bottle. I’m not a fan of this tripel. All the flavours are nicely balanced, but the dry taste in combination with the mouldy yeast of St.B makes this hard for me to swallow. Lots of fruity flavours and aroma’s, some spices. Dry mouthfeel.

Very sweet and spicy, with a very powerful malty backbone. I really liked that there was that authentic belgian yeastiness but there was also a complimenting sourness and sweetness to chalk up the complexity of this beer. Really very good.

Everything you expect in a Tripel.  Pours a hazy dark orange color.  Thin white head with decent retention and lacing.  Aroma is sweet fruit (cherries) and yeast.  Alcohol is noticeable in the aroma, but less so in the taste.  Flavor is fruity, with some citrus, and  lots of honey and caramel sweetness.  Nice clean finish.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy antique gold with a moderate white head that faded to an uneven film after about two-thirds of the glass and left a coating of  foam after each sip.  Surprisingly light aroma with a few whiffs of malt, yeast and some fruit.  Much more flavorful than the aroma suggests with rich malt, caramel, fruit and yeast.  Lovely, light silky mouthfeel.  No hint of the 8% abv.  Very nice!

pours a semi-hazy yellow-orange with a large white foamy head.
smell is of sweet fruit, some citrus, yeast, few spices.
taste is over carbonated, peach, pear, spice, pepper, ends is bitter and dry.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, cloudy, good head, good brew, balanced
Bottle, pours a white long lasting head with a big lacing.  aroma is sweet like bananas, color is dark golden.  citrus honey sweet.  Pretty good i would drink this again!

Bottled: Pours a thin fine white head with a cloudy orange color. The smell of this beer was great with its full aroma of bananas balanced well with malt and other fruit. Taste very fruity with a bitter bite on the end. Good!

Quickly dissipating head, which leaves an oily looking lacing. Hazy, unfiltered orange color. Really carbonated appearance at first, but that changes as the carbonation starts to fizz out. Powerfull fruity aroma. Champagne-like... quite tart. Citrusy taste. Rather sweet. Grape taste in there, which makes you think you are drinking champagne if you don’t look at the beer too closely. Some syrupy taste in there as well. Not as dry as other tripels.
bottle.  golden color with fluffy white head. smells nice with citrus and yeast.  starts sweet and a little fruity, then some spice and bitterness.

just want to say thanks to mr.moneyman for my two bottles, much appreciated ... interesting brew ... some honey and belgian honeycomb blocks of caramel .... is a tasty little morsel ... never wear sunglasses at night.. would have to say this is a very mellow trippel, maybe to much for some...

Bottle. Poured a coppery-amber color with a moderate white head that produced nice lacing. Smelled of raisins and a earthy wheat/yeast aroma. The taste was an interesting combination of the bitterness in the hops and the sweet raisin and fruity malt. Masked the high 8% alcohol content maybe a bit too well..... My favorite St. Bernardus Brew!
dark yellow/orange with an aggressive white head. good mix of spices and yeast in the nose and a taste to match, clean and good.

Light lemon aroma, fresh pear, apple, sour yeast, wheat.  Perfumey floral sweetness.

Wheats up front, earthy sourness builds thru mid, along with some yeast.  Light sweet lemon peel and a hint of spice. The belgian funk and alchohol are subdued, very tasty.  

Killer silky texture on the rough + dry palate.

Such a good Trip, very restrained and well balanced.

The beer pours a hazy yellow orange with a thick white head. The nose is a rich mix of spice yeast citrus and malts. The taste is slightly less then what the nose lead me to believe but it is still very good; a clean mix of yeast and citrus with light notes of coriander and peppercorn. The finish is slightly sour but very nice.

Bottle at de Boom in Alkmaar. Very decent tripel. Nice golden color, decent head. Aroma is hard to describe. Tastes like citrus, not much like banana, dry aftertaste. Also very balanced, the alcoholic taste is hidden perfectly.

Great, great Tripel. I actually think I prefer this over the St. Bernardus quad, it’s so drinkable and smooth. I get a hint of sugar and fruit as the predominate aroma. Pours an astonishing gold color which is fairly opaque, with a large standing head. Love the malt/yeast dominance  in the taste with hints of citrus and a pleasant spice, which make it tremendously smooth and balanced.

Bottle at Benny.
Hazy, golden with a large white head, beautiful lacings. Aroma moderate/heavy malty (caramel, light fruits), moderate hoppy. Flavor moderate sweet and bitter. Medium body.

Slightly orange and just a little hazy with a huge rocky head. Nice aroma of caramel, esters and some light spice, typical of a tripel but neither very powerful nor complex. The flavour is sweet, caramel malt and lot of  lemon on its soft but lingering finish.  A nice gentle beer.

Bottle thanks to 1_2many.  While Im not a huge fan of the Tripel style beers, this one is pretty good, better than many Ive tried.  It has the standard yeasty aroma and flavor.  Nice carbonation as with all Bernardus beers.

Not too bad for a Bernardus but didnt meet my expectations.  Hazy golden with a sweet yeast flavor and aroma.  Smooth but not mind blowing.  Would have rather spent my money on the 12 but you gotta try everything right?
UPDATED: OCT 31, 2008 Golden orange color with a nice white head.  Citrus taste, definitely orange.  Really smooth.  Great beer!

Bottle 75 cl. Huge fluffy white head on a golden and moisty body. The nose has hints of vanilla, orange-peel and citrus. A thick and heavy palate with a dry aftertaste. Taste: yeast and citrus-fruits with a clear sense of alcohol. Not the best tripple in the hood...but not the worse either.
Bottle. Pours hazy gold with a white head. Lightly sweet aroma with dough, yeast and banana. Medium, crisp body. Flavor is rather light, with a general fruit sweetness and yeast. Not very impressive.

Very pale straw color, hazy,  with a HUGE white head. Complex aroma of sweet malt, a little dough, some spice and slight funk, and some fruit-banana and lemon. The mouthfeel is so thick and heavy, mouth-coating. I always love the messing with the mind of a beer so pale in color but heavy in alcohol% and gravity. The flavor is pure citrus. It isnt as spicy as some Tripels that I have had, but very solid indeed. There is a little spice in the finish, moreso than initially. My only gripe is that I would like to have a little drier finish.

75cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a clear dark yellow with a thick, white head that lingers. Aroma is citrus, malt, yeast, and faint notes of alcohol. This beer seems to be strongly carbonated. Flavor is also somewhat citrusy, with predominate notes of orange and faint hints of lemon. Medium-bodied ale with a smooth, somewhat lingering finish.

very good tripel, nice golden orange color with a fluffy white head, strong yeast smell with plenty of citrus, the flavor is nicely balanced with the alcohol content, i pick up mostly oranges with the flavor. This is a great tripel one of the best ive had at least.

hazy gold pour with a medium sized off white head.  Aroma is strong fruit esters,  mostly pear and orange.  Flavor is pear,  flower,  orange,  pear,  all sorts of belgian yeast,  and a bit of funk.  Very fresh tasting.  Finishes lightly sweet with a bit of bitterness to round it all out.
Bottle @  Maria tasting. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is sweet, citrus, orange, yeast. Flavour is sweet, citrus, orange, yeast, fruit, malt. Nice belgian tripel.

Bottle, thx to fonefan. It pours a lot of floaters, else it is a clear golden beer, topped by a white head. Cellarish aroma, fruity and citrusy, some apple, and pale malt. Rather ordinary actually. Its fruity and a bit sweet in the mouth, rather bitter, with pale malt and citrus. Nice level of carbonation, and it finishes fruity and bitter. A nice tripel, but not world class, it lacks a bit on the aroma, and overall the beer fails to stand out. (080412)
in my opinion the best tripel i have tasted nice big soapy head very yeasty aroma light complex flavors with a little bit of complexities well balanced

Bottle, thanks sparky27.  Pours a nice cloudy organe color with a big bubbed white head.  Aromas of tripical fruit,sweet citrus, sweet bread, yeast.  Flavor is sticky and yummy.  Rich mouthfeel with some high carbonation.  Good beer.

Bottle from Rivers Bend.  Poured hazy orange color with a huge frothy head that lasted with excellent lacing. Complex citrus fruit and yeasty aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium fruity balanced flavor with a medium sweet & sour finish of long duration with a small alcohol bite. This is a good beer.

Bottle. Light unclear medium orange color with a large, frothy, good lacing, fully lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, fruity, citrus, light caramel, moderate yeasty, light toffee and alcohol. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. (160408)

A very fine brew!  The aroma was nice, with a banana smell, some sweet fruits, and some medium-sweet malt.  It had a golden-light brown body, with a nice finger thick head.  The flavor was very nice, with a nice balance of mild-sweet fruit, yeast, and mild malts.  It was extremely smooth.  A fine delight.

Draft at the Great Lost Bear in Portland - Poured a hazy orange-amber in color with a small white head that faded to a thin rim around the glass.  Aroma is of flowery hops  with lots of yeast and fruity esters.  Flavor is also much of bready yeast, caramel, lots of fruit (citrus, apple?) and a nice hint of pepper at the end.  A very good beer!
330 ml bottle. hazy orange colour. BIG white head. nice fruity taste. alcohol is just there,

Opaque dirty blonde body with a lot of suspended yeast.  Cream colored head that has good retention.  Floral, fruity, hoppy aroma.  Delicious fruit flavors finish each sip but yeast and sweet malt are the mainstays.   Pepper appears late.   Alcohol is tasted it is more felt via warming.  Good effervescence and mild bitterness.  There are few tripels better than this one.
wonderful tripel, between the 8% ABV and the delicoius taste of fruits, malts, and nuts, this was a great tripel.  Very well made and very fun to drink.

Pours a cloudy sunburst golden with a medium frothy fine white foam on top.  Sweet fruity, nutty aroma malty aroma.  Sweet fruity Belgian flavor with some light nuttiness. Pepper and lots of alcohol in the finish.  Light, very fluffy body, with some better than average, but not stellar, carbonation.  As far as Tripels go this is a good one... and I really dont like Tripels =)

Interesting Tripel.  11.2 oz bottle from Total Wine.  It poured a caramel brown color with a nice frothy head with a ton of effervescent carbonation.  The aroma is of light sour fruit with caramel(?) and honey.  The flavor delivers all that with a hint of sour in the finish.  Good stuff.

Sour fruit nose, some honey clove spice present.  Nectary pearl orange-gold color, huge frothy head with great lacing.  Caramel/vanilla/clove spicy syrupy sweetness, great bitter to slight tartness that creates perfect balance.  Tight effervescent carbonation, finish is long and has a nice little burn of alcohol at the very end.  A excellent Tripel.

Alittle hazy golden colored beer, with a nice foamed white head. It has an aroma of fruits, spices like coriander and malts. Its complex. The taste is complex as well. There are fruits, citrus, spicey, with a little bitter in the back. It sparkles in your mouth. A very nice triple.
On draft at Oldsmar Tap House.  A very good tripel.  Pours golden with a nice frothy head.  Flavors are a mix of floral and citrus.
bottle, cloudy golden color with a fast receding head, nice mild nose and bright notes of spice, cloves, and some fruit, very balanced finish

Thin head some mild cover,nice orange colour,aroma is fruit ,citrus,spice.Flavour,malt,nutty,banana very tasty,some sour tastes not over done,clove lime touch,melon notes,an intersting ale really tests the taste buds.At the finish malty full flavoured,some drink.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2008 On tap at Track 84 in Warwick, RI. Pours deep orange/gold with a fluffy white head.  Aroma of yeast, citrus, caramel, and hops.  Taste much the same with strong notes of bread and yeast.  spicy on the finish. Very nice tripel.
Well balanced tripel.  This ranks up there with my favorite tripel Chimay Cinq Cents.  Pours a cloudy pale amber and delivers powerful abv kick.  Bitterness is balanced well.

Like a more complex, more refined version of La Fin du Monde. Pours a light, hazy cider color with a huge, creamy head. Aroma of light, creamy caramel, apples and spices. Flavor is a great blend of sweet fruits and a mild bitterness, with notes of apples and just a bit of the bite of black pepper. It has a great depth, and is extremely drinkable.

Nose is caramel and slightly citrus with a little pepper in the background. Cloudy-golden color and loads of sediment. Lots of lacing from puffy white head. Tastes include pepper and citrus hops, mixed with caramel sweetness and hints of sour apples/apple cider. More pronounced malts with some wheat as it warms. A nice tripel, but little pricey.

750 ml brown, Belgian bottle. Corked and caged. No freshness date, but a cryptic mark on the cork, like a lower case "A".  Loud pop released the cork. Poured out a deep orange / yellow color, with a thick white head. Carbonation is persistant. Aromas are of pineapples, black pepper, funky yeast. Flavors are of peppery yeast, tropical fruits, earthy hops, lots of malts. Thick mouthfeel, but normal body. Tasty beer overall. Alcohol is well hidden, but sneaks up on you.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 First off,  I love the Belgians. Effervescent, tingle of hops. Champagne and fruit. Tasteful and long lasting palate. It sparkles and shines without being too fruity. Plus a drunken monk is on the front of the bottle...Praise  god!

Pours a murky light brown with lots of carbonation. Big, thick, fluffy white head. Sweet fruit aroma with a dash of yeasty breadiness, maybe some caramel. Flavor is sweet and fruity: very rich malt. A big alcohol presence. Lightly dry finish.  Wonderful.

750ml bottle. Poured a cloudy, honey-straw color with a very nice looking white head. Left a ton of lacing on the glass, and the head lasted untill the end. Beautiful beer. Aroma was spicy with some floral character. Lots of spice, refreshing, fruity, dry finish and no alcohol coupled to make it very drinkable and hard to sip slowly. medium, fizzy mouthfeel . Delicious

A- Pours a slightly cloudy tangerine hue with a large eggshell head that slowly fades to tons of lacing.

S- Smell is sweet and deeply reminescent of Belgian yeast. Spicy and funky with light apricot undertones.

T- Taste is a array of blended spices, earthy belgian funk with a dry, tangy finish that leaves you constantly going for another sip.

M- Somewhat light with a good amount of carbonation that dances on the tongue and tickles the throat as it goes down.

D- This is highly drinkable and even though im not a huge Belgian fan this tripel really does it for me. It takes a Belgian yeasty taste that turns me off to quite a few other beers and makes it so enticing its hard to put down.

Poured a bottle into a tulip glass. 

Inch tall head that settled into about a 1/4 inch covering that lasted throughout. Nice lacing. Very nice looking glass of beer. Golden, honey colored. Very tiny, compact carbonation. 

Smelled of yeast, fruits, alcohol. Very well balanced. No particular aroma stood out, but all worked together. 

Delicious, well balanced. Some fruit, some yeast, some hops, some malt, all working together. A very balanced beer on a par with Westmalle Tripel. 

I noticed a lot of carbonation that made my tongue tingle a bit, otherwise Id give it a 5 on mouthfeel. Warmed the palate after it went down. Slight bitter and alcoholic aftertaste that warmed and then left the palate quickly. 

Very drinkable, but tasted strong with the alcohol not as well hidden as the Westmalle. But an excellent, delicious beer. And my wife says I look like the monk on the label!
Light leather-brown, average head. Pleasant doughy, light banana, nutty (almond) and leather aroma. Lightly malty, honey flavor with light tartness.
Pale golden of color with a nice white head. An aroma of sweets, spice, aplles and fruit. A flavor of honey, spice, sweets and a oily texture.

Golden honey color, fairly cloudy with a white, white head and sediment suspension.  Sour, spicy citrus aroma like one of those christmas russian teas, but much fainter.  Very nice flavor, bright citrus, but smooth feel. Slightly metallic aftertaste.

Had this a few weeks ago, been sitting on my haves list all this time. Pours hazy gold with a medium head. Aroma is citrus. Flavor is coriander spice with some fruit and citrus. There are also some slightly yeasty notes and a nice spicy finish.
Pours a nice hazy golden color, thick head which mostly dissipates fairly quickly.  A little spicy, sour, and fruity.  A little tart for my taste but very good.
Poured a cloudy amber, with the aroma of fruits and bread. The flavor was fruity, mostly citrus. A very nice beer!

Tasted 4/5/08.  330ml bottle.  Hazy golden hue.  Honey and roasted bready aromas.  Full bodied and astringent.  Flavors of apples and fruit.  Tight effervescence.  More of a citrus note than the Watou.  This took the bronze in our small Triple tasting.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a white head. Fruity aromas of bananas, citrus and dough. Flavor is sweet with hints of fruits and spices. Medium body with prickly carbonation and a slighly bitter finish. Decent tripel.

Bottle, bought @ Magasin, Cph.
[vintage 2005]
Pours a hazy coppery amber with a frothy white head. It settles a bit, gets denser and more creamy. Streams of big bubbles reach lazily for the foam. Aroma is pleasantly sweet with a heavy dose of yeast. Lots of oranges peep through. Some overripe apple notes. Wonderful creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is truly magnificent. Quite sweet with a very slight fruity tartness. The apples appear again mixed with tartish oranges. Yeast dominate the finish with a nice warming sensation.

05/04  @ Hopdevil. Zagreb. 0.33 l bottle which poured murky golden orange body with medium to bigger white head. Lot of things in its nice aroma, fruity orange, lemon and pear in combination with banana like yeast. Also a bit dusty and some leather, but not really in a bad way.  Flavor nice as well, but not exactly as aroma, bittersweet with fruits mentioned. Alcohol can be hinted. Finish is nice bittersweet gradually turning into sweeter. All in all, nice tripel.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2008 Pours a hazy golden color.  You could call it tan, brown, orange, yellow, golden, flat out murky and I dont think any answer is wrong.  Very thick foamy head that leaves a lot of lacing on the glass.  Subtle hints of fruit spice and yeast in the aroma but nothing thatll just jump out at you.  A very nice blend of citrus, spice, malt with a nice little alcohol presence in the flavor.  A little tang and tart in the finish and aftertaste which is surely a sign of the alcohol content.  I like it.

Poured a nice golden blonde  hue with a frothy white head  which had great lacing and retention.  Aroma was fruity mainly banana notes, some yeast notes.  Flavor was similar, nothing spectacular or unique.   Carbonation was present on the palate, other wise palate was mediocre.

From a 750ml bottle - first glass smelled skunky, was only slightly cloudy, nice visible carbonation and fantastic fluffy head which left behind generous amounts of lace. Taste was a bit skunky and bitter as well. 2nd glass, consumed the following day, mellowed out, skunky smell was replaced by some spiciness, and the taste wasnt as skunky or bitter. Since I poured the sediment in as well this time, the beer was an extremely cloudy yellow. The head was not as impressive, possible due to lost carbonation. A decent beer, but due to the initial skunky experience and secondary average experience I give this a score just above average.

11.2oz bottle, poured gold/amber color with very frothy white head.  Head was mostly lasting and left good lacing.  Aroma was very malty, with hints of flowers and sweet fruit (grapes, apples, pears).  Taste was moderately sweet, body was medium/full, murky, and fizzy.  Delicious beer!

33cl bottle.   Gushed out a hazy amber orange color with a lasting fluffy head.   Plenty of sediment suspended.   Sweet nectary aroma, real fruity, slightly tart, dusty dough, and some pepper.   tastes like orange marmalade and apricots.   Really candy-like, but the tartness pulls the sweetness in a little, though it remains quite sweet and fruity throughout.  The body is a little sticky and sugary, but feels smooth on the tongue.   About middle of the road thickness.   Good stuff, but tripels never really leave me fully satisfied.

a tad dark for a tripel, typical of st. bernardus. also expected is the dark frutiness that does well to cover their often strong. nice bit of belgian spice and murky yeast makes this a unique tripel and another great st. bernardus.

330 mL bottle poured into a Rochefort goblet. Hazy dark gold-orange color with a finger of tan head. Retention is fantastic and the lacing covers the glass.

Smells very estery, with a touch of spice and a touch of booze.

Taste is classic tripel. Overripe fleshy fruits and a big dose of yeast and dough are balanced perfectly, accented by peppery alcohol and herbal spiciness.

Mouthfeel is delicate but not too thin. Great complexity while remaining drinkable.

1 pt 9.4oz 
Sweet yet bitter scent. Not quite what I was expecting of a Tripel of this brewery yet still quite enjoyable.

Pours a pretty medium amber with a little haze. Tall and frothy white head. Nice mix of citrus, caramel, and yeast in the aroma, even a little sour. Delicious sweet, and citrusy flavor with touches of creamy florals/spices which changes into a fizzy and somewhat sour body that fades out with a slightly bitter finish. Very smooth drink with a ton of complexities.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2008 St. Bernardus Tripel is a very attractive ale. The color is a hazy yellow while the head is a perfect off-white. The aroma is full of yeast, malt and the spices that I associate with a wit beer. The flavor is very smooth and easy to drink. This is a clean, yet full bodied ale.

Courtesy of Naka.  Pours a mostly clear gold with a nice white head. Wheaty (I know thats not a real word) and spicy aroma with clove and sweet orange hints. Incredibly complex taste - different flavors developing with each sip. Fruity (grapes and lemons) with over the top sweetness. Finishes very wheaty (again, I know, not a word) with spicy and banana overtones. Bubbly and lively mouthfeel. A freaking classic, and one of my favorite Tripels.

750ml Bottle. Poured a light gold with a small fizzy head. Found it spicy, with hints of apricot, and more sour than other triples Ive tried. Good carbonation. A nice beer, but I wouldnt rate it at the level of their Abt 12.

aroma of ripe red apple, balanced by some sweet malt and some dust.  taste is malty and fruity; notes of red apple, champagne, & dry flowers.  mouthfeel is bubbly and frothy, with a fairly light body.  dry finish, a bit phllegmy with a light sweet-yet-bitter malt coating on the palate.  very nicely balanced, some complexity yet still simple enough to enjoy without too much thought.  really does have a nice sweet/sour balance.  a very nice brew, an excellent tripel.  some might call it a bit light and the flavor a bit subdued, but i think that adds to the gentle character of the brew.
Pours golden with a decent head. Aromas are banana, coriander, and citrus. Tastes are the same.

3/15/08 - 350 ml shared with Naka and santoslhalper.  Christmas BeerClub haul, courtesy of Naka.  Pours yellow-gold with white head.  Nose is citrus and spice, orange.  Taste is malty with peach, orange, and banana, some spice, but not overpowering.  This is good stuff.  very balanced.

Shared w/ Juart and Santoslhalper.  Pours a hazy golden apple juice color with a small white head which dissipates quickly.  A beautiful nose of apples, grape, yeast and alcohol.  A pretty caramely flavor with the apples and spritzy carbonation mingling nicely.  Some fruity esters and a bit of a dry finish round this out nicely.  The carbonation and texture combine to make a nice creamy mouthfeel.

From 33cl bottle, best before 10/10. Golden hazy body with a large foamy head leaving a medium lacing. Banana, bitter orange peel, clove, vanilla and malts in the nose. In mouth it has a light sweet start that explodes in a wonderful mix of spices and fruits. A light bitterness at the end enhances this great mix and adds complexity. Medium body and light carbonation give character to the brew and power the flavors. A great tripel!

750 bottle corked and caged poured into a trappist glass has a golden color and loads of yeasty sediment from the bottom. the head is a thick two finger that left a heavy layer with great retention. aroma has champagne yeast, lemon peel, flowers, banana, spice, and grain. mouth feel is lighter with frothy carbonation. flavors are well blended yeast, grain, malt, spice, and sweetness. has a good yeast and spice snap along with the alcohol. a little touch of apples and a finish going dry with spice and very light bitter. definitely a nice tripel, perhaps the best i have tried.
Big bottle pours rich and golden with billows of white foam. Sweet bready aroma. Striking accomplishment in balance and style. Its a Tripel. Beautiful and delicious.
11oz bottle from BevMo Carmel Mountain.  Pours a deeper golden yellow with a nice head. Aroma is kid of sweet and yeasty and flavor is sweet and the alcohol was smooth and not over powering

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 Pours hazy dark yellow with thick crown of head. Aromatically sweet with banana and other witbier-like scents as well as a grain and hop purity. Sweet but finishes very clean. Floral, a little fruity, super juicy, and just a nice, easy going, light (not interpreted by me as thin) tripel.  re-rate from draught, LeBon. Clear golden, small white head. Complex resinous aroma and dry resinous body. Soft mouthfeel. Some vodka-like elements but smooth and quaffable.
Golden, slightly cloudy pour with generous frothy head and good lacing.  Aroma of yeast/bread and banana spices.  Full taste with a really great finish.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 A delightful beer.  This one was poured a bit too cold which was unfortunate--cut the aroma a bit, but was still nice and yeasty.  The flavor was sweet malt, herbal with a bready yeasty finish.  Pours a hazy gold with a fabulous rocky white head.  Very drinkable!

Zhytos beerfest. On tap.
Wanted a grottenbier, but they had none and tried this instead.
Appears hazy blond.
Herbs, fruits, yeast in the nose.
Spicy mouthfeel.
Mildly bitter and sweet aftertaste.

750ml bottle; cloudy amber-gold with a huge off-white head that laces as it recedes; nose of yeast, very light tartness,spices, cidery overripe apple notes, and a vanilla hint that appreared last; flavor is lightly funky, peppery spices, yeast, and fruity caramel. Darn good stuff! A nice lightly funky tripel!

Sharp, white head which subsides almost immediately.  Doughy, almost apple cider aroma.  lots of sediment!  Carbonation and sourness at first, followed by many flavors.  Green apple, yeast, and spice (im not thinking hops).  An exciting beer to taste - due, in part, to all the different flavors.

750 mL bottle. Pours a clear golden yellow, with a large, thick head that dissolves in a few minutes. Aroma is very bright, with citrus, dried pineapple, spicy hops, and yeast. Flavor tracks the aroma fairly well, with a nice balance between sweet malt, bready yeast, and acidic fruit. The finish is spicy, hoppy, and dry. Very nice.

Amazing nose.. sweet candy, citrus fruits and heavy yeast. Unfiltered, golden color, white head. Well carbonated. Flavor is very spiced, lightly fruity.

Let this one settle for a minute so the heavy carbonation can subside.
Very nice tripel, nice white head, sweet aroma with spice. Flavor is nice as well, spicey, sweet and smooth. I love this brewerys stuff.
Poured with a nice white head. Initially very yeasty but opened up after a few minutes.  Nice carmel sweetness.  Less fruit and spice tones than the ABT 12 but still very good.

This amber ale poured with a decent beige head and  a sweet malty aroma. The flavor is caramel malt with a carbonated mouthfeel and a candy sugar finish. Very much up to the standards of this great brewery.

Quite good and very easy to drink.  Aroma is of malt, lemon, yeast, and alcohol.  Pours a clear golden color with a frothy white head.  Flavor is of light caramel, very sweet, with a little lemon, slight alcohol presence, and a tiny bit spicy.

1 pt. 9.4 oz. bottle, caged and corked.

Clear pale amber with a rocky white head, good lacing. Has a peppery, spicy, yeasty smell. Super smooth foamy mouthfeel with a medium body. Lots to taste here with black pepper, salt, spicy, earthy yeast and dusty pale malts. Finishes on the dry side. 750ml bottle.012406
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bouteille de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée avec MartinT, Rastacouere, Cathschlag et Beerbuzzmontreal. Arôme: Odeur dépices avec une pointe de banane et de poire. Apparence: La couleur est orange voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dagrumes et dépices avec une pointe de pêche. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence dépices en arrière goût. (Rating #1455)

Light orange with yellow and red tinge.  A little hazy with tiny sediment dots.  Good head.  Nice honey, apple, caramel, toasty, and yeast aroma.  Mild spicyness on taste and finish.  Only a hint of alcohol.  Soft and light palate leaving a quickly dissolving light honey coating on the tongue.  Not just ompletely unoffensive but sublimely pleasant.

11.2 oz. bottle... pours a deep golden with a thick white head.  some citrus and spicy aromas, but not as pronounced as I would like in a Tripel.  nice medium body that seems to be quite even over the palate.  full of citrus fruit flavors.  overall a very good Belgian Tripel... but not one of my favorites.  I was expecting a bit more out of this beer.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a very urky orange with a large, go figure, foamy white head that disipates but leaves a nice slick of white floating on top of the orange liquid that lies beneath. Tropical fruit, bananan and pineapple mostly, dominate the aroma with some yeasty notes and a slight touch of raisin. Medium bodied with very lively stingy carbonation and a slight metallic aftertaste. Flavor of bread, yeast, slight pepper and orange. The guy on the bottle is probably smiling because hes wasted.

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel" tasting.  Slightly hazy pale orange with thick off-white head.  Spicey aroma with a wierd tortilla smell, very light.  Flavor is dough, orange, yeast, subdued alc.  Sharp carbonation with medium body.  A very standard and subdued tripel that might be a little too old.

Bottle at 3-små rum: Hazy golden colour, with creamy head. Aroma is typical belgium beer with lots of yeasty/fruity/flowery nose. Flavor is almost the same, with typical wheety mouth feeling. Nice medium body, and a medium fruity finish. Nice beer endeed.

Poured a light amber, nice and gold. Small head that quickly went down. Sweet aroma of apples and pears and alcohol...taste of light carbonation and nice and sweet- fills the palate but is smooth as well. Dry mouth after the sweetness- good balance. A very enjoyable tripel.

Deep golden in color with a tinge of red this poured a very fine thick head that slowly dissipated.  The nose was filled with banana, spice, yeast and mineral.  In the mouth this is medium-bodied very well-balanced with an enticing mouthfeel that has some richness but is also silky soft.  The flavors follow the nose which makes this both a nice beer for the summer, due to the flavors, and the winter with the density.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2013 Cloudy gold; nice lingering head.  Sweet malt and powder sugar aroma and flavor, plus slight white pepper and citrus.  Overall a beautiful balance.  Ive enjoyed dozens of big and small bottles and many glasses on tap.  A world class tripel.  Years ago I had a blind tasting of 24 tripel-like beers and this was voted in the top 3 by the 9 tasters.
REVIEW Oct 4, 2013 - Im having a bottle dated best before 06-08-10, so probably from 2007.  There are some floaties at the bottom, but damn...Im going to have to up my ratings... near perfect in this style which Ill admit triples are one of my favorite styles outside the big hoppy world of beers.  And, this particular beer would be a strong contender with desert island top 10.  
Ill admit I represented this brewery in California in 2007 and had all the styles many times.  And Ill admit I enjoy this as much as the wonderful Abt 12.  Its similar to how I admire the Westvleteren 8 as much if not more than the 12.  St Bernardus rocks, even after many years of aging its a lovely brew...praise the yeast...ayiee!!!
bottle.  tried it out of a St. Bernardus verity pack.  very light in color, cant remember the head situation.  sour and tart, with a presense of yeast

11.2 oz. bottle into generic goblet. Cloudy copper with a medium head that quickly fades. Tart cider and vinous notes in the nose. Initially sweet and then sharp on the tongue. Plenty of apple and pear flavors and sweetness that is countered by just enough of a sour note and bitterness to keep things interesting. The mouthfeel softens later but remains tart and dry, unlike other tripels where the sweetness builds and takes over. A great tripel.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 Very pronounced yeast and tangy nose. Pours a light amber with a bit of opacity, little sediment. This beer has a very pronounced flavor that follows the aroma, with a generous taste of yeast followed by sour apple, green grapes, and hints of citrus. A very clean finish that lingers in the mouth. A unique taste that presents a pleasant alternative to some of the other abbey/trappist beers, but not my absolute favourite.

Pours a funky yellow with a hint of green (?) in it. Tight bubbled head disappates quickly. Nose is tart and yeasty. Flavor is much more balanced, with a sweetness showing through, followed by a citrus tartness and a malt finish.

Pretty much like the others say: a very nice tripel. Very well balanced!

Too much to add, too little to say :)

Pours a deep amber color with a thick bubbly white head that slowly faded away. It smelled of sweet citrus fruit, some malts, floral and spices. The flavor was much the same with citrus fruit and spices coming through mostly. There was a touch of candy sugar that left a hint of sweetness, but not as sweet as I was hoping for. Medium bodied with just the right amount of carbonation that finished with a little tartness. A very solid tripel.
Bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy amber color.  White frothy head.  Aroma is slightly sweet, with notes of fruits and a touch of spice.  Relatively light, at least for 8 percent.
corked bottle...poured a nice pillowy head...good lacing...subtle litchi, citrus flavor...sharp, carbonated palate...similar to Gouden Carolus Tripel, with less coriander
Pours a pale amber, with a medium frothy head.  Aroma of fruit and spices, with some alcohol.  Taste is good, but not great.  Sour notes and alcohol were too lasting.  Still a very solid beer.

750ml bottle.  pale orange color with big soft pillow of a head that lasts forever.  very nicely carbonated.  lighter feel that some tripels, but very nice.  it reminds me of another belgian tripel, but i cant figure out which one.  guess ill have to drink a bunch of them to remember.

11.2 oz bottle.  Amber orange hue.  Not as frothy of a head as other tripels.  Weiss-like aroma with dried fruit, citrus, and pronounced alcohol.  Biting carbonation, touch of grapefruit (sour and bitter), boozy.  This one was hard for me to rate- no single component of the beer stood out.  Enjoyable.
Amber with large head. Yeasty aroma with orange peel and spices. Flavor is sweet with fruity notes and a dry end.

Fizzy apple cider appearance and aroma.  Poured from 11.2oz bottle.  Soft and flavorful, hints of apple and pear.  Slightly metallic aftertaste.  Sticky, lasting layer of thin foam.  An enjoyable tripel.
Cloudy amber under a frothy white head.  Strong banana and clove aroma.  Light body, light alcohol detected, smooth and dry with a high carb fizzy finish.  Good but not a lot of depth.

Amber with a moderate head and good lace. The aroma is fruity and the mouthfeel is round and smooth. The flavour is sweet with notes of fruit, fermented apple and plum. Towards the finish it has a light bitterness and a citric acidity, that last all the way through the finish.
Bottle: This beer tasted like what I expect a mixture of apple juice and vodka to taste like.  Not good at all.

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel".  Pours clear orange/amber wiht a creamy smooth head.  Aroma of caramel, grains, and malt.  Grains, caramels, toffee flavors.  Too grainy and fizzy.  Blah.

excellent 330ml.  goldenish with a hint of straw.  big foamy over-the-top white head.  aromas and flavors slightly mirror each other with intense lime, citrus, and ripe vine fruits as well.  the taste is candied-esque with just enough tart fruit to balance the two.  lengthy finish.  excellent tripel, as to where most are too dry.

12 oz bottle poured hazy orange little white head that turns to some lace. Belgium yeast, fruit and malt aroma, clean mouth feel some light carbonation. The taste on this one is lightly sweet malty fruity start slightly hoppy bitter finish.
Flaske. Yderst delikat trippel, der er let og luftig. Minder en smule om en wibier i brugen af gær, men virkelig en af de gode trippels.

(New Years Eve tasting Flight (3 of 4) Orange color leaning towards yellowish straw. Nice white frothy head which collapses very quickly. Cloudy. Aroma of yeast clearly present. Plenty of alcohol in the flavor with a touch of residual sweetness in the end. Warming sensation is not really there compared to the 6 and 8 beers. Bitterness in the aftertaste. Frankly a bit more bitter than I would like in a Belgian beer. Just not digging this beer like the 8.

Aroma has an almost wine like quality with a nice fruity yeast scent.  Color is a deep gold with a slight haze and very good carbonation that produces a nice tight white head.  Taste is light and fruity.  Starting with a light/medium body it goes down smooth with a crisp feel.  Finish comes in sweet with a fruity yeast flavor that has a citrus banana taste in it and just a hint of coriander, then it turns a little bitter and ends with a sour nip at the end.  After taste is dry with the sour fading out to a mild bitterness.  It has that wonderful Belgian yeast flavor that most brews from Belgium have but this one is different.  Although it has the fruity flavor it seems to have a little more of the characteristics of a White then others I have had and this gives it an interesting sour note not found in most Tripels.  Overall I think its an amazing brew, its not as good as there Abt 12, but still a very good Belgian brew.

Pours out looking like lemon juice, light golden and hazy forming a good size white foamy head.  Aroma of cloves, hop flowers, citrus, yeast and vanilla.  Flavour is of vanilla malts and yeast, somewhat biscuity.  Taste of flowers comes to mind.....would love to visit this brewery....this is not my fave style,  however these Belgium friends can make awesome beer!  Would love to try on cask/tap.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel". pours clear golden w/ white head. nose of vanilla, yeasty, mild fruit. flavor is grainy, yeasty, mild citrus and plum fruit. fizzy carbonation. sharp going doing. alcohol warmth. surprised this did so poorly.

Bottle.  Poured to a dark cloudy cider color with a fluffy head.  Light to sryupy body.  Sweet cider aroma with light floral hints.  Medium to full body flavor.  Sharp crisp beginning full of strong flavors (malty, fruits, flower).  Long middle with sharp flavors leading to a quick end.  Slight alcohol flavor in aftertaste.  Lively and punchy sharp tastes, clean & crisp.
Bottle 33 cl. Pours a cloudy yallow with a medium head and a thin sour and spicey smell. The taste is mildly sweet and pretty spicey, finish is bitter. One of the best triples I know

Pours a cloudy orange-gold with a frothy , off-white head that diminishes to a thin cap that laces fairly well. Bright, fruity and lightly spicy yeast notes are on the nose with lesser notes of faint bubble gum and light wheat in the background. Medium-bodied and soft with a dry and somewhat tart finish. Fruity yeast, white pepper, citrus and faint bubble gum come out, in the flavor, and conclude with a bone-dry finish. A nice dry tripel, this is another fine offering from St. Bernardus.

Had this one on tap.  It poured a orangy-blond with a light foam head with big bubbles that faded immediately.  There was not much aroma except for a mild dough yeast smell.  The flavor seemed a bit short, tasting of soft fruit and yeast.  There was a bit of a filmy puckering effect which coated the front teeth and gums.  The high alcohol was barely noticeable accept for the mouth warming feel it gave.  Overall, a good Belgian triple, just not my top choice.

[721-20070929] 330mL (By Jul-07). Grape-y champagne aroma is not pronounced. Clear, orange brown body with a big long-lasting creamy white head. Belgian yeast dough and fruit flavour. Medium body. Interesting but does not seem like a great example of itself today.
Hazy straw color with good solid head. Belgian nose with floral, apples and cloves. Taste is apples, lemons, bread dough, and bananas. Very nice sweet tripel.

One of my favorite St. Bernardus brews so far. I rate it up there with there Abt 12. Pours a hazy golden amber with an average size off-white head with excellent lacing (as all St. Bernardus brews seem to have). Another trademark of the monastery are the complex aromas of there brews. This one has pine, lemon, chocolate, dough, apple, cinnamon, brown sugar, and banana. Very sweet smelling. Taste is clean with sweet start and mild bitter finish. Soft carbonation and an alcoholic finish make this beer a favorite in my book

Pours out great and leaves some head with a strong lacing. The smell is very flowrey and really great. Has a sweet flowery nose to it, like a great beligan tripel. Taste is malty and sweet with buttery flavors. It has apple fruit tones. Mouthfeel is a little off, but very nice. I dont like this as much as other Belgians, but it does fine for itself.

A really nice grainy-sweet aroma. Not sure if the monk is blessing me or showing me the size of his endowment. Oaty, lots of yeast, a golden cake quality to it. Long moderate bitter finish. Good CO2. Pretty good stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a foamy white head.  Aroma of white fruits such as apple, grape, and pear.  Also, strong alcohol and spice presence. Pretty carbonated at first but becomes intense as it warms.  Nice balance of fruitines, maltiness, alcohol, and slight hops.  Very crisp enjoyable tripel.

A pop of the cork, and its pale yellow with a very thin white head, lots of bubbles and inches of lacing. Aroma is appley sweet with cloves.  Taste is way drier than the aroma would suggest, and has a metallic hop finish.  Other than that, there is not much to it. Somewhat disappointing from one of my favorite breweries. $8/22oz

The body is a light straw color with a quickly fleeting white head.  Has a very yeast filled aroma with a little bit of spice and noble hops aroma- from the saaz.  The flavor has a little bit of bubblegum taste with a nice bit of sweetness- like honey on the end.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange and with fine yeast sediments floating around, has a lasting off-white head. Classic belgian yeast spiced aroma. Flavour holds a classic belgian spiced yeast flavour and with mild caramel malt base. Delicate yet faint compared to many other more flavourful belgian tripels.

(33cl bottle, bought a couple of years ago, still bb: June 08) Hazy, orange-golden coloured hue with loads of particles and a thick and persistent foamy white head. Sweet bready (cara-)malty aroma with rather subtle fruity (pears) notes, coriander-spice and noticeable alcohol. Sweet flavour, bready and slightly grainy caramel-malty taste spiced with notes of coriander; full bodied with a lively but pleasant carbonation; medium-dry, sweet-bitter finish with a present but non-disturbing alcoholic touch. A decent Tripel.
Sou fã incondicional das "cervejas do padrinho". Muito malte e discreto lúpulo. Muito equilibrada, de carbonatação alta. Excelente.

A taster at Bieres et Saveurs Chambly. The color is golden with a white head. The taste is of hops and spicies with a sweet finish.The aroma is also of hops but I could smell a bit of citrus to go along with the sweetness.
bottle. Bright golden with large white head. Fruit, yeast, citrus, some spice, malt.  Well balanced.

Im not a great fan of Tripels but continue to try various ones, hoping Ill be impressed. Tried a Westmalle Tripel at Resto in NYC and found it quite nice. This was its equal, well balanced with only a hint of sweetness. Love that smiling monk.
Draft @ redlight. Pretty heckuva tripel. Big banana nose, with a sugary breadiness. Big soft sweetness. Hazy golden yellow, with nice lacing.
Garrafa, em Genebra (SUI), em novembro de 2007. Saborosa, bom aroma, equilibrada, tripel de qualidade. Só não gosto dessa carbonatação alta da família St. Bernardus.
Pours a hazy gold white a dense medium sized head, smells like yeast and citrus, yeasty citrus taste with a nice bitter finish.
Hazy golden colour, firm white head. Lots of fresh aromas, with citrus, banana and spices. Flavour is sweet and spicy. Well-balanced. Excellent tripel.

bottle 11 oz:  pours a hazy golden colour  with a large pithy lively white head, some lacing. aroma of fresh fruits and yeast, wheat malts, banana and a light spice also a lemon citrus. flavour is yeasty with banana esters, great spice, wheat malt and a lemon zest. palate is lively and good.

In short: Excellent classic hoppy Tripel
How: Tasting session at brothers place.  750ml Bottle, fresh.  Side-by-side St-Bernardus Tripel and St-Bernardus Watou Tripel
The look: Cloudy yellow-blonde body with a medium white head.
In long: Yet another great beer from St-Bernardus.  Fruity yeast and well malted.  Bready with bananas in crisp honey.  Side-by-side with her sister the St-Bernardus Watou Tripel the similarities were as apparent as the differences.  The Watou Tripel was going a bit more in the crisp sweet malt, crusty grandma lemon-pie.  This one is going more in direction of a Westmalle Tripel with a generous noble hopping.  A bit less complex but with a nice grassier taste and nice drier finish.  I couldnt decide which one I preferred.  This is a classic brewery interpreting a classic style in a classic fashion.  Thats like the Rolling Stones doing an acoustic cover of Stairway to Heaven.

750ml bottle.  Pours a golden amber with a fizzy white 1-2 finger head that dissipates to a 1/8" head that retains to the bottom of the glass.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is yeast, fruit (banana), some spice/pepper.  Flavor is sweet, more banana, spice, yeast.  Mouthfeel is quite pleasant, just the right amount of carbonation.  Finishes dry.  Alcohol is incredibly well hidden.  Im more of a fan of Quads/Dubbels (LOVE their Abt 12), but I still enjoyed this Tripel from St. Bernardus.

has a buttery complexion with an abundance of flavors that collide in my palate ... pepper and butter and hints of lemon earthy hops which give it a sweetness that is almost too overwhelming..  I guess Im just not an abbey tripel kinda guy... ah.

2 ounce sample at 99 Bottles, Federal Way, WA.  White head.  Little lacing.  Lightly cloudy body.  Melted butter color.  Major aromas and flavors include flowers, lemon, straw, black pepper.  Primary flavor is lemony-peppery-floral.  Sweetness that dries as it goes.  Okay.  I can appreciate it, just not my "cup of tea"/"glass of ale."
Light amber in color with a thick white head.  Nice with light fruity and spicey notes.  The alcohol is present and so is a little lingering sweetness.

Pours a pale straw color with frothy white head.  Fruity aroma with a decent amount of yeast and spice.  Flavor is a little underwhelming: banana, pear, apricot, hint of citrus, a bit of nuttiness and yeast.  Palate is nice though.
Pours dark amber with large head. Aroma  is sweet but also has hints of spice. Flavor is nice balance of sweetness, Alcohol, and spice. Very drinkable. with nice smooth finish.

(33 cl bottle at Haket Göteborg) Clear golden color, small white head. Vinous, almond, nuts and raissins, sweet scent, also alcohol. Sweet sirupy, roasted, spicy taste with sme smoke as well. Caramel and coffee with almonds aftertaste. Medium to spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.
Cloudy pale yellow straw color with a decent head.  Nice head, nice smell, nice taste.  Somewhat yeasty.  Strong typical belgian smell and taste.  Malty with strong alcohlic flavors.
pale yellow, high rate of carbonation, very very traditional Belgian.  aroma kind of offensive, not a fan really

11.2 pours a thickly hazed deep dark orange shade. tall, frothy, white head lasts long and leaves lots of heavy lacing. great aroma of sweet apricots, bananas, mild perfume and esters. this is a very full bodied tripel for sure. the heavy oil mouthfeel is fuller than most ive tried. very creamy and round through the finish. quite crisp with a thick butterscotch and toffee sweetness. dry bready finish has only the slightest hint of alcohol. excellent.
Pours a murky orange with a light, soapy, rapidly dissipating head.  Slightly sour, citrus aroma.  Very spicy, citrusy taste.  An interesting beer, but not entirely what I expected from a Bernardus.
Pours a light amber with frothy head. Smell of tropical fruit, honey, and spice. Nice, thick mouthfeel. Wouldnt have guessed that this has an alcohol content of 8%--its well hidden.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2008 A thick and meaty Belgian tripel - probably the densest tripel I ever tasted. Usually tasty bitterness with flowery banana type flavors - well done....I would recommend this for those who especially enjoy triples,not for novices.
Gold color with giant white head and thick lacing. Big sweet, fruity aroma. Flavor was very sweet and fruity with light alcohol burn. Some citric notes. Great
330ml bottle. Burnished gold colour with a big, off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, honey and spice. Flavour also started sweet with some spice, before a dry, bitter finish. very good.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served cool in a tulip glass.
App.:  Golden with infrequent yeast flecks, large white froth.
  
Aroma:  Sickly sweet floral honey, some citrus and coriander/other spice, light pear/apple, apricots/peaches, saccharine sweetness...blech. 
  
Palate:  Medium body, smooth, soft carbonation, a touch syrupy.
  
Flav.:  Plenty sweet, floral honey, some citrus notes, a little bite (alcohol?), some very fruity/bubblegum-like esters; quite sweet, a little tart and bitter enough for balance.

I guess, for me, Belgians are an even-numbered experience.  Dubbels and Quadrupels are wonderful.  Belgian ales and Tripels...not so much.

Bottled. Pours clear golden with fair white head, lots of sediment in the bottle still. Aroma is pretty yeasty with bready maltiness behind. Kinda flat carbonation-wise but with a nice mouthfeel. Flavor has good maltiness with a slight spiciness and mild fruitiness. Not really any outstanding flavors in this, its well balanced I guess, yeasty like it should be, and quite good overall. Finish is fairly dry and it has a decent bitterness to it. If its truly 8% abv, I would say it is well disguised. Ill have another to decide.

Bottle, bottle has aged a bit, much of the wheat and yeast has formed into large floaties, so i just poured slow fro m he top, it formed a frothy white head that left quickly but had nice lacing. Light fruity tart notes, with some apricot, and tangerine notes. Pours cloudy light gold color. Not as fruity or tart as the aroma lets on, rather dry with subtle spice. Fairly carbonated. Hops are slighly metallic. Not too bad, I prefer it over the fruitier triples, also alcohol is well hidden and yeast is not too dominate. Not bad at all.

Nov 2005 - I have to admit, as abt 12 is my fav beer and Ive been on a trippel kick lately, that I had high expectations for this and was a tad disappointed. Beer poured light yellow with orangey tints with a huge head which disappeared rather quickly. Taste was tart and sour with a some sweet fruits and a nice hop twang finish. A good trippel, but not on par with best ones.

Bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar: Very cloudy pale peach color with a generous fluffy white head. Aroma of spice from the yeast and fruity with white grape. Flavor starts peppery and spicy with fruit (pear, grape) a light alcohol burn and a spicy, citrus dry finish.  Medium body is creamy and tangy with lively carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2007 12 oz bottle poured hazy orange little white head that turns to some lace.  Belgium yeast, fruit and malt aroma, clean mouth feel some light carbonation. The taste on this one is lightly sweet malty fruity start slightly hoppy bitter finish. Not one of my favorite tripels but good non the less

Brown bottle, 330 ml, best before 25 01 10, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on September 27 2007; eye: golden, lightly hazy, good effervescence, nice creamy white head, a bit of lacing; nose: yeast, coriander, light caramel, fruity; mouth: in that order, silky, carbonation, caramelized malt, spices, a bit of bitterness, creamy finale en malt and caramel with some spices, mildly sweet, slightly bitter, medium body, quite carbonated; overall: good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 330 ml, 8 %, meilleure avant 25 01 10, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 27 septembre 2007; il : dorée, légèrement voilée, bonne effervescence, belle mousse blanche crémeuse, un peu de dentelle; nez : levure, coriandre, léger caramel, fruitée; bouche : dans cet ordre, soyeuse, carbonatation, malt caramélisé, épices, petite pointe damertume, finale crémeuse en malt et caramel avec un peu dépices, moyennement sucrée, très légèrement amère, corps moyen, très carbonatée; en résumé : bonne

This was rather disapointing I had just expected more of this. The aroma is rather boring for a tripel, a bit of yeast and alcohol. The flavor is of alcohol, with a tint of fruit and a bitter aftertaste. After some time you can taste the fruit better and it gets better for each zip.

Bottle.  prob one of my favorite tripels to date - i havent had too many because they are just not my style of beer.  hints of fruits, vanilla, lots of yeast, and some spice.  really not too bad - similar traits in mouthfeel to the other st. bernardus brews.  but in the end, give me the 12 anyday!!!
A hazy orange beer with a nice head. Aroma is sweet, yeasty and spicy. Taste is malty, sweet. Notes of alcohol and spices. Nice mouthfeel
From the bottle. Pours with a cloudy, hazy golden colour. Decent fruity flavour. Where this one loses points for me is in the palate, It has a wicked aftertaste that just lingers on and on.

Bottle. 1 pt. 9.4 fl. oz.  A hazy, golden yellow color with sudsy, white head.  Floral aroma of lemon and yeast. Light to medium body with slightly oily texture.  Flavor is sweet spice and malt, then sour wheat and citrus with a dry finish.  I was a bit let down by the flavor after such a nice aroma, but overall still a quality brew.

Deep orange-blond beer with almost a withe foam. Citrus aroma, sweet, spice, corriander. The flavor is complex and have lot from fruits, yeast and bread. Some alcohol but it just makes this one better.

Golden with foamy white head, decent lacing.  Yeasty and floral hoppy aroma with touches of fruit and spiced clove.  Wheaty and yeasty to taste, with peppery, bread, banana, vanilla, fruit flavors, dancing with a floral hoppy background.  A smooth, well balanced tripel, with a delicate and complex body.  Nice example of the style.

Pours a clouded gold with a white head. Nose is mild. At first the thing that came to mind was pencil shavings (like when you sharpen your pencil with that little 2nd grade sharpener). Very slight citric tone. Overall though, the nose is very quiet. The flavor. Slightly woody tone on the tail end. But overall, it is extremely well balanced. Smooth and even. On the first sip, the feel was like I opened my mouth, closed my eyes, and had someone pour silk into my mouth. Beautiful. Hence the 5. Very drinkable. One to go back to again and again. 

Normally when I see a beer reviewed so much with such a high score, I approach with trepidation. This one did deliver though. And I am glad to have been able to grab a bottle when I was in the Bay area.

Bu au Festival Bière et Saveur 07 (bouteille). Blonde mi brumeuse, moyen collet. Arome de malte un peu épicé, quelque notes dagrumes pétillant, légèrement houblonné. Bon goût de malte caramelisé aux agrumes, finission sûrette plaisante.

Pours a crisp cloudy golden color into the trappist glass.  Initially there was about two inches of head that dissapated rather quickly.  There was a small bit of lacing on the glass.  The scent was of dried fruits, spice and yeast.  The flavor was a bit sweet with classic tripel undertones.  Not as complex as I would have expected.  A middle of the road Tripel.

Name: Tripel
Date: 02/21/2001
Mode: Bottle Conditioned
Source: Chevy Chase, DC

dark yellow, thin head, sweet malt aroma, rich sweet full bodied malt flavor, touch of spicy hops and a slight bitterness in the finish
-------- />
Name: Tripel
Date: 03/11/2006

sparkling golden yellow, lots of carbination leading to a huge white head and thick lace, spicy sweet malt aroma, light epervesant body, blanaced spicy character to go with the sweet malt, no alcohol, no bitterness

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4

Pours a hazy orange colour with a medium off white head. Aroma of white wine, clove, floral, yeast, sweet fruits. Initial taste is clove, sweet,  and hints of mango. Moving to slight bitter hops on the palate, banana and spices(pepper) for the finish. Great balance, good head retention.
This has to be one of my favorite Belgians right now, love the flavor smell and taste

11.2oz bottle, pours a cloudy dark golden color with a perfect huge white head, lots of bubbles little sediment, fruit, banana, spice present in taste and smell, hops, smooth finish, well rounded beer overall, very good.

Hazily sedimented with milky white froth. Fresh, estery fruitbowl nose. Pineapple, pear and banana. Velvety mellow spice, wheaty softness and gentle hop bite. Fruity malt afters. Clean, unsugary, harmonious Tripel.

Bottle conditioned, 330ml, aged 5.5yrs. This poured a perfectly clear gold with high conditioning, rocky white head. A beer that ages this well has to be good, subtle spiciness with fruity, peachy background, a faint sweetness and a rich maltiness leading to a lightly bitter finish. very good.
