11.2oz bottle. Pours cloudy golden color with full foamy white head. Aroma is sweet and yeasty. Taste sweet, yeasty and lite fruit with a dry finsih.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2007 Bottiglia da 33cl in un bar a Gavi Ligure, accompagnata con piadina prosciutto crudo e pomodoro. Colore giallo scuro molto pronunciato, leggermente torbida, schiuma un poco evanescente; aroma non molto forte, ma con una nota di dolcino che rimane anche nel sapore che non è poi così armonizzato come nella descrizione commerciale. Buona tripel comunque.

Pours light golden with a massive white head. Lots of lovely tiny bubbles. Really yeasty aroma at first and not as floral as I would expect. Further sniffing reveals a bit more of that floral character youd expect from belgian tripel yeast. Lots of good esters. Touch of grain. First flavors are nice and sweet. Lots of banana. Some clove and pepper. Finish is yeasty with some of that pepper. Body is on the full side of medium. What a perfect example of what a tripel should be.

Bottled 33cl. Black pepper, lemon, melon, yeast and spices in the nose. The head is rather big, creamy and lasting and has a surprising light beige color. The beer is hazy orange - A beautiful Tripel. The taste is very sweet, soft and pleasant in every way. Bready, herbal elements emerge.  A nice alcoholic touch shows up just before the finish. Lightly spicy, flowery with a good hop character. Full bodied. This beer leaves a beautiful lacing. Hints of coriander. Fruits include melon, orange and lemon. The finish is dry malty, bready with reminiscent hints of caramel and coffee.

I tried this beer on August 10, 2007 at The Esplanade Biermarket in Toronto.  The beer was a cloudy brown in colour with a short lasting off-white head.  The aroma was very yeasty with some spicy tinges in the background.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied with a fair amount of carbonation while the flavour was full of yeast and wet bread.  Another damn fine product from St. Bernardus!
id almost tie this with their abt 12. its got a good thick golden color, high level of effervescence, nice medium head. really good after a hard day at work.
bottle @ Allen Street Hardware, Buffalo. Darker than a lot of previous Tripels. Nice white head poured into Ommegang glass. Sweet almost toffee like finish. Pretty good
Malty, hoppy nose. Brown sugary/fruity hint.  Sweet, savory, full-bodied. This brewery always seems to come through with consistently quaffable treats.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2007 750 ml corked bottle, cellared for nearly two years. Big white airy head with thick laces.  First pour is slight misty copper colored (sediments is still down there) Aroma is  lemony and fruity- acidic , yeasty,  with whiffs of  alcohol. 
Taste does not live up to the aroma; some fruitiness, sugar,  and a very light hopbitteernss. Medium body.  Finish is not very impressive either ; light bitter and sourish.

A bottle aged nearly 4 years.  Surprisingly sweet in the aroma and flavor.  The aroma does have some alcohol as well.  Flavor has fruit and sugar, and only a little alcohol.  A great looking beer, well carbonated and a tall white head.  Some sediment.  Aged very well.
nuts, nuts, and lots of nuts. bottle in gent, dark brown with fine thick head, outstanding mixture of hops and nuts

Saved the best for last theis weekend.  Dark gold with a swiss-cheese looking white head.  Expected spice and yeast, but more apple and fruits.  Effervescent mouthfeel.  Musty yeast and dry, fruity tartness blend well with the nutmeg-like sweetness.  A very good beer.

Bottle Dark golden pour with a big dying head. Aroma thick of fruits, spice, and alcohol. Flavor of sweet fruits and some tangyness. Light mouthfeel, very carbonated. Alcohol is well hidden in the flavor, but not in the aroma. Overall, a good tripel.
Smooth, malty aroma with a golden hue.  Sort of a flowery undescribable fruity flavor and great long aftertaste.  For a tripel it is undeniably smooth and has a great flavor from start to finish
Poured a yeasty golden color with bubbly white head. Had hints of light sweet fruits, some tarty fruits, subtle spices. Finished with a light sweet bubbly feeling on the tongue.

Hazy golden-orange with a large white head.  Aroma is fruity, sweet, malts, spices, and some yeast.   Spices and fruit malt dominate the flavor with yeast in the background.  Finishes wih a little bite.  Well hidden alcohol.  Thick, creamy body.  Good tripel.
Pours an orange-golden color with a fluffy white head.  Its not special as tripels go, but its a great tripel.
Pours a hazy golden copper color.  Spicy initial flavor.  Thought this would be better than it is.  Typical tripel, nothing more, nothing less.

Bottle at the new spot down the road, The Glenwood.  Nice murky yellow color with a decent white head.  Smooth flavors and spicy aromas.  Slightly bitter.  This one has some body some body and is very dry.  Some citrus fruit flavors including orange.  Very nice one.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange body with thin head. Aroma is of yeast, spices. Flavor is spicey, yeasty. Lots of sweetness.
Pours a dark yellow color with a thin head. Yeasty sweet nose. Kind of tastes like sweet and sour sauce. Interesting balance. Pretty good.

pours a mustard yellow with a small dissapearing tan head. has a nice apple grain aroma. a thin body with small lively bubbles. has a dry citrus taste with a slight honey and metallic flavor. very crisp beer beautifully balanced
Pours a hazy gold with a fluffy white head. Fresh fruit on the nose. Fruit and spices on the palate. Clean refreshing finish.

Pale golden look with a fast disappearing white head. Aroma is fruity and fresh with alchohol being present. Exploding palate. Flavor is quite complex and warming. The sweetness sticks to you gums and teeth, but the alchohold and bitterness balance it out nicely.
Looks beautiful - amber color, just the right amount of carbonation.  Head dissipated quickly.  Much more bitter than most Tripels, and the most disappointing beer Ive had from St. Bernard.

Bottle. Pours a nice orange colour with a medium fairly lasting head. Troma of toasted malt, fruits, yeast, spices and alcohol. The flavour is malty and spicy with toasted caramel, dark fruits, alcohol and with a bitter malty finish. Great brew!
Bottle.  Cloudy orange body with a white head.  Smells of banana, orange peel, cinnamon?.  Tastes of fruits and spices, alcohol is mostly hidden.  Nice and light in the mouth.

on tap @ papago...pale white color. sweet yeasty aroma. flavor is very light and mild, mostly yeast and floral honey.  theres a banana flavor on the finish or its just the creamy mouth feel which is reminiscent of banana eating.  one of a handful of beers that i would not pair with food. its too intricate and mild not to be appreciated on its own
light orange with thick creamy disapating head. excellent lacing.  hints of corriander with a light hoppy finish another excellent beer from st. b!

After trying this is a bottle last night, I knew I had to make a valiant effort to find this on draft. I had heard that the nearest Belgian cafe in Garden City, about 20 miles to the southwest, had this in its rotation, so i made a trip to find this majestic tripel.

I found Waterzooi be a warm welcome home to the Europe I left last summer after my brothers wedding in Lyon, France. Among the neatly arranged taps was the smiling monk waiting for me..

The pretty bartender poured me a healthy goblet full of the butter colored ale, which led to the first taste without a thought....it was amazingly good. It was even greater than I had anticipated as I watched the rings of lacey foam decline into the glass.

The malty triple had more great tastes than Sybil had personalities.
I had the bizarre impression of bananas and milk shakes while I couldnt detect the alcohol at all.

I thought this ale would be great with broiled duck or just by itself in the company of friends.

bottle.  average off white head (quickly dissapates).  cloudy dark orange body.  corriander, light fruit aromas, and yeasts are all present.  light sweet flavor with a touch of bitterness.  actually reminds me more of a white beer than a triple.  Good stuff.
Bottle: Poured a hazy golden yellow color with a bubbly white head. Sweet fruit and floral aroma. The taste was sweet fruit at first but finished tangy floral flavor.

330 ml bottle. Best before Sept 08.
Hazy golden with a thin head

Aroma has banana, caramel, dates, a touch of alcohol and some yeast.

Flavor is fruit, honey, then a touch of sour and some yeastiness.

Alcohol is hidden well.

A golden, almost peachy body with a thin rocky white head and yeasty particles thoughout.  A complex aroma of bananas, rasins, dates caramel, and just a hint of orange zest.  A taste of apples, rasins, figs, carame, along with a touch of honey.  A very enjoyable drink.

330 mL bottle.  Hazy honey yellow with big foamy white head.  Aroma of sour fruit, yeast, and malt.  Lively tangy palate.  Tastes of sweet malt and sour fruit with a smotth finish.  Alcohol is well hidden.
330ml bottle.  Hoppy, flowery and spicey aroma.  Pours with a orange colour and bubble bath head.  CItrus, hoppy, fruity flavour with some spicey notes.  Full bodied with a bitter finish.  Good ale.

Slightly hazy dark golden body, white head, lacing; Very yeasty soft, malty soft, pleasant flowery nose with a very little warm salt apparent; Huge soft carbonation, soft texture slightly salty, slightly sweet; Slightly salty medium long finish, again lots of aroma both malt and yeast. A very warm salty touch is present all trough the beer. Pleasant!
Very delicious brew.  Pours a golden color with many floating things.  Nice honey and biscuit taste, easy to drink.

bottle - Pours hazy gold with a big, lingering head that leaves excellent lacing.  The body of the beer displays loads of fine carbonation and some floaters.  It has a yeasty, citrus accented aroma.  The flavor has a delicious sweetness to it thats complemented well by citrus and spice notes.  Theres a touch of mild bitterness in the finish of this very enjoyable tripel.  St. Bernardus just cant seem to go wrong.

draft @ theotherroom - golden and hazy with a fluffy white head that disappears rather quickly. aroma and flavor are pretty much identical...sweet honey like flavors and aroma as well as your typical spiciness you get in a tripel. very easy drinking. almost like i middle ground between a tripel karmeliet and a grimbergen blonde

Thanks to Secret Santa for this treat.  Pours golden hazy with a medium white head.  Sweet, figgy aroma with malty, candy syrup.  A rather full aroma with metallic hints.  The flavor is strong with honey, creamy dates, alcohol, metallic hints and spicy notes (very light spice).  All well balanced with nothing particularly overpowering.  Medium round body.  Probably the most enjoyable triple Ive ever had.

0,33 bottle. Pours bit cloudy dark orange colour. Aroma... arome is what I already know from few other Belgians but... I dont really like it, its too strong and unpleasant. And what is it? This is a problem. I cant describe it. I read through other comments and I think that "candied orange" is very close. You can feel it also in taste. Though, taste is something that fits me much more. Flavour is good mix of light sweetness ans sourness with some spices. Spices are also quite strong in aroma - cinamon maybe? Bitter and bit dry long enough finish. Nice, lively carbonation. Its quite good, apart this SOMETHING in aroma.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow color with small head.Flavor is a combination of sweet and sour. There are some green apple tart like flavors and a tad of fig and spice. Decent but not totally blowing me away.

12oz brown bottle from A-1 To-Go in Gardiner.  Somewhat murky red-orange body with a good inch and a half oh head that sticks around for a while and leaves a fair bit of lacing as it dissipates.  Smells fruity, like apples and raisins, with nut and spice notes.  Tastes fruity (citrus, apple) with bits of nut and spice.  No real alcohol noticed.  Lighter bodied than expected, making this a real drinkable beer for the style.  Wow, this beer is great.

On tap from Liars club.Nice light golden color with pleasant white head. Light fruity aroma. Flavors of yeast and fruit sugars with a fair amount of compllexity. Length of finish is ok. Nice beer but not the best tripel I have sampled.

11.2oz. Bottle
Enjoy by 7/28/08

St. Bernardus Tripel pours a pale golden into its very own chalice. When held to the light it glows a bright yellow. Fair amount of floaties with many still left in the last 1/2 inch of beer in the bottle. Poured with a 1 finger white head that faded fairly quickly to a thin cap with spotty thick patches. Leaves some patchy spotted lacing with each drink that falls excruciatingly slow back into the body. Looks good.

Smell is complex but falls a little short compared with other St. Bernies. Big bread dough aromas coming forward along with candied orange peel. The yeats character comes through with a little dusty spiciness. I even detect the occasional cherry cordials, very faintly though. Very nice.

Taste is where its at with this tripel. The sip starts off with with the bread dough, lightly toasted bread and a handful of the candied fruits. This beer is an expierence for the tastebuds. A lot of very enjoyable flavors. Candy sugars and all the wonderful doughiness mix together to create an excellent beer. The perfect amount of residual sugars. Im really having a hard time breaking this down, very familiar flavors but at the same time new to me, very strange. Very good.

The body is medium, maybe a little on the lighter side. Good carbonation keeps things moving and is prickly on the tongue. No alcohol in the flavor but when the glass starts getting low my cheeks start getting a little warmer.

This is a beer I could honestly enjoy all day long. The carbonation and mild body help push this over the top. The more I drink the more I want. 

This is an excellent tripel from St. Bernardus and will definately see my fridge many more times in the future. Wish I had more on hand right now. Im kind of anxious to pick up some other tripels to review and compare. This one will be hard to beat. The most enjoyable Ive had to date.

2/11/07

Orangey pour with a slowly dissipating white head.  Very, very enjoyable flavor, and very easy to drink considering the 8% ABV.  That being said, this Tripel has a heavy body and leaves an aftertaste that reminds you that this brew means business.  Nice fruity flavor accentuates the drink from start to finish...highly recommended
My first tripel. Pours a hazy burnt sienna with a big white head that takes a few seconds to dissipate. I am usually a stout man but this impressed me.

Hazy orange with a huge, fluffy white head.  Smells of Belgian yeast with a little citrus and another tangy smell that I cant identify.  Maltier and sweeter than I expected.  Quite spicy; pepper and herbs, maybe thai basil?  A little lemongrass.  Pretty full mouthfeel, a little heavier than other tripels Ive had.  Leaves a peppery, gingerish burn in the back of the throat.  Theres a lot to like in this beer.  I usually prefer a brighter, more cirtusy style tripel, but the spiciness and the texture of this brew keep drawing me back.
Pours deep orange with a big white head that lasts.  Very bubbly...  Decent Tripel.

Big ass bottle drunk on 5/4. Pale yellow color with huge white head. Smells just like a belgian triple. Yeasty and candy flavors. The flavors almost seem delicate. Gets better as it warms. Dry slight matalic finish.

750ml bottle from the Flying Saucer in San Antonio.  A nice tripel but it seemed too carbonated though, which kinda threw me off.  Pours a cloudy gold with a fizzy white head.  Light on the palate, leaving a bitter aftertaste.  Id reccomend trying it, but taste it before you buy a bottle.

Pours a light cloudy brown with almost no head.  Smells like girl and light hops.  Very nice flavor, good malty flavor with leave flavor.  Nice hop profile as well. I would most certainly buy this again, reminds me of fall.  I cant wait for the fall to drink this then outside with the changing leaves.

Aroma of yeast, coriander, lemon? and other spice. Finely bubbled golden color with a huge white head. Starts thin to medium. Very smooth, slightly sweet start. Flowery hop. Not bitter. Pepper, spice, but very muted. Something of an apple/pear flavor, but very light. The finish is dryish, and the bitter is very light. This whole thing is subtle and very light. Refreshing and wonderful. Not sicky sweet like so many.

12oz bottle.  Pours a pale, translucent color with a lot of bubbles and a big foamy white head.  Aroma is vanilla, yeasty, fruits, slightly bitter.  Taste is smooth, fruity, bitter.  This is very good but all of the top tripels are starting to taste the same to me.

Bottle. Cloudy rust orange color.  Suprisingly small head and no visible carbonation.  Orange, lemon, corriander, and honey aroma - all sweet, to whiff of hops.  While the hops were not noticed in the smell, they are apparent to the taste.  Spicy at first with a citrus zing, it gives way to a dry ending.  With a good array of hops, this is one of the more even (an in my opinion mature) abbey version I have come across. It has less of a hot alcohol feels than other strong Belgians.  A nice change, I will look for this standout again.
bottle from Total Wine Ft. Myers - pretty standard triple - malty, yeasty, coriander and other spices - tasty

Peachy straw colour, very hazy, massive rocky soapsuds head with eternal retention and thick lace. Yeasty and vaguely fruity aroma. Sweet malt, bready, fruity, and a peppery dryness that is quite nice. Well hidden alcohol, medium sweetness. A solid approachable triple, but nothing really outstanding for me.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 750ml bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden with a large long lasting white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of citrus, sweet malt, and floral hops. Taste is the same with hints of yeast spice and mild bitterness. A very good Tripel.
Hazy golden color with decent head.  Aroma is slightly sour and fruity.  Flavor is well balanced between sweet and bitter, a little extra sour.  Quite bubbly.  Not bad.
Cloudy yellow and partilces can be seen. Light orangish aroma.  Light, not a strong taste, but works.  Decent, nothing bad, nothing good either.
Pour is golden in color. Citrusy notes in aroma. Taste is citrus fruits with a peppery spice.

11.2 oz bottle, best by date marked 31 12 06. Clear gold with a thick white head. Sweet, yeasty, fruity aromas, light sweet malt and bread. Flavors of sweet bread and fruit to start, a slight peppery note follows. Sweetish malt and bread finish, tinged with a light spiciness. Nice!

UPDATED: APR 20, 2007 11.3 oz. Bottle.  Strong carmel, butter honey, orange, and toffee odors.  Pale golden with lingering lace.  Bready malt, caramel sweetness and peppery spice.  Soft to medium body.  Finishes with malt and spice.

LIght amber hue, a little hazy, frothy off white head, fair lacing, citrus smell like lemon water, kind of creamy texture, soft carbonation, orange tang, average finish...slightly bitter, nice balance.  Remeniscent of an orange creamsicle...Very nice.  St. Bernard is consistently good.

This beer is very fruity.  The nose is chock full of light fruits.  The head is small, white, and dissipates quickly.  The taste carries with it the heavy influences of light fruits and yeasts.  Not a very heavy beer at all, but enjoyable.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Cloudy light brown/orange.  Not as good as the ABT12 by a longshot but still nice.  Medium amount of head and a sweet aroma.  Very sweet taste and a nice bitterness.  Alcohol is barely noticable.  Overall, the little brother to the ABT12 but a respectable beer nonetheless.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2011 a orange yellow cloudy body with a mostly diminishing white head with a spicy yeasty light malty aroma and a moderate spicy  bitter alcholic flavor and a average bitter alcoholic finish

330 ml bottle, from BevMo LaJolla.  Pours hazy, orange-golden color with a thick and fluffy white head that leaves heavy lace.  Wonderful tripel aroma, sweet and fruity, with citrus and floral notes, bready, spicy yeasts and a little lemon zest.  Flavor follows the same general character with (as the commercial description says) "a harmonious balance between sweet and sour" featuring tangerine, sourdough, floral hops, and rich, mellow yeast.  The alcohol is well hidden among the cacophany of tastes.  Full body and assertively creamy carbonation.  Very nice tripel!

Probably one of the better tripels I have had in a while. Cool translucent honey/golden color with a small white head that doesnt last too long. aroma of sugared bananas, light malt, yeast. Flavor is typical of a good tripel, loaded hops and citrus, well-balanced with the yeasty flavors and moderately high warming alcohol content. Finishes slightly dry with  a semi-thick feel and numbness to the palate. A pretty good tripel, but it doesnt even come close to the hearty maltiness of the Abt 12

11 oz bottle.  Citrus fruity aromas off this hazy golden nicely beer.  White fluffy head is leaving nice lacing too.  More citrus fruit on the flavor with wonderful pepper and vanilla notes.  Slightly bitter but not too much.  Sweeter finish than I had expected.  Very good
Bottle, 75cl. Hazy golden colour with a large white head. Yeasty & fruity aroma, a bit anonymous. Light spicy flavour.

(Bottle) pours light hazy amber. Fruity, sweet and a bit sugary aroma with some yeast and syrupy malt. Small notes of hops and maybe some almond paste. Fruity, well carbonated flavour with syrupy and bready malt. Medium sweet. Full, round and rather smooth mouthfeel. Medium to full body. Malty finish.

Drank in a trappist glass.  Hazy amber poor with a thin off white head.  Nice amount of sediments at the bottom as weel.  Aromas of unripenned bananas, prunes, creamy (lactose), peaches and cotton candy.  Reminds me also of caramel fudge with lots of spices.  Creamy mouthfeel with added flavors of caramel, cirtous, amazing hops were used to make this beer.  Pefect balance amd nicely carbonated.  Nice sweet start then it fades to a nice bitter aftertaste.
Great aroma.  Complex and just slightly bitter.  Highly carbonated with slight sweetness.  Very light on the tongue.  Its almost like it is dancing on it, then it leaves.

Pours a cloudy beige with mild but persistent white head.  Aroma is thick with malt and fruitiness.  Medium body taste with a hint of bitter citrus that is smoothed by the malt. Finishes equally smooth and wet.  Initially I thought the heavy malt aroma would overshadow the citrus in the taste, but the palate was suprisingly well balanced.  Im not rushing out to buy another, but its not a shameful brew.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2012 Bottle, 33 cl. Hazy golden, medium creamy white head. Wonderfulö fruity aroma with some almond paste and subtle phenolics. No alcohol. Medium bodied, silky smooth, with soft carbonation. Semi dry with medium bitterness. Perhaps not a school-book triple, but simply wonderful.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2007 Poured from an 11.2 ounce bottle into a tulip glass, hazy orange golden with a fluffy white head and a lot of floaters. The aroma was of yeast, fruit, citrus and apples. The taste was very sweet up front with notes of honey and butterscotch, which gave way to spices and a slight bitterness as it warmed. There is a small alcohol bite and a very creamy mouthfeel. Simply wonderful.

Nice brownish gold color. The head is nice and adds to the beers semi-creamy texture. I found the flavor to be lacking. It is a great beer, but the flavor surprises me because it does not stand out. I love the Abt 12 because the flavors are rich. The beer, as I continue to drink it, proves to be creamier and creamier. I like this beer, but I believe it goes down almost too smooth without leaving much of a flavor behind.

A sweet and delicate aroma of sugar and spice with background full hearted yeast. Liquid is a hazed and nearly opaque golden orange color with minimum amount of foam. The drink is a medium toned tripel with definite yeast presence and dash of spice. Has slight metallic aftertatsewith an almost dry finish. An abbey tripel worth revisiting in the future.

Smelt of maple, like the bullseye candies found in penny candy stores with hints of citrus.  Pour a honey color, with a this creamy head that disapated into a thin cramy head.  Floaters like the spice in pumpkin pie filling just added to the eye candy.The taste was simply lovely.  Creamy, rich, alcohol, faint sugar and plums.  As I said, simply lovely.

Pour was a cloudy copper and gold with a thick pillowy white head.  Left good lacing.  The aroma was pepper and spice initially but lightened up as the beer opened up.  Fruit and yeast took over as the main fragrances about half way through the bottle.  The flavor was a nice blend of honey, banana and mild spicyness.  Incredible mouthfeel.  Super velvety with a succinct finish.  My experience with Tripels is somewhat limited, but I thought this one was much better than Chimay white.
Golden colour littel white head and Aroma of fruit.Taste of honey and flower mild and nice beer.

Delicious tripel. Pour was a hazy orange with a 1 finger white head (no lacing). Aroma was of yeast and fruit. Taste was dry and yeasty with pear, apple and some other fruit I cant put my finger on. Medium carbonation and well rounded aftertaste. Man this is good...makes me want to join the monestary!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle.  Poured a solid golden color, fairly opaque with a frothy white head.  Aroma of dried fruit and pineapple and malt.  Flavor is somewhat bitter initially turning to a pleasing sour.  Strong carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel with somewhat dry bite on the finish.  Good.

Bottle @ Bishops Arms in Umeå. Hazy orange with a wispy white head. Wonderfully jammy fruit nose of Swedish cloudberries (hjortron) and sweet musky honey. The yeast is very evident in both the aroma and the palate, which is incredibly silky and smooth. Every sip seems to evaporate with a mere kiss of delicate fruit and faint reminder of the abv. A more balanced beer youd be hard pressed to find. To me a more subtle, more drinkable beer than the 12. My mouth waters at the desserts you could pair this tripel with..........

Pours a cloudy amber with a sparse white head.  Smells of sweet fruit (citrus mostly with some peaches).  Tastes of grainy cereal, apples, pears, some misc fruit flavors and some sugar.  No real hoppiness to this one.  Most of the flavor seems to come from the malt and yeast from what I can tell.  Im not sure what to think of this one and may have to revisit later.  Finish is very syruppy and sugary like fake maple syrup.
Bottled. Thanks to stegosaus for this one. Cloudy golden pour with 2 finger thick head. Yeast aroma with hints of belgian spice. Sweet alcohol finish. I enjoyed this very much.
Light golden yellow with large creamy head. Yeasty and fruity, mabye pear or apple. Good solid triple.

Hazy yellow coloured, some light carbonation and a large creamy white head. Sweet yeasty fruity aroma (pear, apple hints). Full Palate. Finish is dry yeasty, some sweet alcoholic bitter touches. Very nice balanced beer.
Bottle. Nice big white head with excellent duration. Color is light golden and a bit hazy. Aroma is powerful with fruits and yeast. Taste is complex with fruits and spices.

Pours a copper amber with a big frothy white head.  Smells of typical tripel noters, citrus and sweet malts.  The taste is very sweet.  Candy sugar, orange citrus, and sweet malts are all present in the taste.  This is about as solid of a Belgian tripel as there is.  It defines the style very well, and I would use this one as a clasic example of what one should taste like for someone new.

Thin amber color, sticky lasting head, smell of dark honey or molasses. Flavor: Alcohol is noticeable but not dominant; mild, brief sweetness of unripe pear becomes mild bitterness. Finish of hops and subtle alcohol.  Damn pleasant.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2007 Bottled. Much voluminous and creamy head, good resistance. Yellow clearly color, much fraught, solid and bare of fizz. Rather light scent with malty aromas, sugary, alcohol, aged cereals. Wrapping and much alcoholic taste with a structured body. Much warmth, smooths down and sweetish with agreeable notes of clear mildew and stum.
I had this beer at a tasting and its percentile is well-deserved.  It was fruity but didnt have any lead characters that I was aware of.  Another fine example of Belgian brewing.

Aroma: caramel
Appearance: amber, hazy, aminimal head
Flavor: not special
Palate: medium body, fizzy
Overall - I drank better

[bottle] Very mellow fruity aroma. Hazy amber in color, with a short white head. Very rich fruit flavors, like pear and apple, with bready yeast background. Alcohol is quite apparent, along with some strong carbonation. Not my favorite St. Bernardus beer, but still quite good.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2007 Botle. Amber in color with a lot of sparkling. Malty fruity aroma. Flavor is sweet with malt, lemon and some alcohol. Citrus and soft hoppy bitterness in the finish. A medium body.
bottle. golden color. sweet aroma. quite yeasty and caramelly. bit bready. bit of bitter spicyness.
pale straw yellow frothy head. distinct tripel aroma malty and spicy. taste dry and bitter light sparkly a little hint of metal as well as hay. a well balanced tripel.

330ml bottle - pours amber golden, with a nice big fluffy white head. Aroma is very floral and yeasty, with citrus, peach, apple, and some banana. Flavour is equally floral and fruity, as well as extremely smooth, with more bready yeast, apple cider, citrus, banana, honey, and alcohol warming from mid-palate to finish. Mouthfeel is thickly smooth (thicker than most other Tripels Im used to), with perfectly soft carbonation. Slightly sour in the finish, along with light bitterness. Last aftertaste. This is a wonderful Abbey Tripel, very complex and estery.

Bottle from BevMo. Pours a medium golden color with some light copper. Slightly grainy yeasty aromas. A little spice as well. Slightly sweet dark fruitiness up front with a bit of yeast. Some bitterness follows along with a bit of apple cider qualities. Fairly dry finish.

Pours a golden amber with a white head, nice tight small bubbles, and lacing.  The aroma has notes of floral, fruit, malt, and spice.  Flavor has a nice maltiness, with fruit and spices.  Slight astringint finish with just a pinpoint of hops.

bottle: Mildly cloudy dark yellow color with medium sized pure white head. Aroma is full of bananna, apple, pear, bit of honey. Flavor has bit of malt, with bananna and honey, faint pear and white wine. Finish is balanced, touch of sweetness.
Pours a hazy brown with a frothy head, fruity, sweet aroma, fizzy moutfeel, bitterish aftertaste.  Im not a huge fan of this one but it certainly was worth a try.

330. Pours a medium straw color that turns hazy and medium amber as the glass fills. Towering, fluffy, sudsy white head. Sweet caramel noughat butterscotch nut delight on the nose. More of the same on the attack and the mid-palate; almost buttery but not in a diacetyl way. Smooth and silky body, medium thick with soft carb. Beautiful drinkable stuff. Clean lightly herbal bitter finish. This is a wonderfully considered beer; you can feel the years of perfectionistic efforts at work in the balance and the drinkability. Splendid stuff.

Pours a hzy ruby-brown color, with a good 3" of almost pinkish tan head. The foam looks a lot like soft soap suds. Good lacing. Bread dough, beer yeast, and alcohol in the aroma.

Very flavorful with sweet fig, brown sugar, wheat bread, toffee, and mild chocolate malt. Dry spice and alcohol in the finish. Somewhere between medium and full bodied, moderately carbonated

Poured amber with a nice head. Sweet aroma. Very pleasent taste. slight bitterness.
The Commercial Description is accurate.

Yellow gold with lots of white head.  A little wheat and hop smell.  Leaves a nice lacing on the glass.  A very subtle taste, easy on the palate, and a bitter aftertaste.  It leaves the mouth dry, and its a thicker beer that requires you to drink slowly.
Poured a nice orange/gold color...Very nice, sweet smell! Slight off white head, little lacing...taste of apple and banana, and some citrus. This was really good!
BB 30.06.09.  Golden orange color.  aroma of tangerine, caramel, and slight yeast.  Sweetness.  medium bodied and slight bitterness.  Very fizzy texture.  Very dry, spicy finish.

Best before end of 2004 on label.
Pours with a large creamy off-white head. The body is clear dark orange.
Light malt aroma. Caramel and an apple/pear fruitiness. Spicy sweet with a dry finish. Very Nice.

12 oz. bottle dated BB  20.09.07 served in a chalice.  Aroma is rich and lively, dominated by caramel malt and a subtle yeast note.  This beer had an not quite clear orange tea color, and a gentle pour resulted in minimal head and not much replenishing action. Flavor starts spicey and with a strong carbonation note, has a nice gentle malt character that is consistent with the aroma, and ends with a dry, fast finsh and a subtle bitter note.  Medium bodied, perhaps a bit on the heavy side.  Some lacing on the glass.

Jan. 8, 2006; 12 oz. bottle (part of a four-bottle St. Bernardus gift package -- complete with Trappist glass). Lighter in color than the Abt 12, this tripel retains the signature flavor of its brewery.  Murky, hazy, cidery appearance. Some banana flavor amid the fruit, for sure.  Well-balanced and quite excellent.

A very murky, orange-colored tripel. Has a sweet, estery, floral, bready, yeasty aroma with hints of vanilla. The sweet side is more obvious in the taste with a smooth honey taste & supporting yeasty floral notes; overall pretty sweet for a tripel. Spicy and refreshing. The mouthfeel is pretty thick for the style, yet it is nice and smooth with subdued carbonation. Nice one.
Just superb.  Probably the best tripel I have had.  Fruity, yeasty flavor with a nice frothy head and rich mouthfeel.  Go out and buy this beer.

Golden orange pours with a lively carbonated head.  Part of a variety St. Benard 4-pack from Binnys. Wonderful aroma of banana, peppers, vanilla.  A nice citrus bite follows a bready spice.  Medium bodied and creamy.  A great tripel!

(Bottle) Golden yellow colour with a huge, lively, white head. Fruity nose with notes of pineapple, Seville orange, banana, white bread, dried pineapple or papaya and a hint of incense. Soft, malty taste with white bread, herbs, citrus and yeast. Mild, spicy bitterness in the finish. Hiding the alcohol very well. Very well balanced, fruity nose with a more malty, sweetish taste. Not exceptional, but nice and very drinkable.
Bottle. Light amber, cloudy color.  Sweet and strong. Very overcarbonated - sprayed out of bottle when opened and it wasnt shaken or dropped. Overall good.

Doughy and yeasty with plenty of apples, pears and lemon-citrus fruitiness and a pastry like sweetness to the nose.  Hazy golden body is topped by a fizzy byt lasting cover of white head.  Plenty of yeast/protein in suspension despite careful decanting - in fact there was a half inch sediment in the bottle before pouring.  Tangerine, apple, pear and lemon flavours with plenty of sweet doughy character.  Some floral lavender notes and a moderate bitterness that doesnt quite offset the sweetness.  Medium body with lively, sharp effervescence.  Tulip glass.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle (BB 040209, Bièropholie, Sep-05).

33cl - BB 300109 - Aroma is yeasty bread dough, banana, bubblegum and spice.  Pours cloudy yellow-brown with a big head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma with banana and alcohol taking the lead.  Palate is creamy and tart.  A very tasty tripel.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2009 BB 03-09. Pour is a hazy, nearly opaque, golden-copper color, with sediment; head is white, full, almost rocky-looking head which is mostly diminishing but leaves minimal nice lacing.  Nose is fairly fruity for a tripel; apple, honey, banana bread from light yeast notes, and faint floral and clove.  Honey and banana bread are dominant in the flavor with more floral presenting itself; lighter notes of sweet yeast notes, clove, and a sour flash just for a second.  Bitterness is there, but only to add depth.  Palate is more than medium, lively, and nearly creamy in texture, drying slightly.  Finishes sweet with banana esters and doughy yeast with some floral bitterness and at a moderate length with spicy phenols and faint warmth making a presence, lingering.  Decent tripel with all the nice traits, just nothing to set it apart from the greats.  This one may be a bit more true to the tripel style than the Watou but I dont know that I like it any better.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 Bottle/Draft in Poperinge.  Even non-beer drinkers will like this beer.  I stopped in a Poperinge pub and wound up drinking 4 drafts with the locals when all I stopped for was a cup of coffee.  I REALLY like this beer.

4yrs old: Lots of caramel in the aroma and flavor. Still tasty!

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy off-yellow with a foamy head. Aroma is yeasty, with spices, floral notes, and citrus.  Flavor is very sweet, akin to honey, with the yeast and floral notes making their way in as well.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2007 750 ML Bottle-Poured a cloudy golden yellow color w/a huge white head. Sweet floral aroma of a classic Belgian. Sweet, light, citrus, bananna flavor w/a slight trace of spices, maybe a little trace of dates/figs. Very good, very fresh sample. Much better than the bottle I first rated @ 3 months ago. Long flavorful finish-highly recomended.

From an 11.2oz bottle, this beer poured a gold/yellow color with an average head and copious lacing.  Nice, heavy bready aroma.

On first taste an incredibly soft, smooth, creamy full bodied brew hits your tongue.  Nice lightly malty, and sweet fruit finish

Despite the 8% ABV this is highly drinkable

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 pours a dark cloudy yellow gold with some sediment and a one finger white head. aroma is light bread and malt with a little alcohol. light to medium body with nice lacing. flavor is a little bread and malt and alcohol.also has a little dry hoppy aftertaste and nice carbonation. as smooth as the abt 12 but not as powerfull of course. pretty good and very well balanced. this is my second tripel and is by far the best yet. victory golden monkey being my first tripel.

Bottle.  Nice golden pour with a thick, long lasting white head, lasting to finish with excellent lacing.  Nice carbonation, tingly with a sweet aroma and a taste that is sharp, flowery, maybe a little spice, fruit.  I may rate it higher, but I enjoyed it thoroughly.

Hazy dark golden with a large foamy white head. Aroma is reasonably light, metallic and fruity. Flavour is fruity and very smooth, with pudding spice and heavy toffee/candy.
Earthy flavours in the finish, rounding off a great triple

Poured a clear gold color with a moderate head that faded faster than I would have hoped for.  Aroma is interesting with both fruit and sweet malt.  Hops are very present in the aroma as well; flowers, herbs and cat pee.  Upon tasting the beer has a sweet malt beginning that is followed by a robust bitterness and carbonic bite.  Full bodied but not heavy enough to be lingering.
Bottle at home. Another excellent brew by Bernardus. Sweet scent. Orange color. Sugary taste, also peaches, then prickly exit. Really good.
Bottle. Pour a light golden color with a frothy white head. Aroma of yeast, citrus and spices. Taste was musty and slightly bitter. Not nearly as smooth as the Abt 12.

bottle.  hazy brown/orange pour with huge white frothy head.  great aroma of orange malts, pepper and spice.  mouth of bake wheat bread.  big spicy carbonation and dry yeasty finish.  a little bit of alright.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a pale golden color with a large yellow-white head. The aroma is tart, tangy and fruity. The flavor is sweet, tart and bready with hints of ripe fruits and a trace of spice. The finish is tart and reminiscent of sweettart candies.

Thanks to aspidites for this. I have to say that yes, Ive had better triples. The nose was a little too soft for my liking, but what there was, was a bit fruity/lemony and sea salt. Mouthfeel was incredibly soft which I really enjoyed PLUS there was very little alcohol on the palate. Flavors were really subtle with sweet and fruity notes coming around. To say this was an average beer would be a travesty. It was very drinkable and enjoyable, but I just dont think it was something to rave about.

Murky, gold body. Tall, white head that reduces to puddles. Yeasty aroma of tangy clove along with hints of bread and floral hops. Flavor starts sweet and ends slightly bitter. Spice, ripe fruit, raisins. Tart, dry finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Moderate carbonation. Medium body. Delicious but without any surprises.

From a 330mL Bottle.  Pours a pale, cloudy off-lemon color with a tall head of whipped white froth.  Soft, candi-laden vanilla aromas mingle with some mild mango and a dusting of nutmeg spice.  Unique and subtly complex.  Light bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfeel.  A musty yeasty spice warms the tongue, bringing out some initial flavors of coconut husks and some nice clove spice.  Some lighter malty tones provide a nice backing.  The woody, dark spicy yeast characters really give this tripel some extra zip and a pleasingly complex flavor profile.

11.2 oz bottle.  Poured hazy golden with a large off white head.  Aroma is earthy, yeast, some fruits and spices.  Taste is light (in color) fruits such as white grapes, pears, earthy and bready yeast, with some tartness and bitterness in the finish.
UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 draught. sweet but not cloying. complex fruit flavour, something between peach and apricot. aroma reminds me a bit of rose pettels.finish is balanced but not too sweet.

Bottle. Cloudy golden/amber like colour. Head was very impressive egg-white like. Incredible lacing. Aroma is yeast, spicy, bread like, malty and hoppy notes. When sniffing the beer, not that powerful aromas comes into play I thought. (Served at 4-8 degrees as described on the bottle). But wow what a surprise when the first sip has been taken. Reasonable complex bodied, with hints of dry fruit (raisins, date) maybe some liquorish. Flavour is medium sweet, with some notes of bitterness. Well balanced and nice sweet finish.

Bottled(330ml). Shared with Doggythedog at the Hopdevil in Zagreb
Hazy golden coloured, huge white head, dusty spicy nose. Aroma is malty and hoppy with good spicy and slight yeasty notes. Touch of vanilla. After Prior and Abt 12 this was quite letdown.

Bottle shared with ozujsko at the Hopdevil in Zagreb This poured a big to huge thick white head that left enormous, pretty lacing on all sides of the glass. Quite light brown hazy body. The nost... yeasty dust, a touch of coriander. Blah. Could be better. The taste is .... hmm. Its quite good actually. I liked this quite a lot more than ozujsko did. Good maltiness, dust, noticable hopiness, spicey. Lovely smoothness. A hole where an aftertaste should be. Not the most impressive Tripel Ive had, but far from the worst. We mightve had it too warm too.
Bottled. Hazy golden coloured with a medium sized head. Sweet and fruity with notes of spices and honey and maybe hints of yeasts and raisins.

Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a big white head. Complex aroma with grassy hoppiness, spices (coriander?),and yeast. Doughy notes. Dough flavours with hints of gingerbread, alcohol, dry grassy hoppiness. Full-bodied, soft and dry mouthfeel. One of the most complex tripels around.

Pours a hazy pale gold with a huge foamy white head.  Very complex aorma with a warm sweet yeastiness, flowery aromatic hops, bubblegum and some slight spice.  Classic belgian yeast flavors upfront with lots of bannan/bubblegum esters, a little bit of honey, failry strong alcohol and golden raisins.  Nice creamy medium body with lots of soft carbonation.
Poured an orange-yellow-amber, with an average white head.  Visible sediment.  Smell of malt, and alcohol and some spice.  Flavor of hops, yeast, spice, fruit and malt.  Good on the palate.
love these happy monks on the label, good tripel, pale golden, nice spice aromas high carbonation yeasty but soo good
pale golden color with a wispy white head.  aromas of spice and slight alcohol.  bubbly mouthfeel, highly carbed.  spicy taste, stone fruits, esters and yeast.  nice trippel
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: On tap into small tulip, Falling Rock Tap House, Denver.  Pale orange beer with a thick creamy foam head of eggshell color, somewhat rocky.  The head begins to leave a beautiful doilie lace, although it turns sudsy later.  Looks much like Duvel.  Smells like cloves, corriander, peaches and cream, and graham crackers.  Creamy sweetness up front, watered-down orange juice in the middle which lingers into the finish.  The finish is also mostly peppery and long lingering, with corriander and a slightly charred driness.  The finish is wonderful, but the main thrust of the beer is lackluster, mostly containing the watered-down OJ and a pale attempt at complexity embodied in a darker dehydrated apricot flavor.  Light to medium body, a bit thin.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2006 ~12oz. bottle. Pours a medium amber color with a nice white head that lingers for a good bit. Nice lacing. Slightly hazy with some visible chunkies. Pleasant aroma with definite bready yeast and to me an odor that smells like grape juice. Medium bodied and well carbonated. That grape juice presence is also in taste along with some yeast. Decent bitterness lingers lightly on the palate. Quite enjoyable. 8/3/8/3/17

Numbers stand nearly the same on a small bottle opened in Dec. 06. Hazy, medium amber colored with some yeast sediment along the sides of the Chimay glass. Long lasting white head and nice lacing. Aroma is pleasant, bready and still that grape juice quality in taste and flavor. Medium bodied. Really quite a pleasant and balanced tripel to drink. Well done.

Pours from the bottle to a hzy golden orange with thick white head that stays for the whole beer, and reduces to excellent lacing. I noticed the strong hoopy dark fruit aroma as soon as I opened the bottle. Flavor was more of the same, yet with a nice blend of citrus fruit, similar to an IPA. Beer finished off to a perfect palate, where the hoppy bitterness mixed well with the 8% alcohol and a hint of malty sweetness. A most excellent beer.
Hazy yellow. Fruity aroma. Peppery wheaty arom as well. The flavor is complex and have lot from fruits, yeast and bread. Some alcohol but it just makes this one better.

Deep orange-blond beer with almost a withe foam. The nose is fruity, peaches and cookies with a yeasty caracter. The taste is smooth and has hints of bread, dry fruits and yeast. Nice spice and soft hops in the end.

11.2 oz bottle:  Pours a dull hazy orange with minimal head.  It has the thick yeasty bits typical of most St. Bernardus beers.  This triple is nicely balanced with a sweet start and a mildly spicy finish.  Alcohol blends in quite well.
Deep golden color, slight haze, high rocky head. Fruity and savory malt aroma. Velvety mouthfeel, big bready maltiness and sharp yeast. Quite bitter, some alcohol. Long bitter but malty finish.
Citrus aroma, sweet, spice, corriander.  Pours yellow with a huge white head.  The flavor is crisp, sweet, some spice.  And it feels light on the palate.  A great triple!

33cl bottle at Pub Italia, Ottawa. Hazy golden with a minimal and long lasting white head. Aroma is malty and spicy with citrus and yeast. Taste is similar as the aroma with a creamy mouthfeel. Excellent.

Ive never seen so much unfiltered goodness.  There were a frightening amount of chunks floating in the glass after I poured the bottle.  Very spicy!  Excellent as it got warmer...like a meal...only liquid and refreshing.  Warmed my head fast too, at 8% .

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2006 Pours a hazy deep golden with a thick white head. Huge aroma of date-like fruityness. Upfront fruity notes of figs, banana?. Nice nutty element as well, along with some belgian yeast and has a late smooth, light bitterness. Nice tripel.

small bottle.  Purchased at the Holiday Wine Cellar in Esconcido, CA.  This brew pours a slightly cloudy straw color, with a large pillowy head.  The aroma is light, slighty sweet, and citrusy.  The taste mirrors the aroma and has nice citrus notes and is very drinkable and nice on the palate.  This is a solid quality tripel, yum.
[75 cl bottle] Golden, hazy colour. Huge head. Fruity, yeasty aroma with notes of citrus. Tastes pretty much as it smells. Very easy drinking.

Pours a golden/amber color with a medium lasting head. Big fruity aroma, sweet flowers and maybe some honey. Flavor is sweet and malty with a kick of yeast and spice in the finish. Overall a good beer but there are better out there.

Golden colored with a thin white head that maintains til the end. Sharp, woody carb melts away leaving a yeasty banana. Wonderful stuff! This hits all the right notes. Sweet fruit never overpowers. Balance is perfect with refreshing carb giving way to sherbet smoothness.
Poured a cloudy amber color.  Aroma was frutiy/yeasts and spices.  Flavor was much the same with a flavor that i couldnt pick out that wasnt good.  Good beer but have had better tripels.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2007 Bottle, side by side with Mad Bitch, and this is better.  Bright honey color with a white head and good retention.  Nose is yeasty, mildly sweet, clean, fresh.  Flavor is balanced and nothing is overly pronounced.  Silky and smooth with great carbonation.  A very good tripel, balanced and delicious.

This brew poured a nice dark golden color...initially fairly clear but became quite hazy with the addition of the sediment on the bottom of the bottle.  A very modest and well-balanced aroma of yeast, malts, some subtle hops, citrus, and a general fruitiness.  Flavors were similarly well-balanced:  yeast, malts, hops, fruits (citrus, green apple)... it all comes together perfectly.  The texture of this beer is strangely velvety and soft--it seems to almost turn to a very fine foam when in the mouth.  Overall an amazing, possibly archetypal example of the style.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: I was a bit stuffed up during this tasting so the scent was difficult for me to accurately determine.  What did come through was yeasty, wheat with fruity banana and apple with a nice hop scent.
Appearance: Hazy golden orange with small to medium bodied sediment floating throughout the beer.  For some this might be a turnoff but for me it just makes it interesting.  The head was a bright white in color that sustained somewhat throughout the glass.
Flavor: Quite yummy sweet yeast with the fruits again coming through nicely balanced with the hops.
Palate: Fnished nicely with a medium body and some bite along the roof of my mouth.  Not bitter or overly sweet either.  Balance is an important theme with this brew.
Overall: A truly quality Belgium Tripel.  This is one that you can use as a standard bearer for the style.

Bottled. Hazy honeyish golden colour, mediumsized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity, a bit spicy and aa bit hoppy. Smoother than many other tripels. Flavour was very smooth caramel, fruits, spices and hops. Very nice palate, and one of the best balanced beers I have had in a long time.

orange/golden color with a small white head. aroma is fruity, spicey, sweet, and sour with a nice hop backbone. typical tripel nose, but balance is just right on this one. palate is grassy, lemony, malty and hops. tasty.

Cloudy honey colored with a thin white head that maintains til the end. Sharp, woody carb melts away leaving a yeasty banana.  Wonderful stuff! This hits all the right notes. Sweet fruit never overpowers. Balance is perfect with refreshing carb giving way to sherbet smoothness.

Aroma: mmm, wheat, cloves, spicy, yeast, Duvel/Leffe, little berryish, apple peel, nice hops that makes the mouth water. 
Appearance: cloudy passionfruit-yellow, very beautiful, thich carpet of cream colored foam. Flavor: metal?, sweet, strange bitterness, soft. Palate: quite OK, fluffy, sticky, good amount of co2.
Pours a nice hazy gold into a snifter.  Bright white head quickly recedes to skim rim.  Fruit and yeast notes.  Active and dry.  With upfront fruit and a sharp finish.  Winner.

Bottle. Poured a great lemon-orange with some sedimentation visible in the pouring. Thick, dense, foamy head with a lot of lacing. Scents of lemon, yeast, some nutmeg. It does have a bit of a watery mouthfeel however it has a great balance of hops and malt. Very smooth and enjoyable.

25.40z bottle.Pours cloudy light amber with a very fluffy,white head that lasts and has lacing.Aroma of spice, yeast ,fruits,citrus,sweet malt and some hop.A bit thin tasting with a touch of lemongrass,malt and a lot of carbonation.

On tap at Belgobaren (Sthlm). Pale colour, clear (yes, my notes say clear, in contradiction to most reviews here.. Im confused too...) Malty aroma, sweet esters. Sadly, I found this a bit thin on the palate and lacking in complexity. Wouldnt mind a second sampling..

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2006 Pours deep, cloudy gold with thick, nearly-white head. Aroma is sweet, a little grassy, green raisins, clover honey, and alcohol. The flavor is fruity, very malty, some funky yeast flavors, and a touch earthy hops. Sweet in the beginning, like honey-glazed dried fruits in the middle, and dry finish. The mouthfeel is a bit thin for a beer of this strength and very strongly carbonated.
A pale triple with a very nice head. Good balance between malt sweetness and hops.
Man,this is no where the 12, not even close. Too bubbly for me but the flavor was just a bunch of mish mash for flavors,a bit of spice but more just like stale beer.

Bottle - Liked the Prior 8 so gave this one a shot.. Pours an almost hazy orange color with a small white head... aroma of yeast and spices.. flavor is a wonderful fruitiness with a moderate carbonation which makes it all the better.. dry finish... nice tripel

Bottle.  Fantastic beer!  Pours a golden, cloudy brown like a fresh cider.  Heavy head reduced to lumpy clouds of foam.  Aroma is yeasty with spicy highlights.  Taste is amazing.  Smooth on the front of the tongue, spicy in the middle, then malty and slightly sweet on the back.  Alcohol aftertaste is warm and pleasant, not overwhelming.  A second aftertaste is a tenderly sweet reminder that hits 30 seconds after the first taste.  Just a wonderful beer.

11.2oz, Best before end 13 04 09.  Pours a hazy golden with a mod-large white head.  Aroma is some citrus, dust, candy sugar, toffee, yeast, and maybe a tiny bit of alcohol.  Taste is more tart and alcohol is more present, though otherwise the flavors are the same as the aroma.  Lightly bitter dry finish..  Medium bodied, mod-high carbonation.  Not my favorite tripel, but still a solid brew.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: A nice beer to take your time with. This is  the first beer from this brewery I have tried and I am definitly impressed. I could taste the alcahol but it was still relatively smooth

From a slender 33 cl. brown bottle with a best before date on the back label, 26.01.08.

Poured a cloudy amber hued orange with a foamy white head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing, small amount of ringed sticking.

Aromas of apricots, pears, apples and caramel toffee.

Good carbonation and a smooth, creamy full bodied mouthfeel.

Nice tripel taste, fruity, apricots and pears, candied sugar, a soft bitterness from the hops, caramelized toffee, the alcohol is a bit spicy, fruity and provides a nice warmth in the palate, and a dryish sugary and bready finish, very good tripel drinkability.

This is a dangerously quaffable tripel, one of the better one Belgian tripels.
Tripels in general are not a preferred style for me.  They tend to be too floral and dry.  This is a well-rounded abbey tripel that was generally pleasing and another quality brew by St. Bernardus.

A slightly hazy golen colour with a 2 finger thick fluffy white head that all too soon disappears to nothing (my bottle?) Lovely sweet fruity spicy aroma with a similar if slighly effervescent taste. A great beer let down only by its flat appearance.

Pours a nice gold, with a quickly dissappearing head. Bready on the first taste. as it warms, earthy, with a hint of sourness. Alcohol is there, but not dominating. A nice sipping beer and a nice day!

From the 33cl capped bottle.

Pours a hazy, deep golden hue. An inch thick frothy head that leaves sheeting lace. Smell is fruity and lightly spicy (Clove and vanilla). Hints of oak.

Taste is fruity and caramel malt. Really rich maltiness for a tripel and that oak is there again. Notes of sherry and candy sugar too. There is prominent alcohol n the mouth that helps to dry out the finish. Creamy and smooth, surprisingly drinkable and tasty. 

They do nothing wrong. I am slavishly devoted to drinking St. Bernardus beer.

Beauty.  Slightly hazed and polished bronze in color with a sudsy, densely packed and jiggly beige foam head.  Aroma is similarly stunning.  Baguettes freshly broken and sprinkled with powdered sugar.  Coriander adds a musty mystique while a nectary willow wheat stalk sings sweetly unto the nose.  Flavor doesnt disappoint.  Field house meets flour dusted potato rolls.  Granary delight.  Sweet vanilla and almond minuet colonizes a brittle spiced banana scone, flakey at first chomp.  Light rosemary and rose petal harmony.  Perfect carbonation plays with a husky coriander motif for a blanketing starch ensemble that makes the heartland fear a usurping power across the pond.  Balance is a symbol of effigy and symbiotic glory.  Bequeathed floral traits transcend artesian bakeries in the finish, painting a final portrait of pure pleasure on all accords.

I thing St Benardus is my favorite Belgian brewery.  Ive loved all of their beers.  Had this in a wine glass (thats all the beach house had).  Just a little bit of a head. Yellow, straw color with a strong floral and yeast aroma.  Not overpowering.  Much different than Allagash Tripel Reserve, which is great in its own way.  Taste has some banana.  Can taste/feel teh alcohol, but it doesnt detract fromt he beer.  I great example of a classic Tripel.

330ml bottle.Pours a hazy light gold with bits of sediment in suspension. Foamy white head forms on pour and refuses to go away. Aroma is a bit muted but otherwise pretty standard Tripel fare -- musty, earthy, herbal, modestly bitter, and revealing of a lot of sugary sweetness. Flavor delivers on the aromas promise, with the grassy, earthy, lightly flowery hops showing first, then a bit of light grain, and finally that sugary sweet malt. Medium body & tingly palate accompany a surge of hop bitterness in each swallow. A nice tripel that lacks the intensity found in the top examples of the breed.

Draft. Pours beautiful hazy honey-golden, with a tick, rich off white head. Aroma is light and complex, noting clove, pear, floral hops, honey, and yeast. The flavor is quite smooth, and dare I say refreshing (?) for an 8% tripel, with an herbal, floral, sweet combonation that finishes light, earthy, herbal, and utterly delicious!
Pours light yellow with thin fizzy white head.  Aroma is yeasty with lemon and citrus.  Slightly earthy.  Flavor is much the same as the aroma.  Sweet and malty with some earthy notes.  Tasty Tripel

Aroma is amazing with spice and sweetness all around pours a golden color with a pinky sized white head that lasted the whole time. This would have scored better if the taste lived up to the aroma. Beer was tasted at proper temperature. Perhaps this was a fluke and a re-rate is needed.

11.2 oz bottle.  Cloudy honey colored with a thin white head that maintains til the end.  Peppery pizza dough with traces of melon and porcini.  Sharp, woody carb melts away leaving a yeasty banana.  A little peachy sour with lingering marshmallow and nutmeg.  Wonderful stuff!  This hits all the right notes.  Light enough for summer but with a full mouth.  Sweet fruit never overpowers.  Balance is perfect with refreshing carb giving way to sherbet smoothness.

St. Bernardus Tripel pours a hazy yellowish-orange color with a bright white head. The head was very nice and left tons of lacing. The aroma, mouthfeel, and flavor were all the same--weak. This beer is very easy to drink, and it isnt bad--but I want more flavor out of a belgian in this class. One of my most dissapointing beer experiences yet."
Pours a cloudy gold with a lacy white head. The taste is sweet and creamy with toffee, bubblegum and cloves, and a lingering spice finish.
Bottle at Ølbaren. Light amber, white head. A good tripel, very nice carbonated. Citrus, yeast, hop, spicy, dry.. A good triple.
Bottle. Quite a typical tripel. Quite yeasty, with some stewed fruit and warming alcohol. Probably a little too raw for me, most tripels tend to be for me anyway.

cloudy golden with fine white head. Aroma & taste of spices/fruit & wheat. Very yeasty & malty. A little sweetness. Lively carbonated. Finish has a pleasant bitterness - could perhaps have had a more hoppy punch. Above average tripel!

amber pour with heavy carbonation and no head...wonderful fruit-filled aroma that begins light in spice and herbs, and finishes with alcohol and wheat...flavor begins with a lemon punch and finishes with a tonic water backbone (florals abound that finish dry and bitter, yet crisp)...nice tripel

bottle. Cloudy lemon pour with a dense, firm, white head. Aroma is sweet and full of yeast, lemons, bananas, and a far off sourness. Very palatable bright citrus in the mouth with an even level of banana sweetness. A bit of floral, spicy character is noticed throughout. Very delicate balance in this brew. Pairs quite well with the homemade garlic bread.

750mL: Pours a golden yellow-red color, extremely fizzy.  Very clear looking.  Big big head, slightly off-white, lasting.  Extremely floral aroma, dark fruit.  Similar aroma to Allagash Triple, one of my favorites.  Very floral taste, dark fruit, sweet, not thick, sightly creamy, smooth mouthfeel.  Floral afertaste.  Similar in almost everyway to Allagash Triple.

Bottle. White high and lasting head. Clear yellow body. Fruity alcohol aroma. Flavor too alcohol dominated if the intention was to make it fruity, only some dry hops bitterness apart from the alcohol can be tasted.
What can I say.  St. Bernardus makes a great beer.  The numeric beers are all great.  This is a classy triple with great flavor and aroma.  Not much else to be said.

Maybe I was expecting too much, given the impressiveness of the Abt 12, but this one was slightly disappointing for the style - a very nice beer nonetheless. Poured into my Chimay goblet a hazy orange amber with sedimentation on the loose against the rise of the carbonation bubbles. Aroma was lightly fruity and spicey with some yeast detectable. Flavor was malty with a unfortunate cardboardy taste behind it all - somewhat musty. It started mildly sweet and finished somewhat bitter (but lacking a sharp hoppiness that should be in a tripel) with lingering apples and oranges in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel was both carbonated and creamy (soft might be a good word for it below). Again, not bad, but Ill take Chimay White over this any day.

A large, white head stayed over a mid-golden & particulate heavy body. Yeasty dough & banana aroma with English toffee and light sulphur. A sharp palate stings as it bites the lips and tongue. Mid-bodied and fizzy mouthfeel.  Flavor finds yeasty sour fruitiness and stale caramel. Alcohol does not dominate, nor does it hide. Overall, I expected greater.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL 60462<font size=-1>
Golden color with some floaties. Large white head. Spicy/fruity aroma and taste. Carbonation seemed harsh. Dry finish.
A good tripel but i was a bit disapointed. Very fruity with the classical tripel tastes and and very dry finish. But this one is lighter in alcohol and flavour than some others.
Bottle:  One of my favorite Tripels.  Nice golden color, with a white fluffy head.  Very fruity, sweet smell.  The taste is awesome.  Nice and warm going down.  Pretty much a perfect Tripel.

Bottled.  Murky, light brown color with a white head.. Tons of floaties.  Sweet, sugary aroma with notes of prunes, grapes, raisins, yeast and leather.  Sweet malt flavor with notes of brown sugar and plums.  Dry finish with a slight astringency.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 11.2 oz bottle, best before 7/28/08.  Pours a cloudy dark gold with some yeast floaties in it.  The head is white and very bubbly.  It retains pretty well and clings to the glass.

The aroma is very spicy - cloves, banana, floral and earthy and a little honey.

The flavor is kind of musty, bready malt with a little spiciness, some bananas, some honey sweetness and a laid back bitterness throughout.  The mouthfeel is pretty full with some rather harsh carbonation.

Overall, its pretty good.  Its almost a little more saison-ey than triple-y.

Pours cloudy peach with a big, rocky, white head. Lasting with nice lacing. The aroma is big, fruity and sweet, candi, peaches, banana, tangerines and oranges. Flavor is golden raisins, oranges, candi sugar, caramels becoming slightly tart at the end. Suprisingly dry. Finish is dry, bitter and slightly metallic with some warming alcohol. Mouthfeel is light with lively carbonation.
Another fine example of a fine Belgian tripel, I tried it at Christmas and it went well with the smoked ham and Dijon mustard.  Good carbonation, nice amber colour and fruity with a yeasty finish.

Bottle: Nice white head with a deep amber and misty body. Fine carbonation. Aroma of fruit (citrus), bread and honey. Yeast and coreander in the flavour with a nice hoppy bite. Medium to full bodied. Slightly bitter/ sweet fiinish. An enjoyable classic tripel.

330 ml bottle courtesy jerc. Hazy bright orange colour with a mostly lasting fzzy off-white head. Strong citrus, lightly spicy, and light alcohol aroma. Caramel, sweet orange, light raisin flavours with a dry, light alcohol finish. Medium to full bodied with a very dry finish, slightly prickly mouthfeel.

Bottle poured at local pub tasting. Poured a golden color with a decent white head. Smells of banana, ripened beyond their prime. Tastes much the same, super ripened bananas.  Everything comes out with the right temperature. There is a lot going on.

750 ml bottle: Aroma of mellow yeast and mild banana with a slight sourness. Great looking cloudy golden pour with crisp white head. The flavors are the citrus/coriander and a nice mellowing honey that creates a great creamy texture on the palate. This is totally full bodied and so smooth on the tongue. A slight crispness on the end adds a nice twist. This is outstanding. No traces of alcohol. Even better as it warms. Delicious.

Aromas are pretty weak... bread, mild floral hops and a little yeast with some clove/spice in the background.  Hazy amber color with a massive foamy head.  Flavor is wonderful and it comes together nicely as it blossoms.  There is definitely a slight acidic, sour character under the surface, but it is brilliantly balanced by a honey and spice sweetness.  Top notch!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
An excellent beer that, true to Belgian (and especially tripel) style, is sneaky in both the complexity of its flavor and the strength of its punch. Creamy and full-bodied, but dry, effervescent, and even refreshing in its finish. A bit underwhelming in its first impression, but then transforms almost magically on the palate into a parade of well-balanced flavors--the usual cast of yeast- and malt- derived fruits and spices with just the right amount of tartness and bitterness to balance it out.

I was surprised on pouring the beer by how tame (and disappointing at first) were both its initial aroma and head. The first estery/phenolic whiff of fruits and spices was plesant but subtle and short-lived. Rather than a thick rocky head, the beer produced large bubbles that supported only a thin layer. But its effervescence never died down, and that thin head proved to be long lasting and left behind a modest collection of Belgian lace. The first wave of flavor is likewise a bit underwhelming, if only because the tart (not astringent) tingling of carbonation dominates. But as the bubbles settle down in the mouth, they leave behind wave after wave of harmonious flavors--none of which are unfamiliar in a Belgian but nor does any single note dominate.

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with white head. Standard tripel aroma of yeast, bread, citrus and spice. Slight sourness in the flavor, along with some fruit, honey, and spice. Dry and slightly bitter finsih. At 8%, I picked up some alcohol. Not bad, but I was expecting better considering how good the 12 is.
UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours a copper color with a white head. Aroma of spices, fruit, and alcohol. Flavor is smooth, citrus, fruit, and carbonated.

33 cl bottle. Unclear golden colour with a nice creamy white head. Aroma of yeast, bread, caramel, little sour, fruity and spices. Nice flavour of yeast, fruit, toffee and someway complex. Ends up very dry and nice.
Cloudy, light brown color.  Thin-to-non existent head.  Light bit of lacing.  Malty and yeasty flavors.  Medium bodied mouthfeel.  Very drinkable.  Surpised by lack of alcohol taste.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with big pillowy white head. The aroma is lemon zest, honey, and green wood. The flavor has a lot of honey and yeast at first, then some lemon kicks in. The finish is on the dry side and slightly vinous, with a few earthy tones. A tasty Tripel.
Murky golden color, slight candy nose, light hops with earthy taste but a clean creamy body, after taste bitter and sweet in the back Palate

Strong, spicy ale with a slightly fruity and hoppy finish.  Rather dry. I havent had very many tripels in my time, but this is the best one that Ive had.  Strongly carbonated, but not over-carbonated. It still tasted natuarally carbonated, unlike some cheap beers.  Pretty enjoyable, but for $3 for a 330cl, I probably wont get it again.
Pours a hazy gold with a large head. Big overripe apple fruit in the aroma. The flavor is fairly dry, and has a bit of bitterness in the finish.

Aroma is clean malts, pepper, coriander, a touch of fruit - possibly white grape and yeast.  Pours a nice golden color with a large head that goes down fairly quick.  Taste is very malty with spices high in the mix as well; there is a pleasing sweetness along with a spice aspect.  While in the mouthfeel there is a relatively high amount of carbonation, but it does not interfer with the flavors.  A very nice Belgium tripel from one of the top Belgium breweries.

A dry, spicey Tripel.  Pours a cloudy yellow with some orange haze and a lively white head.  Spice, clove, and yeast in the aroma as well as the flavor with a mouthfeel that doesnt become tiresome even though it is quite dry.
03-11-05 De Garre, Bruges. Cloudy warm orange colour, Large white frothy ice cream head, plenty of fruit flavours but hops and yeast backing this up very good.

The guy behind the bar insisted that this should be drunk at room temp, which i was highly against but bought it anyway. Aroma is herbal, grassy and honey. Taste is similar with a decent amount of bitterness and yeasyness as youd expect. I really dont like triples these days to its lucky its getting a 3.

Pours dirty honey colored w/ a malty sweet nose. Medium froth with medium hangtime. Medium nectar with ample residual effers. Flavors of malt, caramel, dried citrus fruit. Long tastey finish w/ a steely, peach pit bitterness and slight alochol flavors. Overall: a fantastic specimen. Highly recommended.
A bit more complex than their Watou triple.  Flavour is earthy and has some nice bitterness.  Nothing too special.  Aroma is light with a balance of hops, yeast, and alcohol.
Belgian candy, peach, apricot, bananas in the nose.  Very nice bouquet!  Flavor is more of the same.  Delicious!

Bottle. Pours a clear bubbly golden-orange with an average size foamy white head. Sweet sugary aroma with yeast, fruit, honey and spices. Dry flavours a nice blend of yeast, sweet malt, fruit, alcohol and spices with a finish of light hops and a slight tartness. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Medium bodied. Another fine beer from St. Bernardus!

Pours a cloudy golden orange and has a bit pillowy white head.  Arom a is baked lady fingers, sweet honey, yeast, and spice.  Flavor is sweet chinese restaurant oranges, dry floral spices, subtle sweet malt, and a late coming hop bitterness.  Mouthfeel is very rich and creamy for a tripel...also very dry.
11.2 oz. bottle in a St. Bernardus Trappist glass.  Pours a cloudy tan, almost khaki with a 1 inch head.  Has hints of wheat, yeast and alcohol.  Sweet and tart with a light smooth finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Pours a gold/amber with a small white head. Nose is fruity and pretty typical of a triple. Flavor is fruity with hints of orange and spice.  Very good overall, but not the very best triple. Still better than most other beers.
Pours an almost clear warm yellow with a white head. Sweet with yeast aromas. Hints of sweet liquirish. Slightly creamy texture. Low carbonation. Short dry (and mild) finish.

Bottle.  Pours golden blond color with a medium bubbly white head.  Sweet, fruity and spicy aroma.  Some oranges, lemons maybe a little ginger.  Taste is kind of funky.  Some bananas, cloves, some over ripe dark fruits.  Smooth and velvety, creamy.  Fairly light body and easy drinking.

sweet, spicy, lemony aroma with some alcohol.  pale golden color with a large frothy foam head.  slightly bitter, spicy, candy banana flavor.  light body and palate.  lacks the smoothness of maybe Karmeliet, but still pretty good.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2014 Re-rate.  Bottle.  Hazy golden with a firm, rich white head.  Yeasty and fruity nose, spicy with wheat, heavily malty and sweet.  Quite spicy, almost exaggeratedly, and slightly warming.  Mouth is full of sediment.  Sweet maltiness and a very dry finish.  This did gain a few points from last rate, but it seems a little rough around the edges, a little harsh. [2006.03.09: 3.5]Re-rate, bottle best by 02 10 15.  Nose is sweet pale malt with yeast, lemony citrus, and has this great "it" character somewhere between orange peel and Lucky Charms.  Pours golden with above-average carbonation and a soapy bright white head.  Smoothish light-medium body, somewhat sugary but not all that sweet (certainly not cloying); has a bit of heat, perhaps more than Id like tonight, but still solid for a Tripel.  Slight tang and good candylike edges, not berries or other noticeable non-citrus fruit, but sticky lips with light vanilla and a good malt profile.  Very spicy, low bitterness.  This really has great harmony, a welcome step up from the disappointment I found in the Eight earlier tonight.  [2014.05.02: 4.0]

330ml brown bottle. Golden-honeyish in colour, spare but creamy white head. Some floaties. Aroma is sweet and spicy, fruity malt with soft orange notes. Strong malt profile with honey overtones contrasts with tangy yeast, fruity orange and nice late hop bitterness. Slighly spicy end with minimal alcohol notes and some yeast in the finish as well. Finely carbonated, creamy smooth texture in the mouth. Very well done Tripel.

I had this from a 750 ml corked and caged bottle.  There is a monk on the label and it says Belgian Abbey Ale and Watou on the label as well.  On the back it says, "Best Before End: See Top So, I did.  Unfortunately the date did not get printed correctly on top of the cage.  I could make out the number 27 sitting on top of 5:22?!  You can also see the yeast sitting at the bottom of the bottle.  

I poured this into my St. Bernardus snifter.  This Triple is a cloudy golden color and it formed a nice thick foamy head.  It looked very inviting.

You can definitely smell the spicy aroma before it even gets to your nose.  There are hints of fruit and malt in the aroma as well.

There is a bit of a citrus bite upfront and then the spicy flavors come into play as it wanders around your teeth and gums.  As you swallow it, Wow!  You get a spicy fruity creamy flavor that just makes you want to have another swig.  It is very nicely carbonated and feels light and creamy on the palate.
Slight golden colored pour with a large head.  This had a little spicy aroma to it, with a nice flavor.  Im a big fan of the tripels and this was another one.

Pours w/ much head, gets chucky and lasts. Golden, yeasty ale.  It is just really too strong for me,  theres nothing to hide the alcohol here. Great yeast strain, poor malt choice. bottle, proper glass
Bottle. Hazy golden beer with a big white head. Spicey/yeasty aroma with some banana and sweet malt. Yeasty, sweet malt flavor with some breadiness. Finishes dry. Slight soapiness.
Really liked this tripel. Rich in flavor, almost a pilsner in color, VERY RICH HEAD that laced beautifully down the glass. Alcohol was there. Better than Omegang Hennipen .

Poured from bottle into shaker glass.  A profuse fizzy white head developed on top of the hazy golden body.  Aroma was yeasty and of bright citrus fruits. Ienjoyed the flavor, but had a difficult time figuring it out because of the crazy- high carbonation levels.  This is very drinkable and light when compared to its relatively strong abv.

Poured from the bottle into a trappist glass, this beer looks great! Its a cloudy orange color and it has a nice big, white fizzy head that lasted for a long time. It smells of yeast, citrus and spices. Very pleasant and easy to drink, lots of fruit and sweetness. The alcohol is hidden well. Very good!

Bottle.  Bloudy gold with 5 mm white fizz head.  Yeasty spicy aroma, andied apples, cinnamon, brown sugar, banana.  In the mouth, its a dry-sweet mix of those flavors.  Slightly on the plain side of triples.

Very similar in appearance to the Watou tripple that came in the same gift pack.  No strong scent that sticks out.  Fairly subtle taste going down but a complex aftertaste.  Really little alcohol taste.  There was a taste I didnt like in this though, think it may have been gapefruit.

Cloudy golden body with a large fluffy white head.  Nice and refreshing aroma of citrus and yeast.  Nice balance of sweet malt taste with some tartness.  Very full, smooth body.  Short spicy hop finish.  Alcohol very well hidden.  Very nice.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2007 St. Bernardus may be a faux-Trappist brewery, but that hardly makes them any less of a brewer.  Its quite the opposite, actually.  St. Bernardus with its avuncular monk has, to my personal tastes, risen above the traditional Trappists to make comparable or superior beers.  This especially holds true for the St. Bernardus Tripel, an obvious improvement over its blue-blood Westmalle cousin.
