The aroma centers around the lighter and sweeter fruits, like apple and banana, and implements a little brown sugar for a cooked variant on the fruit smell.  The head is, like many other Tripels, cream colored and gently floats atop a faded dandelion colored and semi-cloudy beer.  The taste is rich and smooth, with a current of sweet flavors slowly transitioning to a toastier bread taste.  The texture conforms perfectly to the taste, and allows the Tripel, sometimes an overpowering drink, to get taken down an eager gullet.  Im usually a fan of the dictum where food is concerned, that the original or genuine brand is the best.  However, this is certainly not the case with St. Bernardus: it may not be an official monastic community of Christian beer minded men, but it brews up a good drink all the same.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007 Jan 21 06. Relatively fresh bottle.
Pours a lightly hazy gold with floaty bits and a fine and  long-lasting white head. The aroma is belgian yeast and lemon, with a bit of leather. The flavor is a full, rich belgian tripel: orange and lemon, honey, mild spices on the uptake, turning somewhat sour and then with a hint of alcohol burn leading into a pleasingly dry finish. Mouthfeel is finely carbonated and lively, the liquid buttery but not cloying. 
A pretty impressive beer. 8/3/8/4/16=3.9

Dec 12 07 Roughly two-year-old bottle. 
This time around Im much less. Banana esters dominate the nose; some orange blossom, some pear. Honey (flavor, not sweetness) dominates the front end of the taste profile; an elegant subtle bittering closes it (that is one nice detail) nudged gently by hints of sour. But the flavor itself seems thin and weak. I can feel the heat here but Im not getting flavor to match. Id have rated this 7/3/7/3/13=3.3, a pretty low-ball rating for this beer. Ill shade the original downward somewhat but Im not willing to pull it even half way until I try another fresh bottle and feel similarly. Hard to tell whether my previous rating was naive and overly generous, or whether this simply ages poorly.
Bottle.  Orange, lemon, apple and malt aroma.  Cloudy orange tan with nice head.  Orange-apple flavor with moderate bitter finish.  Nice fruity tripel

Pours hazy golden with a large layer of minuscule bubbles.  Excellent head retention.  Aroma is spicy and earthy with cloves, citrus, yeast, honey, bubblegum.  Lots of fruit and floral hops in the flavor.  It tastes of lemon, pineapple, banana, honey, and lots of grains.  The grain taste overpowers the fruits just a bit.  The tripel starts of sweet and fruity with lively carbonation on the tongue, and then finishes slightly dry and bitter with several spices in the aftertaste.  Overall a very good tripel.

I love a tripel, and to me, this is one of the best! huge head, some of which quickly deminished, if I were forced to be tough on the review, it might be to say that it was slightly overspiced, but what the hell do I know

Notes from Decatur Beerfest 05.  Bottle pour, hazy golden pour, huge white head.  Very spicy yeasty nose - lemons, sweet honey, clovy, floral and herbal.  Light caramel malts underneath the yeast and spices make the flavor very nice.  Pleasant light bitter bite, and alcohol is not upfront.  Very good beer.

Pours slightly hazy beautiful golden with very fine, medium off-white head that laces well, small bubbles rising from the bottom of the tulip glass.  Nose is sharp, spicy, and very yeasty.  Sweet burnt marshmallow flavor, mixed with honey,  that segues into a very strong wheat taste, then to cotton candy, crysanthemum, pepper, cinammon.  Nicely bitter finish, with bitter floral tones.  Bitter and yeasty aftertaste.  ETOH character subdued.  Pretty good.

Props for the beautiful silkscreened bottle. Pale sunshine gold with light haze. Active rocky head; the fusilade of bursting bubbles sounds like rain on a tin roof. Almost no lacing. Promising "farmhouse" ale nose displays spicy/earthy phenols, yeast, bubblegum, and lemon zest. Flavor starts well with subdued crackerjack caramel and nuts, honey, malted milk balls, flowers, and galangal (a white-peppery/gingery spice). The beer finishes off-dry, again with earth and spice; also chammomile and hyacinth, and a tame leafy bitterness. Medium-light body is airy, gritty, and electric with needle-sharp carbonation. The CO2 accentuates an annoying blood-iron tang that remains on the tongue and erases the beers more pleasant assets. Begins nicely, but is overwhelmed by metallic taste. May have rated better as a saison.

St. Bernardus is one of my favorite breweries, so I couldnt pass up the opportunity to try their take on the Tripel - a style which Im growing to like more and more. Pouring into my trappist goblet produced an opaque titian tint topped of an airy cobweb-like head. As the foam quickly fizzed away, bubbly lacing was left clinging to the glass. The nose is sweet and full of the common esters: banana, bubble gum and pineapple. Some citrus fruits such as orange and mandarin appear subsequently in combination with mango, apple, caramel, biscuits and pepper. Truly a mouth-watering fragrance! The flavor was more lucid than I anticipated, losing some of its fruitiness to grains, especially corn and wheat. Honey, banana and some citrus are still present but seem a bit dilute. The alcohol is not aggressive but definitely present in the taste, giving a fairly full-bodied texture even though the flavor is a bit watered down. I was a little disappointed with St. Bernardus effort on this one but it is still a great beer that leaves a smooth and refreshing aftertaste in the mouth and a pleasant warming in the stomach.

12oz bottle @ tap room detroit. Pours a dark brown color with a foamy off white head. Nose has light citrus fruit, yeast, and honey in it. Taste is a bit citrsuy with more yeast and honey, some raisins and grapes, and a light alcohol in the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2007 Pours golden with a big foamy white head in the St.Bernardus glassware. Near perfect head retention.Aroma of bubble gum, mangoes, peaches, and cotton candy. Taste is sweet and yeasty with notes of bubble gum, honey, chamomile, and a touch of spicy alcohol. Mouthfeel is light bodied for a tripel, medium bodied on my normal scale. This beer is wispy like a cloudy. Refined and restrained, this beer is incredible.

(12.31.05) 11.2 oz brown bottle purchased from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 7.5% ABV. Bottle label states that the beer is best consumed before end of 2004. Clear golden Belgium Tripel having a large long-lasting head with good lacing.  Soft carbonation. Fruity toffee aroma. Full bodied that starts semi-dry with light malt sweetness and fruity flavor.  Finishes dry with light sweet malt aftertaste. Delicious, even though sampled one year past the expiration date.

Light citrusy lemon aroma.  It is like a subtle malt covered lemon-drop candy.   Cloudy golden, hay color with a thin white head that fades.  Flavo is sweet and lightly malty with hints of citrus initially, but it changes in the back of the mouth to have a nice toffee, caramel flavor with a  slight hint of dried fruit and licorice.  Full bodied, with an almost cloyingly sweet...not dry like you may expect from a triple.  Thanks to Brigadier for sharing.
dark gold pour, floating sediment, lemony coriander aroma, slight banana flavor, weak alcoholic presence, same yeasty coating on the finish as the 6, but doesnt last as long.

Poured a golden orange color with a light head and good lacing.  The smell was of grapes and toffee.  I picked up pepper, toffee, caramel and citrus with a slight bitterness.  It settled on the tongue with a roasted finish. There was a creamy texture that filled the mouth.  Overall, very excellent.

Courtesy of bditty187.

Pours a hazy orange color with a thick, frothy two finger head that slowly settles to soapy cap and leaves behind sheets of lace.

Smell; slighty peppery to start, and then some lemon zest comes through along with bubblegum and cloves.

Taste; the citrus flavors stand out up front (lemon & oranges), with a nice bit of bread dough in the middle and finishing with the peppery spices and cloves with a touch of banana pushing through. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy, with really nice carbonation.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Wow. Another great Ale from St. Bernardus. Bottle. Pours a nice golen brown  Nice aromo. Smells of yeast and fruit. You do not notice the alcohol in this very much. Would be easy to drink to many of them. Sweet fruity flavor but balanced very well. Another great job by St. Bernardus.
pours a nice golden color, with a lasting white head. tart, fruity, and sort of spicy. pretty sweet but enough bitterness/bite in it to balance it nicely.

Aroma is very fruity..pear and apple stand out and impart an almost vinous aroma. Hazy yellow/gold in color with a large bubbly white head. Very fruity and yeasty. Creamy even. The fruit components are more of the apple with a dollop of sweet cream thrown in. Very nice.

Yeasty, vinegary aroma.  Color is like that of a hot cider, head is about 3/4 inch of white foam.  Tastes faintly friuty, hops are not very strong but still present, surprisingly smooth for a beer of this alcohol level.  Alcohol flavor is barely noticable when compared with its cousin the Abt 12.
All in all an excellant beer, not as expensive as Rochefort Trappist Ale, so you can buy more. But, it is VERY good !!!!!

33 cl, smooth full-bodied tripel with surprisingly assertive bit of hops, and more than a little complex fruit character. Creamy and dangerously drinkable, I just cant knock what these brewers do. Quite balanced and worth buying several of.

Bottle - aroma is that of yeast.  A touch of malt.  Pure white head of creamy foam.  Dirty gold with tons of suspended floaties ... have you ever seen that in a bad beer?  Yeasty and fruity flavor.  Not quite as complex as expected, but still nice.  Full-bodied.  A very nice brew!

Cloudy orange colour with a fizzy white head.  The nose is yeasty and candyish, sweet with a nice tropical fruit presence - mango.  The body is strong with yeast, predominantly yeasty.  A bit too yeasty for a tripel if you ask me.

bottle in france 33cl, can aquire in maryland.  very sweet, not as carbonated as I would expect from a tripel, perhaps because I am use to sampleing tripels in the states where they have fermented more and lost sweetness.

Clear gold, poor head for a Belgian. Loads of candy in the aroma, spicy phenolics, vanilla custard, glue and perhaps lime rind. Pretty full-bodied and carbonation isnt all that high. Tastes quite sweet and candy-ish, with a tiny bit of earthy, minty hop. Very drinkable but not that exciting. A bit too sweet for mine.
A sweet and malty aroma with light carbonation.  Golden and cloudy in body.  Fruits and nuts are the primary tastes evident.  Very plesant ending.

Clear golden color with a rocky white head. Flowery aroma with hints of malt. Light spice flavor with malty notes. Pairs very well with a sharp cheddar cheese, which will bring out the candy sugar in the flavor

Dark gold in colour with high carbonation. Aromas are of light and slightly sweet malt, black pepper, and touches of grassy hops and banana. The flavors are somewhat fruity (a bit more banana and apricot) and sweet, but are balanced out by some spicy yeast notes. A bit of alcohol warming, but nothing over the top in that regard. No surprises, but this is a well made, balanced tripel.

Pours honey-gold with a huge head that keeps growing long after you stop pouring. Aroma of hay, grass, bread, and yeast. Some alcohol and pepper. Very mellow flavorl. Yeasty and spicy, with a light hop aftertaste and a little alcohol warming.
Bottle. Aroma seems a little oxidized. Nicely bready flavour, not very peppery. Slightly swelling mouthfeel. Finish is a little dry.

Pours hazy citric gold brown ale. Large frothy head. Refreshing, yeasty aroma, with such potency yet soft and gentle. Meadow flower. Yeast, clean smooth body, hints of spice, just shade of alcohol in background. Drinkabitiy is superb. I am not sure how they have done it but they did it. Silky smooth Belgian ale, seamless blend of flavour. Very clean work I must repeat. Highly recommended.

Hazy golden honey hue, with a white head, yeasty, fruity, candied oranges, bready, sweet pale malt, with a honeyish accent in the nose, follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a fruity, yeasty note, with a honey touch, mouthfell, an a peachy fruitiness, with an alcoholic warmth, leading towards a sweet candied citrus fruits in a dry finish.
Beautiful hazy old-gold colour with a small head. Aroma very sweet and fruity with grape and kiwi. Taste has a yeasty start and a bitter aftertaste. Whats that in the middle? Banana, pear, citrus?

Draught at Tylers in Durham, NC. Cloudy brown color with tan head that laced the glass. Malty, floral nose with hay undertones. Sweet malty flavor with alcohol and vinegar underones. Cotton candy sweetness lingers. Very good beer.

huge white frothy head foggy apple juice appearance, sweet yeast nos, very creamy mouthfeel, bitter dry finish w/ slightly warming, generally sweet and not too complex array of flavors present, alc is well hidden

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 Brown colored, medium lasting yellow head. Aroma is sweet with grains, brown sugar, mild alcohol and spices, maybe too sweet for my taste. Medium bodied. Very sweet, yeasty flavor, nice warming alcohol in the end with some spices.

330 mL bottle.  Poured a beautiful hazy, medium copper/amber with a nice, creamy 1" beige head.  Nose picked up a wonderful bouquet of light fruits, cloves, pepper, some citrus, and a sticky underlying caramel sweetness.  Mouthfeel was quite creamy and really coated the taste buds with all its goodness... and just the right amount of carbonation kept it moving.  Subtle hoppy bitterness graced the tip of the tongue and returned for the finish, and the middle was chock fulla smooth malts.  Flavors included some light fruits (apple, green grapes, pears), spices (pepper and some clove), floral hops, caramel, and a yeast presence not unlike the Abt. 12.  My only gripe is that the fruit and other sweetness bunched up toward the back, and became almost cloying.  This was an excellent brew... get some!
Cloudy topaz color. Banana, white bread, and earthy aromas. Tangy feel. Comes off as being lighter than it is. Seems more like a Weisse.
Botttle. Yellow colour with a good off white mostly lasting head. Amora of citrus, hobs and fruit. Long lasting finish. Great beer.

Clear copper with a huge white billowy head. Aroma of spice, caramel and pear. Flavor has notes of caramel, clove, banana, apple, spices, yeast/bread and white grapes. Sweet and malty with  plenty of hop character to balance it out. Alcohol content very well hidden.  Medium bodied, smooth texture and lively, spritzy carbonation. Good stuff!

25 oz corked bottle.  Pours a yellowish copper color with a very thick white head. Unfiltered, with plenty of hops floating around.   Aroma is lemony with hints of fresh yeast, hops and flowers.  Taste is sour, dominated by lemon citrus and orange peel.  Very refreshing belgium tripel.

More and more I realize that Im really not a big fan of Belgian ales.  No doubt, this beer tastes good, it looks good, it smells good, but its so close to all the other abbey ales, is it really worth shelling out $5 for a bottle of t his stuff?  Only time will tell...   until then, more IPAs and Imperial Stouts and Lambiks!

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2005 Rich and fulfilling.

Light and refreshing.

Strong, yet unassuming.

The kick is in the alcohol, not the flavor.

.
UPDATED: NOV 10, 2005 Wonderfull appearence. Frothy excellent fully lasting head, light yellow colour, powerfull aroma, fantastic taste og yaest and hopp. Feels good too. A very very good beer.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 Orange hue. Light head. Slightly swet. Orange peel, honey, banana and clove. Crisp, balanced and refreshing.

I think Ill go with the 12-oz. bottles from here on out.  The 25-ozers are not quite balanced in their effect.  You have to get to about mid-bottle before the proper viscosity is attained, and once it is, its heavenly.  The aroma is mild but sophisticated.  The rest is simply divine when you get mid-25 oz.  The first third of the bottle is too full of carbonation and the liquid is moderately clear.  Then you finally get to the cloudy gold portion and its unbelievable, just what I crave in a Tripel.  Deep cloudy gold with lovely foam head, and then a fruity delivery.  Egregiously well-balanced between hop and malt, and some banana flavoring.  Smooth and creamy to the point of criminality.  The final third of the 25-oz bottle should be declared illegal its so decadent.  Im speaking purely figuaratively here, of course, being a radical libertarian in politics.  Legalize this stuff like crazy, and nirvana shall ensue.  Absolutely delicious; its almost like a direct experience of the Form of Deliciousness, but Im speaking purely figuratively, as an empirical realist in metaphysics.  Speaking as a eudaemonist in ethics, this beverage is integral to virtuous, happy living.  Drink up!
I shall note that this beer has the distinct advantage of being served in a bulbous glass with "Matou: St. Bernardus" printed on it, obviously quite specifically tailored to maximize its enjoyment and rating amongst Belgiasts.

Bottle (330ml).  At Ciros.  Poured bubbly hazy gold with a big foamy slightly off-white lasting head, decent lacing.  Aroma - ahh, thats a real trippel.  Ashy, spicy, banana, tobacco, sweet fruity malt, sharp yeast, and an odd note of hospital bandage on warming.  Taste very mild - follows the nose closely, initially a bit ashy and a whisper of hop bitterness, very spicy, but as it opens up it mellows out and finishes flat, blended and sweet.  Quite thick and sticky-sweet mouthfeel - a lovely trippel, couldnt ask for a lot more.
Again, yum, St. Bernardus is consistently good! enjoyed this one on the Block with TM over Catan. Dark, soft, full, a bit of alcohol, malt sweet.

11.2oz bottle. Best before 20/09/07. Served at 61° in my NB worthy glass. First pour is 4-5oz. Light golden color with a large, white head. Moderate carbonation visible. The aroma is yeast, tart lemon and citrus, vanilla, white pepper? Pretty nice (spicy) tripel smell. The flavor is vanilla (whipped cream), tart lemon, banana, yeast, with some spiciness and a bit of that alcohol (not bad). The finish is spicy and tart with some really nice lingering flavors. The mouthfeel is full with a good amount of carbonation apparent at first.

Pours with a golden body topped by a medium thick head with some lacing.  Its slightly sweet yet bitter with notes of clove, a touch of banana, and a little pepper.  Light to medium bodied, smooth and slightly dry.

Light apple, fruit, pear flavors.  Really lively, the alcohol being well hidden.  Some sour tastes -- grapes, white wine, also.  Really nice beer.  Medium haze apricot color.  Sweet cookie bread tastes.  Nice.

Opaque blonde bier, medium head. Some spices, but the aroma is overall very fruity and even has some hints of honey. The flavour has the same fruityness, sweet without any bitterness. This beer just misses something exciting and is dull for a tripel. Maybe because it was served on tap?

Orange/amber color with a tan head. Very crisp flavor with nice spice that does not overpower an underlying citrus, fruit, and vanilla. The alcohol is well hidden and it is very refreshing. I would recommend this,

pours a cloudy orange/fire color with a pretty thick head and very little lacing.  Fairly lite aroma with hints of cloves and alcohol.  CLove like flavor through-out with hints of vanilla, pepper and raspberries (??).

i was very happy to find this today as i love st b. brews.lets see if the tripel compares to the others.poured into a st bernardus trappist glass and was shown a super murky orange body with a thick,creamy white head that sat atop the brew nicely.i took a whiff and could smell apples,raisins,cookie dough,straw,and a tine bit of citurs.first sip was much of the same with a bit of honey and malt thrown in.man these monks sure do know how to brew a beer.this is yet another st bernardus masterpiece.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2006 Bottle poured cloudy gold with a white long lasting fizzy head. Aromas of cookie, perfume,pineapple and honey. Palate was slick and fizzy. Flavors of cookie, vanilla, lemon, and pepper with a sweet finish.

pours a orangish golden hazy color, with a decent sized white lasting head, typical belgian style aroma, spices, fruit, alcohol, sweetness. i thought an 8% triple would be weak though, i was wrong this tasted all of 10% and just like its aroma, just add some carbonation, not bad, but not as good as the quadrupel.

Keg @ Akkurat, StockholmBlonde with a white soapy head. Yeasty aroma. Sweet malty with vanilla and wheat character. Some light virginia tobacco is present and it is well balanced and quite refreshing for its strength.
Light aroma with faint hops scent.  A light coppery color with alot of yeast floating around.  Not much in the flavor department but it did finish with a sour aftertaste.
Clear gold . Light yeast aroma. Banana flavour. Alcohol is very subdued. Clean and fine drinking but missing some character.

As a tripel aficionado, I found St Bernardus a bit disappointing.  Dont get me wrong--it has an appropriate degree of strength and range of flavors to be worthy of the Tripel title--but there didnt seem to be anything distinctive to this specimen.  It lacked spiciness (though to be fair, I drank this after a Fin Du Monde which blows the lights out in the spice arena), and it also lacked much distinctive yeast or hop character.  Still, its respectable.
This was an excellent Triple. The smiling monk on the cover says it all.  Small head on a yellow body. Sweet caramel start, dry bitter finish.
1-Apr-05 Light hop & malt aroma. Orange brown hazy colour, giid head and lacing. Heaps o hops and spiritus, fruit malt. Nice hoppy bitterness light mouth feel. A bit simple but appealing.

A Mes rate: 
A fine tripel. One of the very best next to St. Feuillien and the Rulles. Initially let down a little by the poor head (I have had this quite often so I know its not a one off) but that soon gets forgotten once sampled. Typical tripel body but a little more cloudy than usual. Great palate with just right carbonation. Tastes just like a tripel should but not so much of the floral notes as others. Citrus and spice as you would expect. Lovely sweet finish. Great stuff all round.
Excellent tripel. Honey aroma, also some licorice. Next to Karmeliet Tripel this has to be my favourite one.  Quite bitter aftertaste.

Second sample in our recent "Weekend at Bernies".  Poured a golden amber with a decent white head.  The head dissapated in different areas, producing some highs and lows, interesting to watch.  Warm, malty aromas with bananas and bready yeast.  Sweet and spicy, with noticeable alcohol in the finish.   Good stuff.
Pours a deeper golden yellow with a nice head.  Aroma is kid of sweet and yeasty and flavor is sweet and the alcohol was smooth and not over powering

pours with a slightly smaller head than the petrus tripel did.  certainly a much better beer than the petrus was too.  a little darker yellow color, white head.  yeasty smell with some hints of malts in it.  taste is fantastic, easy drinking, smooth, sweet, and rich.  a very good example of this style.  most definately the best tripel i have ever drank.
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2017 Hazy golden color, moderate to small sized white head. Aroma is yeast, sugar, spiced, pale malt, lighter fruits. Medium bodied, dry, lightly yeasty.
[bottle from beer cafe] amber colour with a large lasting fluffy head. nose is yeasty and fruity with some spicyness in there as well. well bodied with a dry finish.

In the 330 ml bottle. Pours an unusual carbonation pattern: a ring of large bubbled nucleation sites at the bottom of the glass, followed by tiny lines of microbubbles rising to the top. Rich golden color with a pillowy white head. Aroma of honey and green apples. Yeasty and mediciney sweet flavor. Back of the tongue residual bitterness finishes the job. Slightly harsher palate than some of its bretheren.

Bottle. Lively gold with two fingers of white bubbly head leaving plenty of lace and lasting well. Aromas of orange peel and spice with a sweet malty background and a slight Belgian funk, although a little more muted than expected. Taste was a little medicinal, with a sweet malty start, spicy middle and a very dry peppery finish with a light bitter hop punch right at the end. Alcohol was a little noticeble, but not overwhelming. Palate was creamy and light as it should have been. Competent Tripel.

Poured a cloudy golden color with a medium white head.  Aroma is yeasty with a bit of lemon and orange.  Flavor is fruity, orange, lemon, spices and belgian yeast.  Medium mouthfeel with good carbonation.

Pours a cloudy golden with a fair ammount of sediment and a nice airy off white head which resulted in notable lacing. Aromas of citrus spice and a little yeast. Good flavors including spices, fruits and a hint of malt. The finish was quite dry and left me traces of alcohol. Overall fairly solid.

Pours a beautiful honey gold hazy body with a thick white foamy head. Pleasant yeasty aroma with spicy and fruity (mainly banana and apples) notes. Taste is well balanced and hides the alcohol very well. It ends with a long bittersweet finish.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Best before:  January 18, 2008.  Honey pour with a thick, fluffy off-white head that leaves some thick lacing.  Yeasty aroma of yellow apples and spices.  Very hefeweizen-like in smell and taste.  Crisp, but with a notable presence of bland alcohol that warms near the end.  Creamy.  Light and airy banana flavoring along with some yellow apples and hints of nutmeg and other spices.  Quite refreshing for such a high ABV.

Apricot colored, clear and active with a large loose white head. Sharp and yeasty aroma with minerals and a little horsiness. Big fruity and alcoholic flavor finishing tart with a little bitterness and some candi sugar. The alcohol seems a bit pronounced to me.

Honey color with a white head. Aroma is most spices, but a light hint of banana, and yeast compliment the spice character. Good malt body. Spicey with lots of yeast, almost like spiced bread. Some slight hints of banana in the flavor as well. Very smooth and disguises the alcohol well. The maltiness of this one is quite pleasing.
Bottle. Golden colour with a white head. Malty yeasty light barnyard citrus aroma and a light alcoholic fruity taste. Medium to full body and a sweet light alcoholic finish.

Pours a very light dark yellow/light orange with a decent amount of lacy white head.  Lots of yeasty sludge at the bottom.  Aroma is sweet, a bit carmely and citrusy.  A little too carmely for my liking.  Flavor goes down pretty good and overall masks the 8%, but theres something just not there to make this a great beer.  Still, its pretty good.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2014 Bottle.  Orange colour, bit ordinary really, nothing to get too excited about.  It does what you would expect from a tripel.  Some orangey sweet fruit mixed with a little toffee. Re rat. Belgian yeast orange fruit hop. Decent.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2005 Golden orange body with a large creamy white lacing head.  Citrus, caramel and a perfect touch of spice in both flavor and aroma.  Very nice, smooth, creamy palate with just enough carbonation to keep you interested.  Well balanced, sweet beer.  These get better every time I have one.  This beer is what I like about Abbey Tripels.  Glad I have a case of 750s.

Bottled at DBF 2005.
Clear yellow coloured with a white head.
Fruity aroma with notes of spices.
Sweet flavour of bananas and spices.
Slightly bitter finish.

Golden orange with a big ol white head.  Light floral and honey aromas.  Spices also.  Grassy and citrus flavors abound (I said abound).  Well carbonated.  Dances across the tounge.  Touch of alcohol in the finish.  Very nice beer.  Would recommend to anybody, especially at he 3.50 per bottle price tag.

(Bottle 33 cl) First impression is bubbly. Bubbles everywhere actually - this is extremely carbonated. Deep orange colour, almost bronze with a huge frothy head. Lots of malt with a pleasant. dry fruityness in the palate. 301093

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2005 Lots of fruit coming out in this one. Nice sweet Belgian Tripel. So far the best Abbey TripelsIve had. Very drinkable well rounded beer. Will have to pick up a few more of this one.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2013 Bottled.  A hazy orange coloured beer with a nice big long-lasting white head.  The aroma is spicy coriander with lemons and yeastiness.  The taste is full and spicy, a bit floral and perfumed too.  There is more citric fruits and a biscuity character.  Another top St Bernardus beer.  Score 3.9Subsequent rating scored 3.6. Average becomes 3.8
Pretty good, but drank it around the end of a ferm beer drinking session, so I didnt write anything down on this one, so I must retry in a better state of mind

Golden color with a thick white head that went away quickly. Gorgeous beer.  Spice, alcohol, and some fruit in the aroma. Flavor is loaded with apple and apricot with a spice and a malt finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Great beer.

Hazy golden colour with a big foamy white head. Complex aroma with lots of fruit (citrus & apricot) & spice (clove & anise), and some rye bread as well. Carbonation is lower than some other reviews here suggest - maybe it varies from batch to batch. Nice rouch flavour, with apricot, almond, malt, and bitter licorice in the finish. The finish is short at first, but once it warms up, it starts to linger. The first half of the glass didnt impress me that much, but it got better, and Im really liking it now as I get to the bottom of the glass. Thanks to Andicus for this one.
hazy golden with thick white head dissipates quickly. little lacing. aroma is earthy,  fruity and malty. taste is apricot and spice.  another great beer from st. bernardus.

From the bottle this pours a nice golden color, very clear with a fizzy white head. Very crisp and sharp tripel with a nice bitter finish. This didnt have the malt up front i was expecting, but a very dry tripel throughout with a very nice crisp snap to it. The spicing in the finish really made the fruit in the malts stand out.

My first Trippel (thanks Jeff) - Creamy mountains of foam  and loads of carbonation as well in the pour.  The prickly mouthfeel quickly expands and decompresses to become smooth and creamy.  Body is like banana cream pie in a glass.  The drinkability of this is just ridiculous.

Bottled (BBE 2004)
Hazy honey-orange color, good off-white color. Lots of floating yeast particles. Aroma starts metallic, then fruity- apricot, yeast, smoke, chestnut and anise - when it warms licorice.. Sweetish fruity: pear, typical St. Bernardus yeasty licorice flavor. Bitterish long aftertaste. Complex and rich abbey triplel.
Hazy pale yellow. Thick white (vanishing) head. Thick mouthfeel, full bodied. Sweet, fruity nose. Bitter flavour with segments of bananas. Very small hints of sweet liqorice. Slight citric.

The aroma is a nice mixture of butter, cheese, herbal hops and alcohol. It looks as good as nay I have had. It is a hazy but rich golden color. It has the nicest head a beer could have. It resembles a huge cream froth on a latte. The taste is everything you expect in a beer from Belgium. First you get a sour maltiness followed by sweet fruit, and some butter. Just a hint of spiciness that lingers into the aftertaste along with a return of the malt taste. Only moderately complex but perfectly balanced. Great beer!

Wow! This beer is GREAT! This brew is nice, creamy and is silky smooth across the palate. Has good fruity flavors mixed in with some candy like goodness. I am pretty amazed that this beer doesnt have a better score! (although 3.79 as of this review is respectable)

UPDATED: APR 9, 2005 Foamy snow white head, muddy orange body. Sharp fruity aroma, orange and citrus, with notes of cookie and yeast. Rather tame malt and fruit flavor with marzipan hints. Rather low on CO2. Alcoholic finish. OK, but not the most interesting tripel.

Poured a cloudy gold.  Nice large head that lasts pretty well.  There was some lacing down the sides of the glass as the beer was drunk.  Some particulate matter in the beer, but that just added to its character.  Smooth beer with a great taste.  The finish was ever so slightly bitter.  Great beer.

Hazy golden hue that was topped by a big fizzy and frothy white head and very good lace. The aroma has notes of candi sugar, caramelized malts, pear, apricot, floral and heather, star anise, white pepper, and a touch of wood. The taste starts malty and sweet with a dose of fruity twang. The finish is mildly spicy and a hint of alcohol. The feel is somewhat sticky on the lips but fizzy but the tongue. Nice brew, quite quaffable.

Aroma: light sweet malt and fruit. Apperance: poures clear orange wtih a great head. yeast makes it slightly hazy. Flavour: toffee, fruit, hop, alcohol. Almost simple but with massive flavour. Palate: light to medium mouthfeel with lingering alcohol and light malt.
Hoppy malt aroma. Yellow brown colour with good head. Smooth malt sweet flavour. Smooth palate.

Nice big head that lasts. Color is hazy yellow, very little particulate until the bottom of the bottle. Aroma and flavor are both straw and grass, with a slight yeast overtone. Nice clean beer that has no objectional flavors.
Blonde ale with a white thin bubbled head. Oxidized spicey malt aroma with gin alcohol. Light sweet malt, dryish, with light coriander and oxidation traces. Creamy mouthfeel and medium bodied.
Big fruity aroma. Cloudy gold appearance with a small white head. Smooth, light & dry to the palate. Lots of yeast & citrusflavor. Tastes much better as it warms up.

I hat to try zis bier be cauzen zat guy ont ze label looken like mein bruzzer! He was not him zhough. Zis guy vas a monk! Zhey be maken zum gut wheat bier. Plenty strong mit a nice body unt lastink head. Remindts me ov Helga, it does.Earlier Rating: 3/26/2005 Total Score: 3.7A good wheat beer. heavy body and a great head that lasts. typical tangy wheat flavor with hints of ester. A bit costly for simply a wheat beer unless you want the higher alcohol.

Aroma:Citrus fruit,spicy.....
Appearance:gold,very hazy with yeast....
Flavor:Citrus fruit,alcohol,malt and honey....

bottle at the Alex P Keaton in London. the aroma consists of pears, sour apples, and some yeastiness. pours a hazy golden colour with a thin medium white head. great mouthfeel, smooth, medium body. Flavour begins fruity and somewhat sweet and finish is dry and slightly sour. I thoroughly enjoyed this tripel last night with good company.

Nice beer.  Aroma is malty sweet and flowery with hints of fruitiness.  Appearance isnt anything special, just a regular amber color.  Flavor is nice.  Malty with a bitterish, citrusy flavor to it thats very easy on the taste buds.

Thanks Mark.Body: A pale yellow topped by a huge and foamy white head. Look at all this sedinment too, awesome. I have never seen black sediment before. Aromas are citrus, peaches, some malts. Taste is sweet and tart at the same time. Fruit and bitterness. Good. Finish is slightly boozey and bitter citrus. A good tripel.

Thanks to Mark from the Keaton for supplying this baby!
Pour a yellow body with an orange hue. Head is huge, as with most tripels, and frothy and looks to be bleached white. Nice looking black sediment sitting in the bottom. Aromas are subtle. Apricots, some malts, citrus, rum. Slightly sour, and some citrus flavours are present. Peaches, and sweet malts too. Good. Finish is smooth and creamy, alcohol not detectable. Would have liked stronger flavour and aromas. Still a good example.
Bottle.  Cloudy golden color.  Very nice spicy armoa.  A well balanced flavor of sweetness and bite.  Fruity flavor almost covers up the taste of alcohol.

I am not a fan of Tripels so this review may not be too accurate.  I was anxiously anticpating trying this beer after having had the ABT 12 (best beer in the world to me) and this beer was a major disappointment.   It is not too good and for the price it leaves a lot to be desired.

Cloudy amber-gold w/ creamy pale tan foam. Yeasty, malty, fruity, lightly spiced aroma of bubble gum, candy, citrus (lemon), cookie dough, coriander, & pepper. Soft, creamy feel. Yeasty, malty flavour w/ a warm, peppery finish.

Cloudy orange beer with lots of yeast in the bottle. Big white head, that leaves a nice lacing. Yeasty and alcohol aroma with hints of fruit. Sweet fruity flavor with some caramel notes and a slight alcohol finish.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2005 This became a saviour for me, the night before my wedding. An absolutely wonderful and defining Tripel. Poured into a tulip glass, a two-layered dense beige head formed atop an auburn-orange body. Poured the yeast pack in to give it a fine hazy glow, and preceded to take in the aroma. Intense smokey toffee and candi sugar sweetness dominated the low fruity esters, unusual nuttiness and alcohol and pepper spices. Similar in the mouth, sweet candi sugar was dominant, but balanced out with a mild peppery spice. Well rounded flavours of vanilla and yeast, citrus and floral hops, and nice alcohol warmth (no ethanol feel) made for a good complexity, yet smooth and creamy Tripel that was a pleasure to drink. Big flavoured in the mouth and long into the swallow.

Very nice tripel. Beautuful pillowy head with good release of gases. nice flora and spice notes with some light nut and toffee flavors good balance of malt and cnady sugar. fairly dry and hop spice finish . good mouthfeel and effevescence. one of the best balanced tripels.

"Bomber" bottle. I got to sample this from close to the bottom of the bottle, so it was cloudy and particulate with conditioning yeast. Smell of apricot and peach, with some spiciness. somehow its both slightly dry, yet distincly fruity in taste, and a bit grassy. Finish is slightly "juicy fruity."

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2005 large bottle. light color, cloudy, nice foam. bottle conditioned. aromas of fruit, honey and banana nut bread. rich happy flavors of honey, fruity malt, candy sugar, alcohol, and mellow bitterness. effervescent. finishes on the sweet end. simple wonderful tripel.

750ml bottle.  Cloudy light orange with a good creamy head and nice lacing.  Fruit, spice, and bread dough in the nose.  Yeast and spice in the flavor with a nice hop bite. Soft creamy texture with a full body.  Slightly bitter fininish. Great beer.

Hazy straw color with large bubbles.  Large bubbles with yeast spots on surface remain after 15 minutes.    Citrus and spice dominate this ale along with a nice alcohol profile.   LIght bitter finish.  That monk knows his brew.
Bottle. Even though I poured it into the right glassware, the head was less than I expected. Taste is light with spice, banana and grass. Mouthfeel is lively yet somehow something is lacking.

Bottle from qwak, consumed while watching HGTTG (bbc version.)  Cloudy orange, strong fluffy head.  Nose is yeasty, clovey, plum.  Strong clove flavor, earthy yeast, vanilla, grape skin and a slightly alcoholic finish.  Amazing creamy body
Hazy golden beer with orange shine. Puffy broken white foam. Hoppy and fruit touch in the nose. Soft full taste with some stonefruits and milkbread and vegetal bitterness.
Pours a light golden pale color with small lasting head.  Excellent carbonation.  Aroma is of alcohl, yeast, honey.  Taste more of same.  Exceptionally smooth.

Its a decent tripel.  Golden hazy brew meets superfluous head job.  The taste is all honey lemon and a sniff of booze.  Carbonation like champagne and a finish like morning dew.  A little sticky sweet, but well worth the tasting!

2004 bottle.  Pours with high carbonation and an amber brown, light body look.  Aroma of tart apples and peaches.  Taste is light with slight malty flavors of citrus.  Very smooth and quenching with a crisp finish.  Very carbonated with lots of head and small particles in suspension.  Good triple that had no flavor of alcohol.  Nicely balanced nose and finish.  Good ale.

Pours honey gold with a medium sized small beaded big lacing head. Bread and lightly toasted grain aroma with a good whiff of alcohol. Clover and grassy, honey particularily cleaner than what was shown on the nose. Lemony sweet finish. Good example of the style.
Pretty nice beer. Since I think this is my first trippel Im ceartain I have to try more of these. Is it citrus in the taste.....after all not a bad idea
Pours dark yellow with a big white head.  Yeast, citrus, and coriander in the aroma.  Dry, well carbonated, but a little thin.  Decent Tripel.

Lots of yeast in the aroma, citrus and malt too. Golden amber, pouring a large white head. Tastes of orange zest, malt, then bready, followed by lemon. Well balanced, full bodied, tart and dry. Terrific!

Bottle: Poured lightly hazy dark yellowish ale with a super huge head with excellent retention. Carbonation was extremely good and body was a thinner then expected. Aroma is quite particular with some weird but enjoyable sweetness (like some crazy candy my kids would love) and good strong malt. The sweet malt dominates taste with some undertones consisting of soft spices, candi sugar and yeast. Wow, this one was quite a surprise and probably ranked very close to my top Abbey Tripel.

slightly hazy gold with faomy white head.  spicey aroma with pepper and coriander and lots of mixed fruit.  some biscuity malt flavours and some soft honey notes up front.  finishes fruity and appley.  a very fruity, but very tasty take on the tripel.  well done.

Poured slightly hazy gold with a huge white, long lasting head. Fruity aroma, with spices coming through too. Light caramel notes, honey too with a dry spicy finish. Smooth feel, medium bodied. Not bad.

Bottle:: into St Bernardus glass. I think Ive got the pour into this glass down. all in with one shot and head stopped short of the lip. woot. Poured a brandy sorta gold.  Nice white head and lots of lacing. Very very smooth fruit aroma and taste, add the honey please. Very easy on the mouth and rather warming. enjoyable for its lack of complexity.:)

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2008 Dont let the fact that this brewer has only been brewing since 1946 fool you.  These guys are good, and this brew is a fine example of that skill.  Smooth, warming, and quite sweet.  Good, good, good.  Peachy aroma with a dash of fresh grapes/raisins.  Beautiful cheddar orange body with a luscious and full white head.  Bready notes along the tongue that slowly give way to peach, strawberry, and a touch of raisin.  Full and slippery mouthfeel.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle.  Dark yellow colour, nice sized white head.   Really fruity aroma, with subtle alcohol and spiciness.  A fine malty taste, delicately balanced with the alcohol to produce a beer that is hard to describe except to say exceptional.  My only debate is whether I like the 12 or this better but regardless, but recent exposure to this brewery has been an eye opener.  Of the highest quality.

Golden yellow bodye, moderate fluffy white head (3+)Sweet malty aroma contains honey and ambrosia, teasing you sweetly before giving way to a slide into and alcoholic haze. Alcohol notes run the risk of becoming belligerent but restrain themselves nicely. Flavour is delicately balanced between sweet malt and a dry alcoholic undercurrent. Pure tripel essence encompasses a range of flavours not done justice by mmy attempts to pull them apart from each other. Palate is smooth, medium to full bodied. Yummy and delightful. Thanks again Tupalev!

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2005 Hazy yellow/golden, nice white head. Malty aroma with some nuts. Fruity from tropical fruits, peach, melon and pear. Some smoky touches, vanilla and marcipan. Fruirt, malty flavor with some wheat, peach and melon, yeasty and without very much bitterness.

Draught at RFDs thanks to eyedrinkale: Golden blonde color with a nice frothy white head.  Nose is light, with notes of malt, yeast, vanilla, wheat.  Taste is very crisp with notes of light fruits, yeast, sticky light malt, and is slightly acidic just like the descriptions says.  Nice.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2005  Very creamy head.  One of the creamiest I have ever seen as a matter of fact.  The aroma is dominated by malt but has wine, orange, wheat, vanilla and mocha.  The malt is the best from this brewery.  The yeast is also really beautiful to look at.  The flavor is spectacular because you get this orange, vanilla and wine sensation in the mouthfeel.  This beer is really impressive and certainly the best tripel I have ever had.   It really takes this style to a new level for me.

11.2oz from the gift pack with glass.  Its a hazy blonde beer with a nice creamy head and some lacing.  Pleasant light fruity aroma.  Flavor is smooth, lightly fruity, lightly hoppy, tripel character. Barely noticeable bitter finish. Quite mild, actually.  Understated and unassuming, but nice, and pleasant to drink. Perfectly balanced.  It could use a little more pizazz, but its enjoyable just as is.
Turbid gold pour with huge, fizzy head.  Typical triply aroma with barnyard, hopcit, and subdued fruit elements.  Tastes fruity, with malt and citrus at the finish.  Not bad.  Smooth and fruity.

This is nearly the perfect looking beer.  A deep amber hazy beer with white thick head and tiny yeast drops on the top of the head from the bottle.  A sweet bready aroma.   A fruit sweet flavor with medium carbonation.  Excellent beer.

bottle...hazy blonde pour with a nice frothy white head.  Considerable yeast floating around.  Yeastly, fruity aroma.  Banana to start, lots of carbonation.  Nicely sweetness in the middle, some raisin to finish.  Fruity, sweet, very carbonated, almost too much for my liking.  A decent brew, but a slight disappointment.

Slight hazy dull amber body with a tight beaded white head. Light caramel in the taste, lovely light and smooth malt, though it seems to be quite filling, some fruit characters, alcohol doesnt seem to show itself, no big flavours but easily drinkable.

Hazy and a deep yellow/light brown in colorwith a foamy white head, this has a sweet caramel aroma with lightly sour overtones.  Very light in the mouth.  Not very big in flavor, just a bit of sweet malt with mild citric hopping.  Okay, but not real interesting.
Sweet beer.  Deep yellowish color.  Its pretty good but a bit underwhelming.

White large mostly lasting head. Amber color. Aroma is moderately malty with fruity (apricot, banana), floral, nutty and slightly spicy notes. Flavor is fruity too with light dried fruits tones, ending in a balanced moderately hoppy, dry finish. Medium bodied.

Hazy lemon-yellow body and a fluffy pure white head. Estery nose with elements of both bananas and oranges plus a sweet pale malt background and some mild band-aid phenols. For a tripel, the flavor seems sweet and buttery with a hint of butterscotch, but not suggesting diacetyl. Some syrupy quality in the mouthfeel. Solid, but doesnt really hold its own against the great tripels of Belgium.

Orange.  Subtle aroma of citrus fruits, dough, bubble gum and sweet malts.  The lovely malt and hop balance is only better complimented by the silky, coating mouthfeel.  Slightly tart.  Notes of cotton candy, bubble gum and tropical fruits.  Wow, damn, why was I ignoring this beer for so long?
Yellow color with a medium head.  Nice aroma of spices.  Yeasty taste, but nothing else.  Another bland and hollow Abbey...

Hazy golden light orange in color. Big white fluffy head that lasts a couple of minutes. Strong yeasty/malt aroma. Roasted malt caramel taste with hints of fruit. Dry finish with a tiny hint of alcohol. Very good overall.
Gold Coloring with White Head.  Yeasty. Fruity and Mild Amounts of Spice.  Very Nice!

On tap at Anam Caras Belgian Month.  Slightly hazy golden orange with nice big thick white head.  Aroma is yeasty with pepper and light citrus.  Taste was a bit mild at first, but as it warmed the malt became strong and blended nicely with the fruity hop.  Excellent.

Sweet, nutty, poaceously fruity. Nice head and numerous floaties. A murky off yellow. Yeasty aroma with apple booze, caramel and cane juice. Sweet apple cider and butterscotch. Off fragrance as it warms. Metalic. Good but not great.

Light brown color with a dense head and cloudy appearance.  Aroma was malty witha  hint of spice & yeast.  Soft palate - fruity, spicy that warms as it finishes.  Hints of apples &  roasted something - peanuts?  Slighlty acidic.  Very nice.

Orangish brown w/thick white head. Musty yeasty nose with light spice, nuts, malt and creamy notes. Med-Heavey w/sweet creamy finish. Malt, honey, light spice, citrus, carmel, and toffe flavors. Nice!

Cloudy orange with quite a few floaties. Nice carbonation level. Appealing nose, with notes of apple and pear. Rich malts (yeasty dough) with a subtle sweetness (vanilla, cookie). Some bandaid phenols. Mild bitterness and some spiciness in the finish. Pleasant tasting and enjoyable.
Bottle conditioned at room temp from the Beer Bar in Glasgow. Good off-white head, golden orange colour. Citrus/yeast/hop/flower/honey aroma. Full mouthfeel, long hoppy finish. Good un.

Clear yellow with a white lasting head.  The aroma is very characteristic of a Triple; full and enticing.  Well balanced sweetness with some spice and herbal hop flavors. A bit thinner body than what I would expect, but still enjoyable nonetheless.
This one like all the Bernardus beers really need to age.there is no perticular flav in that brew, it is just missing something.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [33 cl. bottle] Hazy orange/amber color with a creamy head that lasts for a long time. Complex and potent aroma of fruits, yeast, slight spice and alcohol. Well balanced flavor that begins with a sweet yeasty flavor and has a nice spicy backbone and a nice peppery and citrus zing at the end. Good carbonation and very creamy.

A nice, hazy golden color, with lots of carbonation and a head that lasts forever.  Yeasty and fruity.  Very drinkable, hides the strong alcohol content very well.  A very well-made and delicious tripel.

Amber orange appearance with flocculation.  Fairly large head had sparce lacing.  Yeasty aroma with spicy overtones.  A subdued sweetness lurks behind the well carbonated, medium-bodied flavor.  Fruity/citrus finish.  Not at all bad, just had higher expectations from this brewery.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2005 BB date just a few mos away. Hazy golden color. Initially very fizzy but  faded away in minutes. Sweet,yeasty and slight malty aroma,big citrus notes. Flavor is sweet and lightly malty with hints of spices,some kind of fleshy fruit I couldnt pinpoint with some natural honey flavor in the finish. Have not had a tripel like this before. VERY good. And damn if half the bottle didnt disappear with this rating.
 4-01-05 Just tasted one that was a month past the BB date. HOLY crap. The best trippel Ive ever had. My 2nd ever 5.
Cloudy golden pour with a big long lasting white head, yet with little lacing.  Aroma is yeasty and nice light citrusy hops.  Same with taste yet nice sturdy malty backbone.  Nice.

Bottle:  Aroma is strong with citrus.  Reminds me a little of a hefe.  A little malty too but mostly dominated by the citrus.  Pours a hazy orangish-brown with lots of sediment.  Nice white head and good retention.  Flavor is citrus and slight alcohol.  A little banana sneaks in, but not as much as the Pater 6.  Finishes with a nice malty flavor with some citrus.  Only a slight tad of bitterness in the finish.  Has the alcohol warming effect as it goes down, but the alcohol flavor is not overpowering which I like.

Cloudy orange pour with a huge bubbly head which settles nicely.  Aroma primarily yeast with some masked citrus.  Taste is rather good.  Very spicy with some cloves and has a nice maltiness to back it up.  Good body with active carbonation on the palette.  Excellent dry finish.  I really like this one... the fruit and citrus in this beer really put it a notch above.  I hate beers that are overly yeasty, this one is just right... this is  a nice tripel.

Poured rich golden color with thick white almost Duvel-esque head that left beautiful lacing...smells citrus and mild spices, maybe cloves...tastes beautiful...malty and sweet at first, then citrus, yeast, mildly astringent...crisp dry finish...excellent indeed...

Hazy orange color, thin white head. Aroma of citrus, spices and moldy yeast. Great flavor of citrus, spices and yeast. Bitter finish. Light to medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Very good.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. As lively as a lively thing. Very hazy yellowy/orange colour. Head measured in inches, off-white and rocky looking. Aroma is citrus and light spices. Great taste; sweet, spicey and dry, malty and buttery. Great on the palate, smooth and full bodied. Class.

Its aroma indicates a very filling beer, and this is confirmed by its taste. This is a beer you want to enjoy slowly, tasting every drop. Dark orange colour. Strong on alcohol and yet very smooth. A beer for all seasons!

Appearance: perfectly opaque orangey color, with a fine, white head atop.
Aroma: full of soft spices, orange peel, lemon rind, spicy, citrusy, yeasty, full, magnificent.
Taste: excellent entry on the tongue & palate, beautiful, yeasty, rich and fruity.
Soft, yet earthy, hoppy, full-bodies, and delicious.
An excellent tripel, for the sugary aspect was much more subdued than other offerings which misinterpreted, perhaps, the portions of the sweetness in the style. Seemed nothing more, or less, than perfect, without being mindblowing.
Very, very worthwhile brew.

Bottle @ Ølbaren, Copenhagen. Pours a nice orange body with a small white head. You can see the yeast chunks flaoting around in the beer. The aroma is quite spicy, some yeast, good sweetness and fruityness. Flavor is very spiced, rather dry, sweet, but a bit too one dimensional. Decent tripel, i honestly dont find them very good.

Pours a cloudy golden color, big white head that lasts for a while and then settles down into a nice thin layer with some good lacing. Im having trouble picking out anything special in the aroma, just regular yeast and some slight spicyiness.  Nicely hopped finish, and all around very decent, but not among the best tripels Ive had.

I ran across this one at the local liquor store and decided to give it a try.  Best when poured into a brandy snifter.  Cloudy golden color with a sweet aroma.  Definitely has a citrus taste.  The alcohol is greatly disguised by the flavor and aftertaste.  A real enjoyable Belgian ale.

Straw to a hazey bronze in color, with a short lived, but nice head. Has an OK nose, but is nothing to write home about.   If I where forced to pick out this beers best quality it would be its long finsih.  A taste that last until the next drink is down the gullet. Overall, an enjoyable beer that I will drink again.

Pours a cloudy dark yellow with a thick fluffy fading head. smells like an open field,I.e like an Abbey ale. malt comes through on the nose. overall description for the taste of this is creamy. this melts together well. sour grape and yeast flavor is noticeable. nice malt profile has a buttery quality. Im going out on a limb but this is like a good helping of biscuits and gravy, only with beer.  alcohol finish that leaves a spicy flavor. good stuff.
Cloudy orange with huge white head and nice lacing.  Aroma was predominently yeast.  Decent mouthfeel.  Flavor was somewhat sweet.  Good but not great.

Well, I wasnt too impressed by this Tripel.  Cloudy orange body with plenty of yeast floaties and a thin, creamy off-white head.  Pear, banana, tart citrus aroma with bready yeast highlights.  Flavor profile included crackers and bread (classic Tripel components), a touch of pear, white grape, toast and a peppery finish.  Perfumey, yet light and unconvincing on the whole.  Rather dry.

Nice, nice, nice.  Golden, cloudy, white head, small bubbles, thick and round, touch syrupy, smell flowers, honey-dipped bananas, touch of alcohol.  Taste sweet fruity dripping goodness, low bitterness, medium acidity, warming booze.  Good medium carbonation.  This was tasty.
This was a nice tripel.  Deep golden in color with a thick white head.  The aroma was fruity and the taste was very much the same.  A beer to recommend and one I will come back to to try again.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2004 The aroma is freaking awesome with some cloves, citrus, pine, and spices. The apperance is a murky yellowish orange color with a large head. The flavor has a nice citrus punch with some orange peel and coriander flavor. There's some wheat and peppery spices present. This one is very nicely balanced, and unlike the Prior 8, its not overcarbonated. The aftertaste is yeasty and sour. This is just a damn fine beer.
very light nose, clear color of light orange.  large head, creamy underneath some spice playing with a nip of alcohol.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2005 Great beer with warm golden color and large creamy froth.Complex aromas of fresh white stonefruit,fine malts,honey and nobel yeast.Intens mouthfeeling with great hints of ripe apple,butter;cinnamon,pepper and fine sweet malts.Fullboddied afthertaste with fine bitterness in the end.

Very yeasty... sucked because I "chugged" the bottle as I began pouring and it really mixed it up. Large creamy and off-white fully lasting head, dirty gold body. Nice spicy (cinnamom, cloves) apple aroma. Not as yeasty in the aroma as I expected. Taste brings the yeast though. Again, a sweet spicy apple with a nice, slightly warm alcohol feel. Slightly bitter edge. A little too carbonated. Overall, pretty good.
Pours hazy deep amber. Spicy sitrus aroma. Spicy clove and citrus flavor, and not a real strong alcohol flavor until the end. Nice lacing too.
This is a reeally good Abbey Triple.  Malty, fruity, and sweet flavors.  Finishes clean, smooth, and crisp.

33 cl bottle best before Dec 31, 2006.  Crystal clear orange coloured beer with a lasting white head and some sticky lacing.  Nice carbonation.  Fruity aroma showing apple and pear along with some warm spiciness.  Flavour is also fruity and spicy, showing especially black pepper.  The body was a bit thinner than I would have expected.  A well-balanced beer but without the complexity I was expecting.

Sampled at Brewtopia. Luckily one of the first beers tried that night, as I soon
stopped rating and started just enjoying.
Hazy golden color with a nice white head. Citrusy aroma. Somewhat sweet on first taste but finishes dry. A very good, but not great example of the style.

Pale orange color is very pleasing to the eye, and the mad rush of carbonation feeds and inch tall head that stays around forever.  The lacing on the sides of the goblet is quite nice too.  The aroma is flowery and tropical with saffron, banana, coconut, and mango on the nose.  The Taste is quite sweet with the fruity flavors mentioned above and alcohol warmth that reminds me of a mixed drink made with some rum.  The finish is pungent and dry with slightly puckering hop bitterness and a peppery spiciness.  A very well done Tripel that is now easily acquired in Georgia.  In my opinion, sets the bar for the style.

Tasted in NYC. Tasted at brewtopia 04.  Aroma is of citrus, pear and sweetness. Appearance is a cloudy yellow straw hue.  A thin white head remains in the glass. Very smooth with little or no alcohol presence.
Dark golden, unclear. White lasting head. Good carbonation. Rich flavour with malty sweet notes. Yeast. Herbal. Soft palate. Hides the ABV very well. Overall fair tripel.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2005 Keith-This may ne the tripel, but it is much like this companys Belgian white beer.  Rich fruity aroma and taste with a decent aftertaste.

06.25.04  Bottle.  Hazy, sort of a dull, tarnished gold color.  Large, thick, and creamy head.  Mucho floaties.  Subdued aromas of rich fruits, cherry, plum, prune, bakery, cream puff.  Bright, effervescent mouthfeel, yet silky; syrupy sweet on finish.  Great nutty, apple, plum sugar flavors.  Very nicely balanced, I thought, where the sweetness could have gotten carried away.
Hazy golden orange color with a great white head. A little alcohol in the aroma.  spices,not a bad beer but not a 94 rating to me but then who am i!!
Sort of simple (easy drinking) and complex at the same time. Nice smooth taste. Spicey with honey sweetness.

Pours a light amber with a large rich head. Sweet malt and oranges in the nose. Light on the palate, sweet, citrusy, interesting, with a slight alcohol presence. Malt once again dominates the finish for a rather sweet version of a Tripel. GREAT!
Poured a hazy golden yellow with a smaller white head. Aromas of spices bananas and apples. Smooth tasting with a very dry finish. Lightly sweet, yeasty with spices. A very drinkable beer.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2004 Nice dark golden pour, with a syrupy thickness.  The citrus and bread was right there to match the warming in this dense tripel.  There is a nice transition from the honey sweetness in the initial taste, to the warm dryness of the finish.  This is a predictable but tasty tripel, that doesnt stray from the style.

Hazy orange with a huge white froty head with good lacing. Nose is wheaty citrusy and yeasty . Taste is bland with just a hint of wheat but not in a gross way, coppery and maybe some metal. Thin bodied.
Wonderful dry hop nose- that belgian style hoppy nose. Thin head. First sip had a strange hint of sourness that was unexpected. Still has the requisite dryness for a tripel.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2004 Bottle from The Wine Company, Slough. Better than the prior 8, not quite up to the Abt 12. Strong and rich, packed full of flavour. Very Belgian.

sweet aroma, with yeasty piney citrus in there somewhere.  another monstrous head on a belgian beer--i needed two glasses to pour all of it at once.  malty and spicy in the body, with a lightly alcoholic finish.  pretty good!

Huge clumpy head atop a hazy, straw golden body.  Aroma dominated by banana and bubblegum with some funky yeast notes as well.  Flavor  is sweet and fruity, not so much in the way of hops besides a decent bitterness in the finish.  Moderately alcoholic.

Sweet and vapory aroma. Candy sugar, citrus oil, light hops, and malts. Belgian yeasties. Hazy light amber with pillowy white lacing head. Medium body with medium-lively carbonation, very nice. Starts rather sweet. Malty, sugary, with light fruity character. No acidity. Finish stays sweet and alcoholic, with yeasts and light bitterness. After is light dryness with extended sweet notes on the tongue. Very nicely balanced. A nice tripel.

Peachy-brown color with a medium thick, long lasting white head. Outstanding lacing. Smells rich malt, fruit, raisins, apples and pears. Taste is same: apples, pears, malt with yeast and coriander. Makes for a very easy drinking triple. Alcohol is cleverly hidden. Sampled from an 11.2 oz bottle purchsed at Chevy Chase wine and spirits in Washington, DC.

bottled: poured nice hazy golden brown with a rocky white head that bubbled high and fell into itself. nose of wheat bread, fruit. smooth and luscious jackson on the palate. bread flavor coming through with some ripe banana and raisins. nice and bold and robust. sweet rock candy bottoms out. a nice tripel. put one down today!

Pours a light golden with a nice fluffy head. Aroma is a bit metallic with some dark fruit, and citrus. Flavor is doughy with dark fruit and a bit of citrus to make it a bit lively. Nice but a bit subdued.

Appearance: Dark Pear like hue, clouded body with a major carbonation flow along with an overwhelming fizzly white head...as I left the smallest portion in the bottle....and once I mixed the dregs up I poured the dregs from the bottom in which brown pieces of yeast sprinkled the head like cinnamon on your latte

Smell: Massive array of citrus fruits...from pear to peach, apricot to mango, mango to star fruit....followed up by strong peppery and flower phenols...

Taste: quite similar to the smell....a robust citrus fruit appeal, follewed by a well introduced Mr. Yeast...banana seemed to makes its impression as well....nice cider like feel with a vinegar malty backbone....just great complexity

Notes: This is a well crafted brew...with all the complex characteristics it remains very very balanced...great stuff

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2004 Im all about this tripel.  Nice fruity notes with a mini alcohol bite on the end.  Very well balanced and easy drinking.  Its not necessarily the best example of the style, but the beer is just so enjoyable I cant help but give it good marks.

Peach and citrus, sugary malty. Lovely example of a trippel, and I like trippels. Becoming better known. Sweet and bubbly like Ommegang Ommegang but with the class of a Belgian. Yes, precisely. And not as spiced out and overly complex as Unibroue can be.

750ml bottle.  Very attractive dark golden color with a massive egg white colored head that is fully retained.  Aroma is nicely hoppy with a nice dose of yeast.  Light floral scent as well.  Really nicely restrained hop bitterness with some wonderful yeast flavor and just a bit of candy sugar.  This is very enjoyable, somewhat affordable, and highly accessible beer.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2005 Sampled yet again at a warmer temperature. Still nice. The main difference I noticed was a slight increase in the sourness. I stick by my previous impressions. A very solid tripel. Poured with a huge, slightly off-white head. This has a yeasty, sour lemon smell. The appearance is a hazy, light copper. The flavor is much sweeter than the aroma would indicate. It has ginger, clove and banana. The sweetness is subtle.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2004 aromas of bread, nuts, esters, alcohol and rum? polished copper color, clear with a huge creamy head that lasts. flavors of brown sugar, orange, bready malt, slight hop flavor. creamy body that dries nicely avoiding cloying sweetness. somewhat powdery in the finish. candy like flavors. excelent beer. very well balanced.

Beer pours (in Corsendonk glass) from an 11.2 oz. bottle a cloudy and dark orange-golden liquid with a generous amount of virgin white head that lingers, but eventually dissipates.  Aroma is of grain, straw, grass, vegetal, but also bannana and citrus.  Flavor is of bannana, small hops, and slight citrus.  Probably as pleasant to drink as Corsendonk Blonde.  Sampled at 68 degrees Fahrenheit.
Great stuff.  Smooth, slightly sweet tripel.  Just a hint of cloves with a lot of honey.  Nice finish.

Bottle pours hazy orange amber with a very large head and sheets of lace.  The aroma is fruity, banana, and spicy.  The flavor is malty, sweet, slight spice in the finish, and very smooth.  The body is rich, smooth, and cleansing.  Overall, this is nice as a Tripel and refreshing.

Bottle:  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a huge white head with some lacing.  Aroma is slightly spicy with some banana notes.  Taste is quite mild, very smooth.  Would guess this was only 3 or 4 ABV, nicely hidden.  Very little aftertaste.

2001 bottle (from what I can guess from the notches on the smiling monk label) - Gorgeously thick and clouded dull orangey-yellow color that you cannot see through what so ever; very syrupy thick body with a very tall off-white, meringue-like, speckled froth that sits on top for a good while before finally settling to a healthy murk of a skim on top that keeps its hold mounting on top for a good time. Great lacing in thickly sticking foamy strings. 

Lovely aroma of well rounded deep fruityness bringing in super dulled citrus(citrus without the sour citrus) of orange and lemon, some passion fruit, banana, dried apricots, and pineapple notes intermingle. Way yummy and candy-licious! Very soft musty, yeasty spices barely make an appearance, which I like, most Belgian Triples seem to have way too much of that plastic/phenol yeast thing that doesn't bold well with me. This is soft and subtle, fruity and candy-like, more to my liking. Not overly strong but oh so yummy to wiff in. Great subtle fruits and softness to its nose! Tropical fruit salad any one?

Oh my...and the taste follows suit from the smell. Huh? Wow! This is yummy! The tropical fruityness is fabulous to my tastes; soft, full, bold, yet biting, all that was noted in the smell comes across in the tastes. Great fruits of dulled down orange and lemon with some pineapple and banana. Super fine creamyness and fullness. Mild as all hell yeast and spice just barely make an entrance peeking even more interest within the flavors. Maintains a strangely interesting finish of chocolate and caramel malty thickness which covers over the fruits later on, quite amazing! Far and away one of the best Triples I've enjoyed! Thick, lush, flavorful in fruits and candy action! Yum, yum, yum, this stuff rocks! I haven't had many Triples cuz most I've had I didn't like, but this St. Bernardus is mind boggling yummy!

Orange cloudy color with a thich creamy head.  Aroma is sweet whith a flour feel to it.  Mouthfeel has no serious bite, and has a good smoothing end.  There is a definite sweetness that comes through after the beer goes down.  The flavor has a nice sweetness, but is balanced out nicely with a breaded feel.

Bottled.
Hazy golden, with a large, white head.
A fresh aroma from ozon and green bananas(?).
Soft, almost flat with a yeasty, pineapple-flavour.

Bottle: Aroma is mild, yeastly, with some hints of cloves and maybe other spices as well.  Pours a hazy copper color with an enormous white head.  Sweet, honey like start.  Very smooth.  Finish is smokey and caramel-ish.  Alcohol is well-hidden.  A solid brew, but shadows in comparison to their Abt 12.

33cl bottle:  This beer pours VERY hazy golden color.  There is a big,thick white head with lots of small bubbles.  Lots of carbonation.  The aroma is citric, yeasty, with some spices (corriander?).  Sweet taste has hints of banana, bread and citrus.  An excellent Tripel!

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2004 Bottle (330ml) pours a hazy light golden, large white foamy head, sticky lacing, with heavy carbonation.   Corriander, apple, pear, and esters on the nose.   Spice and light fruits up front, slightly sweet.   Good body, spritzy mouthfeel.   Finishes with a bit more sourness, slightly acidic.   7.5% ABV is well hidden.   This is a very good Tripel, not overly sweet, good from start to finish.   The smaller bottle seems to be much better than the 750ml.
Pours clear with a heavy, sugary and spiced nose.  A full mouthfeel with orange hints.  On the tongue it actually tastes like "Pam", the cooking spray, but not in a bad way.

Opaque muddy gold body and white head with ok lacing.  It has a nice fruity aroma with notes of alcohol and yeast, but the mouthfeel is weak and ends abruptly.  The body is simple with a slight malty flavour and a hint of yeast.

While I find myself irresistibly drawn to tripels, this Belgian blonde falls short. From the moment you pour, a cloudy, yellowish, almost urine looking liquid appears. With minimal lacing, the lace floats on top reminiscent of mold growing on stale bread. (clumped together in small round 'spots') This beer has a gorgeous strong aroma, very appealing but fades fast, leaving you struggling to place the scents. With a more yeasty than fruity flavour, this tripel is weaker than its contemporaties (such as Petrus) and disappears before fully developing. Despite the weakness of the flavour, the palate is pleasant and very easy to drink.

This is what I like in a tripel.  Lots of fresh cut grass, hay and barnyard aromas.  The taste is again like bread that is fresh out of the oven.  The flavor is nice and sweet, with a bit of acidic tartness.  Very good.

750 mL bottle, snifter.  Awesome aroma: cookie and biscuit malt (H); spicey, earthy hops (M); some barnyard aromas.  Golden peach body with a beautiful creamy, white head.  Heavily sweet flavor becomes a moderately sweet, moderately bitter, lightly acidic finish.  Medium-heavy body, watery/creamy texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: excellent...[taps fingers]

Hard to find Bernardus beers around here, so it was a treat to try this.  Tripel is one of my favorite belgian styles, and this was really a treat.  Lovely fluffy white head, delicate palate w/ample carbonation and a good punch of alchohol.  Will definitely try again.
(Bottle)  Pours a hazy yellow with an impressive long-lasting thick white frothy head.  Has a bountiful yeast nose.  Smooth, soft palate and flavors of yeast, malt, banana, and hops.
Orange colour with fine white head. Nice malty-sweetness, lightly hopped and acidic. Very well rounded. Soft.

aroma is of apples and pine. pours a cloudy straw color with a large white head that dissipates. flavor is sweet and smooth, with a slightly spicy aftertaste. has some lacing. not overly familiar with the style, but I enjoyed this beer.

A competent, but not outstanding, Belgian tripel. Very easy-drinking for a tripel, hence rather dangerous for us Brits who are more accustomed to something about half the strength when quaffing. Bittersweet notes throughout. Bottled, Brugse Beertje, Bruges, September 2003.

Ugly pale off-yellow, however, it has one gorgeous head and lots of carbonation.

Smells like a mix between gin and cider... just by the smell, I can tell this is going to finish dry, let's see if I am right.

Well, the finish isn't as dry as I had anticipated. Goes in smooth and sweet, lays there tenderly, and finishes with a bittersweet liquor taste. Very nice indeed.

A very drinkable beer, though at 7.5% probably not a good session beer.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2004 Pours a nice blond white with a great big white head.  Flavor is very yeasty and full.  Kind of like drinking a cake.  Good stuff either in the dead of winter or on a hot summers day.
Cloudy dark yellow colour with samll white lace. Nice aroma of spices, banana, grapefruit and sweetened oranges. Quite sweet flavour of oranges, marmelade, lemon and toffee. Yeasty finish.
Cloudy yellow-orange with a big white head. Aroma is mildly sweet. Bananas and spices. Mouthfeel is full. Yeast, spices, citrus, and fruit on the tongue. This was a really nice tripel.

Good drinkable Tripel. Has a banana-like aroma with some ester notes for good measure. Hazy, dark yellow appearance with a good thick white head. Flavor has some yeasty notes with some doughy sweetness - very full bodied. Excellent thick mouthfeel. Stays strong to the finish. Thanks to Aurelius for sharing this with me from his Christmas gift pak.

A really nice grainy-sweet aroma.  Not sure if the monk is blessing me or showing me the size of his endowment.  Oaty, lots of yeast, a golden cake quality to it.  Long moderate bitter finish. Good CO2.  Pretty good stuff.
So enjoyable, excellent beer. Pours cloudy yellow. Fruity. Great aroma of hops. Cloudy yellow in color.

Bottle says 8% abv. Pours cloudy yellow with a perfect white head. Wonderful aroma of hops, fruit, and earth that I really enjoy. Flavor is slightly sweet, with a nice hop flavor blended in. Earthy once again. This is a Tripel lover's delight (although I am not one). Very enjoyable and worth the purchase.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Thin white head which last the length of the drink.  Good carbonation that keep regenerating the silky head.  Color is a murky golden orange.  Typical triple aroma of spices, a little citrus and a healthy bit of yeast.  Flavor is tingly in the mouth with a bit of citrus again.  Finish is dry and bitter with a slight alcohol warming.  A decent triple, but triples are not my favorite.

Very frothy with white head.  Slightly darker than I expected.  Looks and smells more like a dubbel.  Light yeasty aroma.  Very light flavor.  Spicey, bitter finish.  Dissapointed.  Overall, flavor is thin and off tasting--with a sour astringent taste in malt flavor.  Grass in aftertaste.  Not gonna buy this overpriced beer--shoulda got the westy instead that I was eyeing.  Damn!  Too bad I have to pay for the beer.
Not bad. Good size soapy head. Nice opaque creamy-yellow color, similar to other tripels I've sampled. Very nice banana malt-dominated flavor. Well balanced, smooth. Thanks lipskin!

A large sized foamy white head that contained fine-small sized bubbles that mostly diminished. The body was quite hazy and there was a considerable amount of lively carbonation observed. The hue of this beer was yellow-gold. The nose was malty, sweet, spicy, and some banana notes. The flavor of this beer was malty, spicy, fruity, and citrus. The mouthfeel was quite smooth and somewhat dry. The lacing was very sparse. I recommend this Abbey Tripel to those who enjoy this beer style.

Finally a decent brew after rating about 5 swill beers in a row.  This bottled brew poured a very large head of foamy white colored finely sized white colored bubbles that left behind a poor lace and a hazy yellow brown colored body with some chocoate colored yeast swirling around in it.  The aroma was floral wheaty malty and a little fruity while the mouthfeel was tingly smooth from star to finish and quite nice.  The flavors were evident right from the start with notes of vinuous alcohol, malt, hops wheat and some spice.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2009 Hazy, golden coloured, thick lasting head, absolutely beautiful. Aroma of citrus, some spices and yeast. Spicy flavor, citrus again. Not overly complex, but very easy drinking. Nice tripel
Spicy and yeasty nose; sweet. Hazy, yellow/golden coloured with a nice lasting head. Taste is quite sublime. Well balanced taste between fruits, spices and yeast. Dry mouthfeel.

Murky yellow out of the 11.2 oz. bottle.  Lasting white head with nice Belgian lace.  Crisp nose of spice and yeast.  Nice flavors of corriander, lemon, banana, and yeast.  Dry finish.  I love this style and this is a good example of it.

Deep gold, lots of floaties, great pillow head.  Aroma strikingly similar to the Pater 6, focused bread, not what I would expect from a Tripel.  More whole wheat exerts itself on the palate, a faint fruitiness emerges as the beer hits room temperature.  Tasty, but not what I was expecting at all.  Give me some more funk!

Clear light amber body topped by a large white head. Sweet yeasty citrus aroma. Some definite malt aromas come through. The flavor is kind of boring, malt with some banana and spice. Heavily carbonated mouth-feel. A bit disappointing.

Hazy golden color, thin white head. Aroma was yeasty with citrus, banana, bubblegum, and a bit of spice. Similar flavor, the citrus and spice were a bit more pronounced. Sharp and slightly acidic mouthfeel with a touch of alcohol. Nice example of the style.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2005 (Bottled) Hazy golden-orange color with a smallish, but lasting and creamy head. Quite strong aroma or red currant and yeast, with caramel syrup and some Poperinge hops. Quite bitter-hoppy, neutral and slightly papery flavor with crisp hops in the dry finish. The flavor is balanced, but not very complex. Medium-bodied, smooth-carbonated palate. Yeast brings lots of fruitiness, and makes the flavor very smooth, as well as hides most hops until the finish. A very well-made, well-hopped and balanced tripel, but maybe lacks the "edge".
