(On 11/24/2003 it was 7-3-7-4-15=3.6) Cloudy with very little head. Fruity, hoppy, alcohol-like taste. Quite bitter, not as drinkable as Chimay triple. Fruity, even biting aftertaste. Has some sweetness in it.
Very cloudy brew with a large creamy head.  Nice citrus aroma.  Slightly sweet with a bit of alcohol coming through.  Quite a good example.

Hazy pale golden color with a light sticky head and lacing strung out like the Philippine islands. The aroma has all the tradtioninal notes of a tripel; banana esters, yeast, bubblegum, citrus. The flavor is lightly acidic with a mellow finish and an alcohol bite at the end. This is a very good belgian tripel with all that needs to be but isn't very complex which is why it won't be too highly rated.

Pours hazy gold, with thin frothy head leaving behind a pretty good layer of lace.  Banana aromas with some citrus lying about.  Clove and more citrus in the flavors. Sharp and tangy palate with a finish of alcohol.

Translucent, straw colored.  Mad headz, sparkling cream.  Aroma was banana pudding, yeast, bubble gum, citric.  Peppery on the tongue.  Had all of the characteristics of a well made tripel.  I like the way the beer seemed to settle on the tongue throughout the finish with different flavors....clove, yeast, bread, berries.  Alcohol throughout, not overbearing.  Well done.

Nice yellow color with small head, some yeasty floaties evident.  Aroma is of Belgium malts with hints of citrus and the flavor shadows those characteristics.  Palate is nice - soft with a crisp finish.
A little spicy.  Good Tripel.

Beautiful orange-honey color. Aroma is of sweet citrus and bountiful bananas. Has some spiciness attributed to it also. Initial taste is sweet with a zesty citrus flavor. Very clean yet lively on the palate. Aftertaste leaves an impression of alcohol yet is not overbearing. A very good well rounded tripel.
Hazy amber color, big frothy head with lots of lace. Citrusy malt aroma. Flavor is sweet and malty with a fair amount of citrusy fruit. Fairly dry.

Well, this was a slight let down, being a big fan of the Trippel.  I had this on tap, and the aroma was great, big yeast and malts.  The color was cloudy orange.  The head decent for a Tripel, but it seems the higher the ABV the less head.  The flavor is where the let down began.   It was sharp at first but then after the first swallow became quite watery with no real after taste.  This beer was served to me too cold at first, so I waited for it to come around a bit, but alas, it did not seems to improve.  Not a good sign for a Belgian Tripel.

Pours with a dense meringue like three inch head.  A cloudy deep gold color.  Lightly sweet but dry at the same time.  A bit of orange crosses my tongue.  Smells Belgian in its complexity (imagine that), a fruitiness and a mustiness is here in the nose.  A sharpness in the taste is present from the carbonation (this beer is well carbonated).  There is some spiciness in the nose too.  Very well put together triple, there is a certain softness/ roundness from the malt that ties this beer together very well.  Definite alcohol notes if you look for it, but definitely not in your face.  Displays the classic Belgian lacing as you work your way through your glass.  One of the best, if not the best, examples of the Tripel style of beer.

750 ml. bottle drank following a bottle of Maredsous 10 (Tripel); the effect was like being at a stereo soundboard, in that it was like someone boosted a couple of dimensions but the commonalities were stronger than the differences.  Most pronounced was the presence of bubblegum over and above the yeasty/spicy/fruity tripel base.  Particularly true in the aroma but stronger in the flavor as it warms.  Smooth palate, alcohol less pronounced than in the Maredsous, and less bubbly as well.  Nice appearance, hazy golden--slightly darker (the orange dimension boosted) than the Maredsous.  In the end, I don't know which I prefer.  I think St. Bernardus, but that could just be a reputation bias.  This one is quite good, with or without a comparison.
Aroma is spicy and fruity. Appearance is good - golden orange with some murkiness. FLavor is ok but slightly chalky like some sort of fiber supplement. Still, not a bad tripel.

Bottle says 8% ABV.  Smells spicey, with the initial taste very carbonated, spicey and punchy.  Sweet lemons and pine, mixed with spices of all sorts.  Big fluffy white head on top of a murky orange body, looks great.  Smooth finish, creamy almost.  Overall very spicey with a residual roasted flavor.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2004 Light dull-orange and hazy. Small cream colored, mostly diminishing head. Some lacing. Picked up the glass to enjoy this one with. I just imagine getting off a plane in Belgium and it smelling as wonderful as the beers it produces. Yeast and that lovely St. Bernardus tutti-frutti scent. Touch soapy. Nice carbonation. Creamy, soft palate that clings to your mouth and tongue. Fruit, yeast, nuts, spice and more Mild bitterness intertwined with caramel maltiness on a finish that is simply one of the most complex and layered Ive had. It just keeps revealing more and more as it goes. I know there is some affiliation with Westvleteren here - not sure what it all means, but these guys deserve the respect of Trapppist cuz I think they do it better than most of the ones Ive tried.

Dark yellow with a few sediments left, generous head. Malty and yeasty aroma. The taste is very malty sweet with a decent fruitiness of oranges, lemon, bananas and mango, a little sour, lightly bitter finish. It's not poorly done, but I certainly expected more from a tripel, especially from this brewery.

(bottled) Medium-amber, brilliantly clear when decanted.  Rich musty-sweet caramelly, bready aroma rises above the proud rocky white foam.  Big malt leads into almost cloying lingering candi sweetness.  Tight bottle-conditioned carbonation and some hop bitterness adds a welcome bite that helps offset the malt and dry out the finish.  Nice!
Soft and light while still being very full of flavor. Odd sensation of carbonation reacting as it hit tongue - foaming - hmm. Very easy to enjoy. Glad to see this Brewery has come to town.

To begin, the happy monk on the label indicates to me that this beer is likely to make ME happy.  That said, let's begin!  This tripel has a very nice dark orange color and slightly off white head.  Aroma is well balanced between yeast, alcohol, and some spices.  Flavor is also well balanced, mellow, and quite nice.  A very good effort!

Pours a hazy golden orange with a large rocky white head that leaves a cloud of lace as it subsides.  Musty, slightly citric aroma with the typical Belgian yeast presence.  Body is nice and thick with a syrupy sweet mouthfeel and nice complexity.  Finishes semi-dry and hides the alcohol very well. A nice tripel.
Fine beer, with a lot to offer. The special thing about it is it's aroma and flavor of lactic acid, not much, but it's there. Lot of bread too.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2003 A beautiful cloudy orange beer with a huge foamy tight crisp white head.  Nose of citrus, spice, wheat and yeast, with a little off-putting sour cheese.  Orange peel, bread, yeast, and spice in the taste.  Good big mouth feel.  Long, slow, sour and bitter finish.  Drinkably low alcohol for a Belgian.

poured a cloudy light copper color with a billowing white head.  Yeasty aroma of orange peel and spice.  Citrus taste with hints of orange, lemon, and banana, with some malt sweetness and mild spice. A nice tripel

Poured a cloudy golden color with a medium head that left nice lacing.  In the aroma I detected some orange, wheat, yeast and some slight coriander.  Taste started off with fruits such as orange, lemon, starfruit... at that point it became carbonated and there was a dry, woody taste.  Very little alcohol was noticible.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2010 Corked 75cl bottle. The cork on this one as with the Abt12 bottle I had recently, shot out like a rocket after I removed the wire cage. I tried not to disturb the thick layer of sediment as I poured the first couple glasses. Fairly clear golden ale with an orange hue. Sizable white head settles down to a creamy layer of foam. Aroma is sweet and fruity and like most Tripels Ive had. Flavor has a distinct citrus character, lemon and orange come to mind. Has a nice creamy mouthfeel that goes down real smooth. Alcohol is well hidden. The last glass I poured inevitably contained some yeast sediment. This glass was really cloudy and the overall flavor was less enjoyable. Id recommend trying to leave the sediment in the bottle. This is a great Tripel that seems to be widely available.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Pours a clouded, dirty blond with a nice off-white head. Nose is full of spice and malt but also has some earthiness to it as well. The taste expands on these aromatic characteristics and makes this a wonderful beer. Finishes with a slightly smooth but spicy aftertaste. Good stuff!
Medium bodied sweet triple. Loads of orange zest and caramel. Gets the job done.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2004 [This rating is for the old 9% version] Hints of yeast in the aroma. A very dark beer that has a filling taste with hints of yeast and fruit. [The 7.5% version] An unclear orange beer with a fine head. The aroma is very sweet with an undistiguable powerful spice note and a weak note of black peber. The flavor is strond but flat yet the alcohol prickles even though it is just 7.5% ABV. In the middle it reminds me of flat wheat with notes of oranges and other fruits. It ends on a dry wheat note. The flavor is somewhat strange. It is definatly not as good as the Triple 9. This is not my beer. [6/4/5/4/11]

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2004  Bottled. 
Hazy pale yellow. Rich head. Fresh, dewy, ozon-like aroma with notes of green banana and canned pineapple. Sweet malty, smooth flavour with notes of fruits. Marshmallow-like palate.

Orange gold color, slightly cloudy. Large creamy head. Aroma is fruity, touches of banana, peaches and oranges, and yeasts.A medium bodied Belgian. It really doesnt taste like a tripel, but it has all the other Belgian characteristics to it. Malts are fruity and sweet. Banana and cloves and spices are very evident. Nice bright yeasts. Very smooth taste. Its a very nice beer. Nice soft mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Mouthfeel is full and soft. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2005 Nice, but doesnt strike me as particularly "tripel-ish".  Lovely peachy gold.  Nose is very yeasty, not too spicy.  Light fruitiness and yeastiness continue in the flavor, very mild spiciness.  A bit raisiny, some sugary sweetness.  Creamy and smooth.
Bernardus Tripel has all the classic flavour notes of a tripel, but is a little lighter both in alcohol and flavour.
Beautiful orangish gold color with nice white head. Spicy sweet aroma. Crisp, clean malty body, with some sweetness and fruit.

Hazy golden orange color with a great white head that hung around for the whole glass, nice looking. A little yeast, spice, and alcohol in the aroma. Each sip I took tasted different, and I liked it more as it warmed. Seems somewhat unbalanced, bitter, some spices, alcohol flavor is up in the mix. Soft in the mouth (nice), but a little thin. Lacks in defining character and spice, but not bad. Kind of a let down judging from the monk on the bottle (and it being a tripel).

The head on this triple is amazing. Lacing is amazing. Buy this beer for appearance alone! Tastes similar to the prior 8 but spicier. Still get the Twizzler vibe with the bernardus. Westmalle makes a better triple, but this aint bad in any sense. Cheers.

Bottled. So much better then the hair of the dog. If only I could always drink my way out of all hangovers with such a nice beer. 10.45am on bright sunny Sunday and drinking this beer feels like the most natural thing in the world. Gold sweet juice from the beer gods. Generous fluffy white head the beer was perfectly conditioned. I am a lucky guy to have this beer still left in the fridge. Im not sure whats next, possibly back to home brew, possibly not. It depends on how successfully I managed to hide the good stuff last night. I think the fridge in my office still holds some challenges. Anyway, this beer is lovely, sweet and inviting. Smooth honey complexion with a bitter hope finish to it. Lacy to the finish.

sweet malty aroma with a touch of raisins - with a yeasty scent to it, nice rich cloudy amber color with a nice fat white head that lurks down on the beer, richly carbonated flavor - banana essence to it - yeasty and bready flavor - with some bitterness hanging around
UPDATED: SEP 5, 2003 Color is yellowish with a small white head. Taste is fruity but with unpleasant hints of alcohol.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2003 mmm.. nice aroma, reminded me of plums, bananas and slightly sweet. Taste was very sweet, this is a very mild triple but very drinkable. Color is very cloudy, taste is sweet, fruity and hints of spices in the finish.. excellent beer!!!!!!  [westvleteren glas]

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2004 Very nice ale & yeast aroma; medium amber color; a rush of flavor unlike most other ales I've tried, and an aftertaste very much like sherry; this is my new standard // Rerated 3/22/04: just as good as I remembered, and I increased aroma to 9

Came gushing out of the bottle. Poured into a Rochefort glass. Color is a cloudy orange with a thin diminishing, lingering white head. Aroma is of yeast and not much more IMO. Has a slight sweetness to it and a little fruitiness. Nice.

My first rating on this site...The bottle I had was a 75cl, Cuvee 2002, BBD 2007.  I carried it back from Belgium, I bought it in a set with the Watou Triple, and the Prior 8 in a grocery in Boullion.

7.5%ABV, poured into a Corsendonk tulip.

An energetic beer, pours with a generous white head that diminished, but lingered. 
Deep golden color, slight haze, but impressive looking all around.

Flora notes in nose? Citrus? Phenol spice and maybe a bit of Saaz spice.

Firm bodied bier.  Malt in the flavor, I get a bit of vanilla in there from the yeast.  Becomes sweeter as it warms and the CO2 depletes.  The yeast is all over this baby.  Hops are restrained, but apparent. It is tough to tell if I'm getting some Saaz or if that's the yeast in the finish.
In comparison, similiar to the New Belgium Trip, but less corriander and less hop bitterness.  Should have done a side by side with them.
Alcohol becomes more apparent as the beer warmed, especially in the finish.

Overall, it seems a fairly balanced tripple to me.

Fresh, citrusy aroma, with notes of pear, melon, pineapple, honey and flowers.  Opaque golden in color, rather heavily sedimented, with a fading head.  Sweet, fruity, malty flavor profile, with a substantial, yeasty, spicy finish.  It had been many years since my last sampling of this one.  It still holds its own.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2005 Orange/gold color with a super foamy head that slowly melts away. Wonderful citrusy aroma and the smell of bread rising. Breadlike theme continues in the taste, which is sweet and grainy. Fine lingering sweet finish. When I first opened it, the foam rose about an inch out of the mouth of the bottle before collapsing. Cool, expensive and worth it.
A good beer, tons of head.  Smooth, but you can tell it's kind of strong.  The aroma is strong too.

Clear bright honey, massive thick lasting lacey head.  Nose yeasty and at first whiff almost brett-like, settles down into a softer fruitiness.  Flavor sweet, malty, warming and rather alcoholic-tasting for 7.5%.  Very pleasant, nicely warming, creamy finish.  Guess I'm about middle of the road on this one.

Hazy golden body with medium white head.  Aroma is yeasty, slightly sweet, lemon, pepper, somewhat astringent.  Taste is minimal up front, turning yeasty and mildly sweet at mid-tongue.  Finishes citrus (lemon/orange), mildly herbal hoppy, and significant alcohol.  Medium bodied, and fairly carbonated.
UPDATED: SEP 12, 2005 Coriander aroma. Nice malty and bready finish. A little fruity and alcoholic.

Hazy light amber pour, large white head that mostly diminishes to good lacing.  Aroma is yeasty, sweet, some lemony hints in there.  Flavor is sweet, dominated with apple and banana, slight spice sneaks in, too.  Body is medium, lively carbonation, and a very dry finish.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2003 Tap from the Toronado Belgian beer month (7 3 7 4 17).  Golden color with a laced white head.  A nice warm spice with honey and alcohol.  Rating #2 from a bottle.  A hazy golden color with lots of rising bubbles and a foamy white head.  Yeast, banana, citrus, spice, and bread in the nose.  A little chewy and zesty on the palate.

Brownish amber color, cloudy, with a small whitish head. Bananas are strong in the nose, which is fairly sweet overall. Flavor also includes banana, is semi-sweet, with a touch of peppery spice. Finishes dry, with a touch of bitterness.

Golden orange, heaps of super small bubbles work together in perfect harmony to build a glorious head. . . Ripe bananas, dough and yeast float in the air where they are bombared by a spicy malt - a very balanced battle, and an amazing one to watch.  Gala apple flavour, along with some very sweet bananas, not much of a hop presence detected on the tongue, but with such balance in the aroma and hints in the finish this brew comes out high on my list.
Very refreshing tripel. Holds a solid place separate from the darker abbey ales. Very good with acidic food.
Cloudy golden color with a big head. Strong fruity aroma with a hint of bannana and peach. Malty but sweet finish. A very good tripel that should be enjoyed.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2009 Valiant, creamy cereal and banana cavaliers peacefully conquer wise gooseberries...On their doughy yeast  saddle, they emulate flowery dignity as they sprinkle a few herbal hops in respectful victory...A glass of classy  nourishment and Old World refinement...
Cloudy,bronze colored.  Bead of pearls head around the glass.  Sweet yeasty fruity maybe banana and apple.  Good Beer

This one pours a cloudy, deep golden color with a big, lingering white head. The aroma is strongly fruity with some malt and citrus notes. Medium body with lively carbonation, the flavor is fruity with hints of peaches, yeasts, and raisons. The finish is malty sweet and slightly nutty with some more fruit flavors. This is one strongly fruity tripel, very nice, tasty, and highly drinkable.

Bottled. Amber coloured with rich, very lively head. Malt and some citrus in an unusually introvert aroma for a tripel. Soft mouthfeel and balanced sweetness together with a big, bready, chewy maltiness. Just a hint of coriander in an otherwise malt dominated finish.
It would be unfair to say I didn't appreciate it. Anyway, I found it a bit too thin to compete with other Abbey Tripels

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2004 Pleasant sour, woody aroma. Bright slightly hazy orange color. A quarter inch of white head. Tons of intricate lace. Slight sour, slightly sweet malty flavor. Definite wheat and yeast notes. Some more subtle notes of raisins and banana. Light, fluffy, and refreshing.

Great beer!
Time to start cutting back on the verbiage. Rating beer is fun, but drinking is more fun than writing and typing. My scores will stay true to form.
Honey colored brew. Large, fizzy, white head. Noisy! Sounds like Rice Crispies. Quickly diminishing into a ring around the glass' perimeter.
The aroma is of citrus and fuzzy fruits, yeast and alcohol.
Spicey flavor full of fuzzy fruits up front. Perfectly balanced on the backside with a nice hop addition. True to the style.
Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation.
Medium-length alcoholic, astringent and dry finish.
Thanks go out to Britt from Annapolis for this great beer!

White, rocky head.  Orange/honey color.  Somewhat furious carbonation.  Cloudy.  Light aroma of citrus and a little bit of yeast.  Light on the tongue, yeasty and a little bready.  The alcohol really isn't apparent.  A little sweet, overall tastey.
Tastey looking orange haze with no head retention. Smells somewhat citrusy and bready. Tastes of alcohol and sweet fruits.

Hazey orange/copper color.Large white head that stays alive with a non stop influxe of carbonation that is constantly rising up from the bottom of my drinkin vessel.Nice fruity,yeasty,earthy,soda poppy nose.Medium bodied,spritsey.Fruity,bready some bananna flavors also.Medium sweet finish.OK.

Cloudy appereance, amber colour, huge head that lasts for few minutes,  very high carbonation: I've just had the time to open it and the beer came out of the bottle!  Fruity aroma, with strong traces of orange peels and citrus. The flavour is sweet (vanilla) sour (citrus) and fruity (peach and apricot). Like the other St. Bernardus beers the finish is too much alcoholic for my taste. So it's a bit unbalanced beer and i would've appreciated a touch of bitterness.

Transluscent amber in color with an agressive lingering head.  Sweet aroma with a hoppy tang to it.  Malty body that opens up into a yeasty/hoppy finish.  Light on the tongue with a slight bitter linger.
Murky dark orange in color with a small bubbled white head. Sweet malt aroma with bits of bread and dark fruits.  Yeasty taste that ends sweet.

11.2 ounce bottle.
It's cloudy/hazy burnt orange in color and the fluffy head is absolutely gargantuan in size, probably 3.5 inches. Just wiggle your glass a little, make it dance, and the head returns for another inch to inch and a half of fluffiness.
The aroma is strongly fruity, twangy, and yeasty. Some pepper is noticed as well. 
An awesome flavor of yeastiness, sweetness, fruitiness, pepperyness, everythingness! It's quite enjoyable and quite smooth and creamy. The finish brings forth a surprising yet mellow caramel maltiness. 

This complex beer is simply an awesome treat to drink. I'm happier than the monk on the label.

Creamy head, but not very firm. Orange colour. Good aroma, yeasty, orange peel in the nose. Spicy taste, moderatly sweet and not very alcoholic for this style. Aftertaste is first a little bit sweet, but then very dry, with a not very exiting bitterness. Too dry for me.

Dark golden color with a tall off white head.  Light yeast and mild orange aroma, with a hint of resin. Sweet light fruit in the start and continued throughout the quaff.  Definite overripe bananas oozing all over this one. Alcohol also shows up for a banana foster furor.  Too many phenols distract.

Cloudy golden colour. Nose with yeast and fruits. Flavour is very fruity (oranges, apples) with some spices too (coriander?). Sweet but well balanced - you hardly notice the alcohol. A very nice tripel.

Bottle conditioned. Gold colour, good head and lots of condition but remarkably soft and smooth in the mouth. Yeasty nose with hints of bread and whisky before smoothing off into sweet malt. More yeast in the mouth with toffee and a spicy note that reminded me of coconuts. A dry bitterness develops into the finish.

Hazy blonde color with large rocky white head.  Crisp and clean with fruit spice aroma, very refreshing. Has a bread taste with some slight spice to it.  Very dry finish leaving an almost cottonmouth feel.
Sweet and very light for a tripel. Aroma is very banana-y. Sticky head. Dark wheat color. Just not impressive, IMO.

Has a cider or bile look to it with heavy carbonation and a fruit/alcohol smell.  Taste is fruit/spice/alcohol and finishes with a slight alcohol flavor.  Overall this is the best that I have tried from this Abbey.  It has had the least amount of alcohol flavor and the carbonation fizz was not that apparent.

One of the many belgians I enjoyed at Lucky Baldwins. A dirty blonde color to it with a strong aroma of dough. The dough was apparent in the flavor as well but more specifically to the likes of a sourdough.  I would have liked some more flavors to be apparent, but the dough was very strong.  Wouldn't know it had 7.5 percent from the taste of it. Well hidden. An above average brew that i would like to try again to hunt out some of the fruit flavors.
Spicy,mild yeast aroma.Opaque blond appearance with a good carbonation and head.Thick flavor of bread dough,candy sugar,nutmeg and bananas with a mild hop finish.No alcohol burn at all.

Had this one from daught at Lucky Baldwins in Pasadena. My impression was that it was far too simple for the as much as this brewery is hyped up to. It poured a dark blonde, light brownish clear color with no head apparent. It smelled of doughy breadiness and malts with a bit of alcohol coming through. The taste is yeasty, bready and pretty much nothing else. Some redeeming qualities in that its carbonation level is held in check, and the yeast masks the alcohol decently, but its just too simple and without kick to really make a lasting impression on me. Fairly dry ending, mildly acidic, but nothing great by any means.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 Draught: Clear golden color..so transparent..no or maybe little head...Aroma of christmas cookies and some more thick sweet spices..mouthfeel was thick and creamy..flavors of banana bread, yeast & thick malts..more banana..Lots of coriander..No notes of alcohol at all..very nice.

The aroma was just medium. But, man, was this a sipmly beautiful beer. Rich, honey gold color. Fluffy white head. Great lacing. Sweet and fruity. Strong notes of cinnamon, nutmeg and clove in the middle. Slightly dry finish. An excellent beer.

Hazy darker gold body, off white head, and slightly hazy.  There was also a ring around the neck of bottle at the top of the beer; usually not a good sign.  Aroma initially is musty and lightly malty; slight hop aromas and a little fruity and clovey.  The flavor is grapey and acidic; clove flavor seems to be absent and finishes dry with an oddly sweet/metallic.  Fruitiness is balanced and sort of overwhelmed by tart acidity and yeasty flavors as well.  The body is light and the carbonation is high, typical of a tripel, but something in this beer was just off.  I'm thinking it was slightly infected(bacterial) and the alcohol was a little more than warming. It was actually hot and seemed a little higher than 7.5% ABV.  It was also astringent.  I'd rate this beer another time to give it another chance, this was definitely not a good bottle to rate.  After reading a few of the other ratings after I rated this, the darker color might also be attributed to infection.

Excellent. Pours w. banana peel yellow color, cloudy, fruity/yeasty with an herbal component. Rich and sweet, but well-balanced with very smooth mouthfeel. Tropical fruits, fennel seed, pepper, banana, malt. Some earthiness  but mostly just really smooth. Almost has a Unibroue quality about it. Refreshing juicy finish. Could drink alot of these.

Pours a golden hay color with a light head whose large bubbles quickly disappeared.  The aroma was appealing, a little sweet, but also dry.  Yeasty, clovey, grassy and a touch of banana.  The flavors are quite nice.  Rather similar to the aroma, but a surprizing bit of bitterness in the finish.  In a good way, mind you.  A pretty good tripel, but note as much complexity as I've had, and enjoyed, in others.
Grassy, citrus nose. Orange and orange peel spice in the taste. Dry finish.

Bright yellow color with a big white head. Sweet and flowery aroma.
Flavor is sweet, yeast, pepper, hops and somewhat acidic. Long dry peppery finish.

Solid white head sits atop an orange/amber beer that is slightly hazy.  Spicy and yeasty aroma, with a bready and very full mouthfeel that I like.  Alcohol, spice, and the yeast characteristics blend well to make am enjoyable tripel.  Finish is very dry and slightly bitter.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2005 Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is
hazy medium amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly yeasty (mold, cobwebs), lightly malty (light bread), lightly hoppy (herbs, flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation,
moderately alcoholic. Rather dull and bland example of the style.
A nose redolent of fruitiness, slight hop nose, citrusy/woodlike taste, and lingering finish w/accessable alcoholic dryness. Head lingers and lingers. Not among the best tripels, but good.
Light fruity, citrusy nose; hazy orange color; big bubbled foamy head. Hints of oranges behind a rich yeasty malt body. Slightly chalky finish and a whiff of alcohol in the swallow. A solid tripel.

Deep golden-orange in color, huge foamy head that sticks around forever, spicy yeasty aroma of cotton candy. Sweet fruity flavors like banana bread, full body with a soft and creamy mouthfeel, has a sticky candy sweet finish, alcohol very well hidden, a great tripple.
Oranges and grapes in the nose. Hazy orange color with a medium frothy head on top. Fruity - I would say like Kumquats. Nice and refreshing.
Yeast (as others note) is very apparent in the aroma, a bit of spice as well.  Nice mouthfeel, sweetish without being cloying.  Alcohol well hidden.  A very solid triple.

Golden, slight haze, creamy head and lace. Nose of banana, pineapple, yeast, alcohol and others. Medium to thick bodied, rich, lush with intense flavors of tropical fruits, sugary malt, acidic yeast that bites nicely and a spicy alcohol kick to boot. A wonderful triple that I will surely revisit.
Draft. Golden-blonde in color, thick in body.  Not spicy or alcoholic, but has a nice malt profile and yeasty flavor.  Excellent with a plate of cheeses.

Straw-orangey colour. Thick creamy head. Nose of special malts, coriandre and blue cheese. Yeasty.
Taste: bitter, spicey (coriandre again). Very obvious underlying sweetness. Rich mouthfeel; alcohol impression, but not much. 
Tasted example is 75cl Cuvée 2002. no real indication of any difference with the usual 33cl.

Golden color, small creamy head. Small yeast particles floating around. Smells a bit sour, yeasty. Candy sugar is very present in taste and aroma. Thick body for a triple, very sweetsour. Its a quite distinct taste seen also in the other St Bernardus brews. In the darker brews i really loved it, but in this triple brew im not quite amazed. I am missing the spices and/or malts in this triple.
Great aroma with a golden color. Delicious yeasty flavor with a beautiful hop tone.

A tiny bit cloudy dark blond beer with a medium, disappearing head. Yeasty, sweet, slightly malty aroma. The taste is yeast, hop and some alcohol. Fairly lively palate with a slightly bitter finish. It is a rather yeasty beer. I like it.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2003 Classic tripel nose with sunny fruits and some alcohol.  The flavor is rather tight green apple with some woody notes providing interesting relief.  Very tough not to love a beer with a label this cool.  Thin bead of head persists.  Very nice stuff.  Update:  My last sample had a rather substantial caramel base which supported the fruit flavors very nicely.

Re-Rate 11/21/02: The beer pours a tenebrous orangish-yellow color, the head behemothic in size, texture that of whipped cream and the color a dazzlingly white with enormously thick glutinous sheets of lace that clean mightily to the glass. 
Nose is yeast laden, malt, hints of lemon peel, with and underlying sweetness. Front is ambrosial, the top middling in feel, the finish is devilishly carbonated, divinely hopped droughty long lasting aftertaste. This bottle borders on being 2 years old, the high ABV is quite evident in the Belly Warming, and the deep malt body adds much to this beer. Oddly enough, seems people either love it or dislike it, I Love it!

Wheat colored body with a white, diminishing head.
Doughy, sour nose.
Spicy first bite with a sour finish. Slight hops bitterness.
Some lacing. More lemon in the mouth as the beer approaches room temp.
Lots of fruit after the beer warms up. Strong too! Nice.
Treble coulour, the typical colour of a trappist tripel.  Malt aroma.  No pronounced palate, but still rather bad.
UPDATED: AUG 18, 2004 Deep golden color.  Fruity - a subtle apricot(?) flavor.  medium bodied, sweet/dry finish.  Thick candy sugar on the tongue as it warms.  maybe subtle for the style.

Medium dark golden body, medium white head, mild spicy, fruity nose with a touch of alcohol. Flavor is full and fruity, but lacks the spicy bite that I prefer from a tripel. Malty and sweet. Minimal alcohol presence.
golden brown color, large tightly bubbled head w/ champagne effervescence. fruity up front w/ a sweet finish
Perfect for a cool fall afternoon, amber,cloudy, rich. Malty, tart finish, very good indeed.
This one is not a bad one, although not the best tripel. It tastes a bit hoppy, and also bitter, the colour is not completely blonde, a bit more orange...
Weak on the nose. Long lasting head. Fruity pineapple taste. Acidic. Not as good as the 12.
Wonderful nose on this.  I was just a bit let down by the taste and mouthfeel which was more acidic than I like in a tripel.
Tasted with the 8 and 12 which were much preferred.  Nice flavor, but lite finish.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2004 Draught: The colour reminds me of a summertime sunset. Has a cloudy head, that last long. The aroma is not as distinct as other Strong ales, i've tasted. A little weak. Flavour is wellbalanced and smooth. Suited the roasted lamb, with which it was served, perfect.

[4 years old bottle]  Hazy amber colour, thick yoghurt-like head. Dry aroma, malt, old hops. Smooth, well balanced, strong malt and bitterness, pretty strong palate. Doesnt ages well, must try a fresh one.

Best Before 2003:Golden oarnge color.Huge,big bubbled,head,resides to a milky,tiny bubbled head.Great retention.Aromas of fruity yeast odors,pale belgian malts,&perfumey hops.Harshness has subsided with age.True mellow treat.Alcohol hits up front(moderately)followed by a sweet,acidic tingle.The finish is lighly dry at first.As it warms,it changes to a fruity,dry,lingering finish.Very refreshing and mellow with age.

Had the look of a hefe at first. Cloudy golden color, head fades to lace.Aroma tells the tale though. Citrus fruit dominates with a little banana if Im correct. Tart on the tongue with a bit of sourness.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2003 slight head with good retention, flavor is fruity but not as fruity or sweet as Orval. 

Re-rate: LOTS of yeast and a bit of pepper in the aroma. flavor has some prune and fig notes with a definitely nuttiness in the finish..walnut or pecan.
I had this one right after the St-Bernardus 12.  I like this one a bit less but it still has the same complexity.  It seemed a bit more fruity, with big citrus notes.
I like this beer a bit better than the Abt. A little lighter on the palate but the same great tropical fruits and bready qualities.

Sharp, strong citrus taste with distinctive malt flavor.  Rather sweet finish as well.  The initial aroma promises well and the beer generally delivers on this promise albeit weaker than the higher ranked Chimays.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2003   Cloudy golden body, nice head retention. Strong citrus aroma, apples, spice. Malt is citus, lemons/apples, bananas with strong notes of toffee/ butterscotch...light bodies. Innovative and enjoyable tripel. Finish is somewhat acidic, although still citrusy.
In the mix of mass tripel tasting in Brussles this one held its own. A bit more of a toffee caramel flavor than most tripels and a littel less of the spicy sharp flavor and mouthfeel.
Huge, lasting head. Hoparoma, citrus and yeast. Full bodied, some rest sweetness left. Bit tart. Hopbitter taste with citrus, yeast and honey.

orange colour, fine creamy head, beautiful lace, very yeasty, bready aroma, spicy, full-bodied, lot of carbonation, strong bitterness and, unfortunately, the typical banana notes of the St.Bernardus (which was absent in the aroma) shows up in the finish but is never disgusting like in the other products of this brewery - by far the best of the St.Bernardus
A very pleasant and likeable Belgian.  So easy-drinking for a tripel, I thought I had opened a lager by mistake.  ha ha
One of the most easy drinking tripel there is.Sweet,floraly and fruity.
Not as overwhelming as many other triples, even considering its considerable alcohol.  Still, refreshing and a good introduction to the style.
Very light body indeed.  Beautiful, huge white head on this.  Only 7.5% makes this one of the weaker tripels I have sampled, but none the less this is a good beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2008 A very soft mouthfeel.  Rosewater and tangerines. Taste is fruity, grainy and herbal.  The head is as good as a head can look.  It never fades.  At a mere 7.5%, this beer is amazingly quaffable.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Quite surprised looking at the other rating comments. I think this was promissing in the aroma, but disappointing in the taste. Maybe some rated the 9% version here? The aroma is great, like a field of flowers in spring. Looks good too with a golden and bit orange colour, nice head but not as firm as I like. The flavors are flowers again and malts but it lacks a good character. It doesnt feel good, sparkling and not sticky. It finishes malty with some sweetness.
My first beer of the night last night and what a disappointment. Bland and boring, much like the La Trappe i also had last night. Weak flavors, fair aroma of fruit, nothing much else.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2008 Dark gold with a very slight haze.  Slightly sugary malts on the nose with light spice, pear and peach. Soft body.  The alcohol makes a statement early, but the brew turns sweet, almost cloying, before spice and peachy fruit finish u.  Smells Belgian, drinks American.

Incredible triple unlike any other out there. With the warming of the glass you get all kinds of aromas just roaring out. This one is a sipper though.Earlier Rating: 8/20/2001 Total Score: 4.7Terrific beer people! Michael Jackson gives the best description:
Almost iridescent, orange colour; the aroma of rosewater; suprisingly light on the tongue for such a strong beer; a palate that suggest vanilla, cookies and sesame seeds; and a tangerine-like finish.
Its tastes much better then the label looks. You would expect a terrible fake-Westmalle or something like that, but it has its own style.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2003 Starts malty, fruity, finishes slightly dry with alcohol warmth. Notes of tangerine, apple, pear, woddiness, spice. Well balanced and flexible. Would work as summertime refresher or late nightcap.
Definitely one of the stronger triples, both in terms of spice and alcohol flavor.  This is not a beginners beer.
